• The transport properties of nonlinear non-equilibrium dynamical systems, particularly ratchet systems, are not well understood. Ratchet systems are asymmetric periodic potentials where an ensemble of particles experience directed transport. This phenomenon is of interest because it seems to occur in biological systems, where useful work is extracted from unbiased noisy fluctuations.
<summary>

• Recently, there has been focus on the behavior of deterministic chaotic ratchets and Hamiltonian ratchets. Chaotic systems are defined by their sensitivity to initial conditions. The behavior of nonlinear systems, including the transition from regular to chaotic behavior, is generally sensitive to the system's parameters. The phase-space structure of these systems can be complex, consisting of stability islands embedded in chaotic seas or of simultaneously coexisting attractors. This structure can change significantly as parameters change.

• A few years ago, Mateos considered a specific ratchet model with a periodically forced underdamped particle. Mateos looked at an ensemble of particles and found that the velocity, averaged over time and the entire ensemble, could be either positive or negative depending on the amplitude of the periodic forcing. Mateos conjectured a connection between these two phenomena, suggesting that the reversal of current direction was correlated with a bifurcation from chaotic to periodic behavior in the trajectory dynamics.

• However, a later investigation by Barbi and Salerno argued that this was not a valid rule, even in the specific system considered by Mateos. They proposed an alternative origin for current reversal, suggesting it was related to the different stability properties of the rotating periodic orbits of the system.

• The paper by Barbi and Salerno, however, based its arguments about currents on the behavior of a single particle, implicitly assuming that the system is ergodic. This is not true in general for chaotic systems of the type being considered. In particular, there can be extreme dependence of the result on the statistics of the ensemble being considered.

• The paper reports studies on the properties of the current in a chaotic deterministic ratchet, specifically the same system as considered by Mateos and Barbi and Salerno. The studies consider the impact of different kinds of ensembles of particles on the current and show that the current depends significantly on the details of the initial ensemble.

1. The discovery of over 200 extrasolar planets has revealed a wide range of eccentricities, with many having moderate to high eccentricities.
2. Several theories have been proposed to explain the origin of highly eccentric extrasolar planets, including planet-planet scattering and merger scenarios.
3. Interactions with stellar companions can also boost a planet's eccentricity, and the Kozai mechanism can induce large-amplitude oscillations in a planet's eccentricity.
4. Of the 15 stars hosting a planet with high eccentricity, six also have stellar-mass companions in wide binary orbits.
5. The Kozai mechanism has been suggested to explain the high eccentricity of certain planets, such as 16 Cyg Bb and HD 80606b.
6. Test particle simulations have been performed to investigate the dynamical possibility of additional low-mass planets in six planetary systems.
7. The simulations show that there are regions in which additional planets could remain in stable orbits, and protected resonances are present in some systems.
8. Combining these simulations with detection limits computed using new high-precision HET data and all available published data can help rule out additional short-period planets in the dynamically stable regions of certain systems.
9. The research was supported by NASA and made use of the NASA Astrophysics Data System and the SIMBAD database.

<summary>

* The LEP experiments at the resonance of the Z-boson have tested the Standard Model (SM) at the quantum level, measuring the Z-decay into fermion pairs with high precision. The agreement between LEP data and SM predictions has constrained new physics at the Z-pole.
* The physics of the Z-boson is expected to play a central role in the frontier of particle physics if the next generation Z-factory is realized, which can generate Z events several orders of magnitude higher than that of LEP. This factory can be realized in the GigaZ option of the International Linear Collider (ILC).
* The rare Z-decays, such as flavor changing processes and decays into light Higgs bosons, have been studied in various new physics models. These decays can have significantly enhanced rates in new physics models, which can be tested in the GigaZ.
* The nmSSM and the nearly minimal supersymmetric standard model (nmSSM) are non-minimal supersymmetric models that can avoid the muon problem and alleviate the little hierarchy problem by having a light CP-odd Higgs boson with a singlet-dominant component. These models can also accommodate a light CP-odd Higgs boson, which can lead to new decay modes of the Z-boson.
* The properties of the lightest CP-odd Higgs boson, such as its mass and couplings, are limited by the relic density of the lightest supersymmetric particle (LSP) and the phenomenology of the nmSSM. The LSP in the nmSSM is a singlino-dominated neutralino, which is difficult to annihilate sufficiently to get the correct density in the current universe.
* The rare Z-decays into a pair of light CP-odd Higgs bosons, a pair of light scalar bosons, or a pair of light pseudoscalar bosons can proceed via the Feynman diagrams shown in Fig.1, Fig.2, and Fig.3, respectively. The intermediate state in these diagrams represents all possible CP-even Higgs bosons in the corresponding model, and the width effect is properly included in the propagator of the intermediate state.
</summary>

1. Supersymmetry (SUSY) is an attractive extension of the Standard Model that solves the naturalness problem and predicts gauge coupling unification at the GUT scale. It also predicts the existence of superpartners of the SM particles, with their masses expected to be below the TeV range. Mechanisms of SUSY breaking and its mediation to the MSSM sector are important problems in SUSY phenomenology, and if SUSY breaking is mediated by gravity, the structure of SUSY breaking masses of scalars is determined by the Kähler potential.
2. The no-scale type Kähler potential is a highly predictive scenario in which all scalar masses and trilinear scalar couplings vanish as the cosmological constant vanishes, leaving only gaugino masses as the source of SUSY breaking. This scenario is also interesting from the viewpoint of the SUSY flavor problem, as the separation of the hidden sector and the observable sector implies that couplings between the two sectors are flavor blind, suppressing contributions of SUSY particles to FCNC.
3. The no-scale structure of the Kähler potential is obtained in various models, including weakly coupled heterotic string theory and the sequestered sector scenario in a five-dimensional setting with two branes. In the sequestered sector scenario, the hidden sector fields live on one brane and the visible sector fields live on the other, and the form of the Kähler potential of the effective theory obtained by dimensional reduction is indeed given by eq. ([eq : noscalekahler]).
4. In the no-scale scenario, the degrees of freedom of SUSY particle mass spectrum are limited, as only non-zero soft SUSY breaking masses are gaugino masses and Higgs mixing mass at the energy scale where the boundary condition is given. Phenomenological aspects of this scenario have been investigated, with direct search bounds and the cosmological constraint (i.e., a charged particle cannot be the LSP if R-parity is conserved) considered to identify the allowed region in the parameter space. The constraints are more severe when universal gaugino masses are given at the GUT scale, but are less severe when the boundary condition is given above the GUT scale or when non-universal gaugino masses are given at the GUT scale.

<summary>

* Colliding plane waves (CPW) result in spacelike singularities, but this strength is weakened by relative cross polarization prior to collision.
* A solution by Chandrasekhar and Xanthopoulos (CX) possesses a Cauchy horizon (CH) instead of a spacelike singularity, which led to a literature devoted to the stability of horizons formed in CPW spacetimes.
* CH formed in CPW spacetimes was shown to be unstable against plane-symmetric perturbations, and any such perturbation applied to a CPW spacetime will turn the CH into an essential singularity.
* The electromagnetic (EM) field itself weakens the strength of a singularity in CPW, and collision of pure EM waves must have a special significance as far as singularity formation is concerned.
* A solution describing the collision of two linearly polarized step EM waves was given by Bell and Szekeres (BS), where the singularity (a CH) formed in the interaction region is removable by a coordinate transformation, but essential curvature singularities exist on the null boundaries.
* A cross polarized version of the BS (CPBS) solution was found, which has the nice feature that the Weyl scalars are all regular in the interaction region, but it does not remove the singularities formed on the null boundaries.
* The paper chooses the CPBS solution as a test ground to justify the validity of a CH stability conjecture proposed by Helliwell and Konkowski (HK).
* The paper looks at the spacetimes of single plane waves with added colliding test fields and colliding plane waves having non-singular interaction regions with test field added.
* The terminology of singularities should be followed from the classification presented by Ellis and Schmidt, and the CH stability conjecture due to HK is defined.
</summary>

1. X-ray studies of "normal" galaxies have been extended to cosmologically interesting distances through deep field surveys, which have now reached 1 ms of exposure. These surveys have detected significant numbers of normal galaxies among the population of X-ray sources contributing to the diffuse X-ray background (XRB).
2. Normal galaxies are likely to be the most numerous extragalactic X-ray sources in the universe and are expected to dominate the number counts at 0.52 keV fluxes of ~10^-15 erg s^-1 cm^-2. They contribute as much as 50-100% of the XRB flux in the 0.52 keV band.
3. The study of normal galaxies in deep X-ray surveys can help constrain models of X-ray binary production in galaxies and investigate the typical galaxy's X-ray emission, whether it is dominated by X-ray binaries, hot interstellar gas, or a low-luminosity active galactic nucleus (AGN).
4. Statistical methods such as stacking can be used to estimate the emission at extremely faint flux levels for individual galaxies. This technique has been successfully implemented in previous studies to detect X-ray emission from the average bright galaxy in the Hubble Deep Field-North and a study of Lyman break galaxies.
5. This study extends the analysis to the entire plus flanking fields region, focusing on galaxies at z~1 due to extensive spectroscopic redshift coverage and superb imaging for galaxy morphology studies. The Chandra Deep Field-North data provide extremely deep X-ray coverage over this area, allowing for the detection of x-ray emission from normal galaxies and the placement of observational constraints on the evolution of the ratio of X-ray luminosity to K-band luminosity for normal spiral galaxies up to z~1.

<summary>

* Quantum systems can exhibit non-classical correlations, which can't be described by classical physics.
* There are different degrees of non-classicality for quantum correlations, ranging from non-separable or entangled states to those that violate Bell inequalities.
* Non-separable or entangled states are those that can't be expressed as a mixture of product states of the constituents.
* Bell-nonlocality is the phenomenon where measurement correlations violate a Bell inequality, indicating the violation of local causality.
* EPR-steering is a weaker form of non-locality, which is the only way to verify the existence of entanglement if either party or their detectors can't be trusted.
* A bipartite state is said to be EPR-steerable if it allows for a demonstration of EPR-steering.
* The set of separable states is a strict subset of the set of non-EPR-steerable states, which is a strict subset of the set of Bell-local states.
* The steering ellipsoid formalism can be used to investigate EPR-steerability of quantum states.
* The authors use the steering ellipsoid formalism to develop a deterministic LHS model for projective measurements on t-states and obtain sufficient conditions for t-states to be EPR-steerable.
</summary>

<summary>

- The concept of using an electron's spin to encode binary information was first proposed by an unidentified individual and later popularized by Feynman.
- Spintronic logic gates, which use spin to encode information, were first proposed in the mid-1990s and have the potential for lower power dissipation, reduced noise, and faster operation compared to traditional charge-based devices.
- In a spin-based NAND gate, the spin orientation of confined electrons in quantum dots is used to represent binary information, with the ground state of the array encoding the logic 1 state.
- The use of spin in classical irreversible logic gates results in a minimum amount of energy dissipation per bit flip, which can be significant for high-density quantum dot arrays.
- Reversible logic gates, which do not have the same energy dissipation constraints, have been proposed as a solution to the heat dissipation challenge.
- The use of spin to encode qubits in solids has gained popularity due to the longer coherence times of spin compared to charge coherence times.
- Optical readout of qubits in quantum dots has advantages over electrical readout, as it does not require contacts and can be performed using circularly polarized light.

</summary>

1. Cataclysmic variables (CVs) are binary star systems with a white dwarf primary and a low-mass main sequence secondary that transfers mass to the white dwarf. The orbital period distribution of CVs with hydrogen-rich donors has a lack of systems in the 2-3 hour period range (the period gap) and a sharp cut-off at around 77 minutes. However, theoretical models have been unable to accurately reproduce the observed short-period cut-off and shape of the CV orbital period distribution near this cut-off.
2. The minimum period of CVs occurs where the mass transfer time scale and the thermal time scale are about equal. The position of the minimum period is affected by the assumed mass transfer rate and the rate of orbital angular momentum losses. The paper investigates ways to increase the period minimum by increasing the mass transfer rate and introducing a spread of minimum period values in the CV population. The study considers a form of consequential angular momentum loss (CAML) where the angular momentum is lost as a consequence of the mass transferred from the secondary.
3. The orbital angular momentum loss rate of a CV can be written as the sum of the systemic angular momentum loss rate and an explicit function of the mass transfer rate. The paper considers the general case in which the CAML mechanism, along with nova mass ejections, causes a fraction of the transferred mass to leave the system. The angular momentum is assumed to be lost via mass loss that is axis-symmetrical with respect to an axis fixed at the white dwarf center but perpendicular to the orbital plane. The paper calculates the long-term evolution of CVs as they approach and evolve beyond the period minimum, and compares the observed short-period CV period distribution with various theoretically synthesized model distributions.

• Stephan's Quintet (SQ) is a compact group that has produced a highly disturbed intragroup medium through a complex sequence of interactions and harassment.
• A large-scale intergalactic shock wave has been produced by the high-velocity collision of an intruder galaxy with the intergalactic medium of the group.
• The shock-heated gas is responsible for the X-ray emission, and the region is powered by strong shocks and not star formation.
• The main elements of SQ include a primary shock, an intruder galaxy (NGC 7318b), a Seyfert 2 galaxy, and other group members.
• The discovery of extremely powerful, pure rotational H2 line emission from the center of the shock has sparked intense interest in the SQ system.
• The collision between two inhomogeneous gas flows describes H2 formation out of the multiphase, shocked gas, and an efficient cooling channel for high-speed shocks as an alternative to X-ray emission.
• Several other systems exhibiting similarly strong H2 emission have been discovered, and a large subset of local 3CR radio galaxies have extremely dominant MIR rotational H2 lines.

<summary>

- The short-lived radioisotope (SLRI) @xmath4al was present during the formation of the first refractory solids in the solar nebula, suggesting that at least some of the solar system's SLRIs may have been injected by a supernova or AGB star shock wave.
- The isotopic heterogeneity introduced by the SLRI injection could have been substantially reduced in a marginally gravitationally unstable (MGU) disk due to large-scale inward and outward transport and mixing of gas and small particles.
- The stable oxygen isotopes appear to have been spatially heterogeneous in the solar nebula during the early phases of planet formation, possibly due to UV photodissociation of CO molecules at the surface of the outer solar nebula.
- MGU disks can accomplish early large-scale transport of refractory particles from the inner to the outer solar nebula, and are likely involved in FU Orionis outbursts experienced by young solar-type stars.
- MGU models can explain the high mass accretion rates needed to explain FU Orionis events and offer an alternative mechanism for gas giant planet formation.
- The numerical models used in the study were computed with a three-dimensional gravitational hydrodynamics code and show that MGU disk masses assumed in the models may be achieved in some fraction of protoplanetary disks, and perhaps in the solar nebula as well.

</summary>

<summary>

* The authors conduct a search for new particles with a narrow natural width that decay to dijets, including axigluons, excited states of composite quarks, color octet technirhos, new gauge bosons, and scalar diquarks.
* They combine dijet mass spectra from four triggers with integrated luminosities ranging from 0.089 pb@xmath0 to 69.8 pb@xmath0.
* Jets are defined using a fixed cone clustering algorithm and corrected for detector response, energy lost outside the cone, and underlying event.
* The two highest @xmath15 jets are required to have pseudorapidity |η| < 2/3 and a cms scattering angle |cos θ*| < 2/3.
* The data shows an upward fluctuation near 200 gev / c@xmath1, 550 gev / c@xmath1, and 850 gev / c@xmath1.
* The authors set limits on new particle production using the likelihood distribution including experimental systematic uncertainties.
* They exclude topgluons of width @xmath57 in the mass region @xmath58 gev / c@xmath1, @xmath59 for @xmath60 gev / c@xmath1, and @xmath61 for @xmath62 gev / c@xmath1.

</summary>

1. * The first evidence of the universe's accelerated expansion was observed through supernovae type Ia (SNIA) being fainter than expected.
2. * This observation has been confirmed by various independent measurements, including temperature anisotropies of the cosmic microwave background (CMB), inhomogeneities in the matter distribution, the Integrated Sachs-Wolfe (ISW) effect, baryon acoustic oscillations (BAO), weak lensing (WL), and gamma-ray bursts.
3. * Within the framework of General Relativity, the accelerated expansion is attributed to a new energy density component with negative pressure, known as dark energy (DE).
4. * The nature of dark energy is unknown, and understanding its properties is the subject of extensive scientific research.
5. * The current observations are consistent with a cosmological constant being the origin of dark energy, driving the present epoch of accelerated expansion, along with a dark matter (DM) component responsible for the formation of galaxies and large-scale structures.
6. * The concordance model, or ΛCDM, is the favored model, but it is not theoretically satisfying due to the discrepancy between the observed and estimated values of the cosmological constant.
7. * Dynamic dark energy models have been suggested, but they face the coincidence problem, which questions why the time variation of matter and DE are so different if their current values are so similar.
8. * Interacting dark sector models have been introduced to address the coincidence problem and the fine-tuning of the cosmological constant.
9. * The interaction between DE and DM affects the overall evolution of the universe, expansion history, growth of matter and baryon density perturbations, temperature anisotropies of the CMB, and the evolution of the gravitational potential at late times.
10. * These observables can be used to constrain the interaction and test the underlying theory of gravity.

1. The text discusses the spectra of Type 1 Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) and the diversity of broad and narrow emission lines that provide insights into the structure and kinematics of photoionized gas in the vicinity of the central massive object. Broad emission lines, like Hβ, are thought to arise in or near an accretion disk acting as the fuel reservoir for the central supermassive black hole. The text highlights the concept of two Type 1 AGN populations, A and B, with different broad-line widths and profile shifts and asymmetries.
2. The text discusses the use of narrow emission lines, such as [OIII]5007, as a reliable measure of the local quasar rest frame, except in the case of "blue outliers" found in sources with specific properties. The text also mentions the correlation between FWHM Hβ and FWHM FeII, and the effect of FeII emission on the Hβ emission line. Systematic line shifts, such as the blueshift of high ionization lines relative to low ionization lines, are known to place important constraints on models for the geometry and kinematics of the broad line region.
3. The text presents evidence for a systematic redshift of FeII relative to [OIII]5007 in a majority of Type 1 quasars, which has been ascribed to FeII emission arising in a region with dynamics dominated by infall and located at a larger radius than the region producing the bulk of Hβ. The text also discusses the potential importance of such a kinematic signature and the different interpretations that have been proposed.
4. The text presents the authors' skepticism towards the claims of a systematic FeII redshift and their analysis of a sample of quasars, which showed no evidence for a systematic shift of FeII lines relative to Hβ. The authors suggest that the accuracy of FeII shift measures depends on the FeII strength and profile widths, spectral signal-to-noise ratio, and the presence of strong HeII 4686 emission. The authors also suggest that low spectral signal-to-noise ratio and above-average HeII strength are the culprits for the large FeII redshifts reported by other studies.

1. Nuclear multifragmentation is the study of the behavior of nuclear matter under extreme conditions, and is being researched both theoretically and experimentally due to the similarities between the forces within nuclear matter and the van der Waals forces.
2. Experiments have identified a wide plateau in the nuclear caloric curve, which is thought to be indicative of a liquid-gas phase transition in nuclear matter. This has led to new motivation for further research.
3. However, subsequent experiments have not been able to replicate the initial results, with some showing no plateau-like region. These discrepancies are thought to be due to both the precision of experimental measurements and finite-size effects.
4. Recent reevaluations of the initial experiments have brought corrections to the kinetic energies of emitted neutrons and the energies of spectator parts.
5. Theoretical calculations suggest that for certain reactions, there is a significant quantity of nonequilibrium energy present in the measured source excitation energies.
6. Accurate theoretical descriptions of the break-up stage and sequential secondary particle emission are necessary to distinguish between the equilibrium and nonequilibrium parts of the measured excitation energies.
7. The paper describes refinements and improvements to a microcanonical multifragmentation model and its application to recent experimental data.
8. The improvements to the model include the use of experimental discrete energy levels instead of level density for fragments, and the inclusion of the secondary decay stage in the calculations.

1. * The solar corona is heated to a temperature of about 12 million kelvins, which is much higher than the temperature of the visible surface of the sun.
2. * Magnetic fields or waves are believed to play a key role in heating the solar corona.
3. * The primary energy source for this heating is located in the convection zone below the solar photosphere.
4. * The debate is focused on whether the energy to heat the corona comes from dissipation of magneto-hydrodynamic (MHD) waves or from numerous small-scale magnetic reconnection events (nanoflares).
5. * Two types of magnetic disturbances in coronal structures can be produced by the interaction of the magnetic field with convective flows in or below the photosphere.
6. * These magnetic disturbances can generate MHD waves or field-aligned electric currents that can be dissipated resistively in the chromosphere or corona.
7. * The two types of magnetic heating mechanisms can be classified as either wave-heating or current-heating mechanisms.
8. * Theoretical arguments support both mechanisms, but observational evidence for nanoflares is less convincing than before.
9. * A set-up is described to search for high-frequency coronal oscillations using the mid-sized coronagraph at Lomnicky Peak Observatory and the SECIS instrument.
10. * The SECIS instrument was built to search for short-period coronal light oscillations and has been used successfully in several total solar eclipses.

1. * Water vapor is an important molecule for the chemistry of interstellar and circumstellar clouds, and has been studied using various transitions of H2O.
2. * The 618-519 masing transition of H2O at 22 GHz has been used to trace high excitation gas around star forming regions and evolved stars, but provides no information on large spatial scales.
3. * Other H2O lines have been detected from ground or airborne based telescopes, but only the 311-212 transition at 183 GHz has been used to map the emission of H2O at very large spatial scale.
4. * The ISO satellite has provided the opportunity to observe thermal lines of water in the middle and far-infrared, and mapping of the SgrB2 molecular cloud has shown that water vapor is an ubiquitous molecule in molecular clouds with an abundance of 107.
5. * The observation of another masing transition of H2O with similar properties to those of the 183 GHz line would aid in deriving H2O abundances. The 325 GHz line of H2O was observed in the direction of Orion IRC2, but no maps were obtained.
6. * The present data show the importance of ground-based observations of H2O in deriving the abundance of H2O in molecular clouds and in providing useful constraints on the physical conditions of the emitting regions.

<summary>

* Threshold nets are obtained by assigning weights to nodes and connecting nodes with combined weights above a certain threshold.
* They can be produced with arbitrary degree distributions, including scale-free, and encompass a wide variety of architectures.
* Threshold graphs have a modular structure, where a subsequence of consecutive s gives rise to a -clique, and nodes in a subsequence of s connect to s thereafter, but not among one another.
* Given the sequence of a threshold net, important structural benchmarks such as degree distribution, triangles, betweenness centrality, and the spectrum and eigenvectors of the graph laplacian can be computed.
* The malleability of threshold nets allows for the design of nets with specific degree distribution, spectrum of eigenvalues, etc.
* Despite their limitations, threshold nets have desirable attributes such as modularity, easily computable structural measures, and high degree of compressibility.
* A broader class of nets, called sequence nets, can be constructed from a sequence of letters by deterministic rules of connectivity, allowing for more latitude in describing nets while retaining analytical appeal.
* The paper explores the general class of sequence nets, finding that threshold nets are only one of three equivalence classes characterized by the highest level of symmetry.

</summary>

1. * Variable selection methods based on penalty theory have been widely used in high-dimensional data analysis.
2. * The Lasso method, which uses the L1-norm penalty, is a popular variable selection method.
3. * The Lasso estimate can be viewed as the mode of the posterior distribution, and can be transformed into the Laplace prior in a Bayesian framework.
4. * Nonconvex penalization has also been studied under a parametric Bayesian framework, leading to methods such as the local linear approximation (LLA) algorithm.
5. * The LLA algorithm was derived by combining the Expectation Maximization (EM) algorithm with an inverse Laplace transform.
6. * The prior induced from a penalty, called the nonconvex log penalty, has an interpretation as a scale mixture of Laplace distributions with an inverse gamma mixing distribution.
7. * Nonparametric Bayesian approaches have also been applied to variable selection, such as the infinite gamma Poisson model and the beta-Bernoulli process.
8. * Subordinators, which are one-dimensional Lévy processes that are almost surely non-decreasing, have been used in Bayesian nonconvex penalization problems.
9. * In this paper, the authors study the application of subordinators in Bayesian nonconvex penalization problems under supervised learning scenarios, by modeling latent shrinkage parameters using subordinators.
10. * The authors also establish the connection of two nonconvex penalty functions, log and exp, with the Laplace transforms of the gamma and Poisson subordinators.

1. The text discusses the use of nonlinear current response as a probe of order parameter symmetry in superconductors, specifically in the case of two-band superconductors like MgB2. It highlights the importance of considering strong electron-phonon coupling and dimensionality in understanding the nonlinear response.
2. The authors present strong-coupling correction formulas for three dimensions and discuss the behavior of the nonlinear coefficient in the context of strong electron-phonon coupling. They also provide a prediction for the nonlinear coefficient in MgB2 using parameters from band structure calculations.
3. The text mentions the importance of experimental verification of their predictions and acknowledges funding and support from various institutions and individuals. It also cites several relevant papers and experimental studies in the field of superconductivity.

1. The classification problem is important in time series data mining, and the 1-nearest neighbor (1-NN) with dynamic time warping (DTW) distance is a well-performing classifier for time series data.
2. The selection of an appropriate distance measure is crucial for 1-NN classification, and the DTW distance has been shown to be more appropriate and accurate than the commonly used Euclidean distance.
3. The Sakoe-Chiba band (S-C band) was originally introduced to speed up DTW calculation and later used as a global constraint for DTW.
4. The size of the global constraint in S-C band depends on the properties of the data, and recent work has shown that the classification accuracy depends solely on this global constraint.
5. The Ratanamahatana-Keogh band (R-K band) generalizes the global constraint model and allows for multi-bands representing each class of data, adjustable according to its own class warping path.
6. A learning algorithm is needed to discover the best multi R-K bands, and the original work of R-K band proposed a hill climbing search algorithm with two heuristic functions.
7. The proposed paper introduces two new learning algorithms, band boundary extraction and iterative learning, to solve the overfitting problem in the learning algorithm of R-K band.
8. The two novel learning algorithms are based on four major fundamental concepts: dynamic time warping (DTW) distance, Sakoe-Chiba band (S-C band), Ratanamahatana-Keogh band (R-K band), and silhouette index.
9. The proposed time series classification algorithm is based on 1-nearest neighbor classification using the dynamic time warping distance with multi R-K bands as a global constraint.
10. The proposed learning algorithms use silhouette index as a heuristic function for selecting the band that yields the best prediction accuracy, and the lb\_keogh lower bound is used in data prediction step to speed up the computation.

1. The Standard Model (SM) of elementary particles has been successful in describing nature at the electroweak scale, and the recent discovery of a new particle consistent with the SM Higgs boson by the ATLAS and CMS collaborations at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) strengthens its correctness. However, there is still no explicit evidence of physics beyond the SM reported from the LHC. An anomaly in the muon anomalous magnetic moment (muon g-2) has been observed, with estimated discrepancies consistently more than expected, which could potentially hint at new physics beyond the SM.
2. The paper explores the possibility of a new gauge interaction for the muon beyond the SM. The mass terms of the leptons in the Lagrangian are given by Yukawa couplings, with the neutrino mass determined by Yukawa couplings and Majorana masses. The neutrino mixing is obtained through mixing among the right-handed neutrinos. The seesaw mechanism provides the observed order one neutrino mixing if the Majorana masses are of the same order.
3. The interactions that break the lepton symmetry and the anomaly against the gauge interaction can wash out the baryon asymmetry in the early universe. A condition is calculated to prevent the washout, and it is found that if the baryon asymmetry is generated below the electroweak scale, the washout does not occur. If the baryon asymmetry is produced above the electroweak scale, the constraint on the parameters in the mass terms is calculated, and two possibilities are considered to prevent the washout.

• Entanglement in quantum multipartite systems has unique properties and plays an important role in quantum information processing.
<summary>

• The study of entanglement's essential features and dynamical behavior under decoherence has attracted much attention.
<summary>

• Entanglement sudden death (ESD) has been observed in qubits under Markovian decoherence, where entanglement is lost in a finite time.
<summary>

• However, further studies have shown that revived entanglement and finite residual entanglement can also occur after ESD.
<summary>

• The lost entanglement of qubits is exclusively transferred to the reservoirs under Markovian amplitude-damping decoherence dynamics.
<summary>

• Entanglement dynamics in a double Jaynes-Cummings model shows that entanglement is transferred periodically among all bipartite partitions.
<summary>

• A similar situation occurs for spin entanglement when the spin degree of freedom interacts with its momentum degree of freedom.
<summary>

• A system with two qubits locally interacting with two amplitude-damping reservoirs exhibits rich dynamical behaviors, including stable entanglement distribution.
<summary>

• The distribution of entanglement among bipartite subsystems depends on the explicit property of the reservoir and its coupling to the qubit.
<summary>

• The identity about the entanglement in the whole system is always satisfied at any time, revealing the profound physics of entanglement dynamics under decoherence.
<summary>

1. Gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) are powerful flashes of gamma rays that lack a definitive explanation, but are believed to be associated with huge energy releases from the collapse of a very massive star or the coalescence of a compact binary system.
2. Gravitational waves (GWs) are expected to be emitted during these events, with a duration of a few milliseconds and an amplitude that can be detected by present resonant detectors.
3. A program was launched to study the presence of correlations between GRB events detected with the BEPPOSAX satellite and the output signals from gravitational antennas NAUTILUS and EXPLORER.
4. An algorithm based on cross-correlating the outputs of two GW detectors is used to cope with the problem of the unknown possible time difference between GRB and GW bursts and unmodelled noise.
5. The analysis resulted in new experimental upper limits for the burst intensity causing correlations of GWs with GRBs, with a 95% probability of excluding signals of amplitude 10^-22 Hz^(-1/2) for a time window of 100 ms.
6. The results are given in terms of scaled likelihood and sensitivity bound, which are considered the most complete and unbiased way of providing experimental information.

1. <summary>The number of citations a scientific paper receives is often used as a measure of its scientific credibility, although this should be interpreted with caution. The distribution of citations among scientific papers is known to follow a power-law form, with highly cited papers being more likely to receive further citations.</summary>
2. <summary>A simple model is proposed to study the citation distribution of scientific publications, focusing on two research areas and referencing within and across each other. This model can also be applied to the web of human sexual contacts, where interactions between males and females can be thought of as two coupled growing networks.</summary>
3. <summary>The model is analyzed using a rate equation approach, and the time evolution of the joint distribution of intra-links and cross-links is described. The total in-degree distribution in each network is shown to follow a power-law form, with an exponent that depends on the average total in-degree and the initial attractiveness of the nodes.</summary>
4. <summary>The distribution of the average number of nodes with a certain number of intra-links in a network is also studied, and it is shown to have a power-law form that depends on both the average total in-degree and the coupling parameter. The distribution of the average number of nodes with incoming cross-links is found to have a power-law form as well, but with exponents that are inversely proportional to the coupled parameters.</summary>
5. <summary>The model is then applied to citation networks and the web of human sexual contacts, showing that it can represent a variety of complex systems. The power-law exponent of the intra-link distribution is shown to be equal to the total link distribution in the weak coupling case, and to decrease as the rate of cross-linking increases.</summary>

1. Hadron production at large transverse momentum in hadronic or nuclear collisions is traditionally described in a two-step process involving hard scattering of partons followed by fragmentation of the scattered parton to the detected hadron.
2. The first part is calculable in perturbation QCD, while the second part uses fragmentation functions determined phenomenologically. However, this production mechanism has been found to be inadequate for particle production at intermediate transverse momentum in heavy-ion collisions.
3. A new hadronization process, recombination of partons, is shown to be more appropriate, especially when soft partons are involved. At extremely high transverse momentum, fragmentation is still dominant.
4. The goal is to have a universal description of hadronization based on the same scheme for any transverse momentum. To achieve this, the fragmentation process should be treated as the result of recombination of shower partons in a jet.
5. The paper aims to introduce the notion of shower partons and determine their distributions to represent phenomenological fragmentation functions in terms of recombination.
6. The subject matter is primarily of interest in high-energy nuclear collisions because hadronization in such processes is always in the environment of soft partons.
7. The concept of shower partons is not new, but previous attempts to generate such partons in pQCD processes cannot be easily related to shower partons and their hadronization due to the limitation of pQCD.
8. The paper will discuss the similarities and differences in various approaches and demonstrate the importance of recombination of shower partons with thermal partons in heavy-ion collisions.

<summary>

* The text discusses a nonconvex semidefinite programming problem with a convex objective function, a nonempty, closed convex set, and nonconvex matrix-valued mappings.
* Nonconvex semidefinite programming problems have applications in static output feedback controller design and topology optimization.
* Many attempts have been made to solve these problems using convex semidefinite programming techniques, such as augmented Lagrangian functions, generalized sequential semidefinite programming, and alternating directions.
* A new method based on convex-concave decomposition and linearization technique has been proposed.
* The paper aims to develop a new local optimization method for solving the nonconvex semidefinite programming problem by approximating the feasible set with a sequence of inner positive semidefinite convex approximation sets.
* The contribution of the paper includes the generalization of the inner convex approximation method from scalar optimization to nonlinear semidefinite programming and the modification of the algorithm with a regularization technique.

* The paper shows applications in static output feedback control and numerical tests.
* The paper assumes that all functions and matrix-valued mappings are twice differentiable on their domain.

1. The Dirac-Kähler formulation of fermionic field theory is a valuable tool in extracting the geometric meaning of continuum vector theories, but regularizing calculations requires the introduction of a discrete differential geometry scheme with the same properties as the continuum and a correct continuum limit. Several discrete schemes have been proposed, but defining such a scheme has proven challenging due to difficulties with the Hodge star and the wedge product between forms.
2. Adams proposed a local, discrete differential geometry for an arbitrary topological space using two parallel lattices to maintain the locality of the Hodge star and a finite element scheme to capture the properties of the wedge product. This proposal has been thoroughly studied and can potentially offer insight into developing non-degenerate, doubler-free fermionic field theories for the lattice. In this paper, the authors show how this proposal can be used to describe chiral symmetry in the associated Dirac-Kähler formulation and extend the idea to describe exact flavour projection.
3. In lattice quantum chromodynamics (Lattice QCD) calculations, the staggered fermion formulation is commonly used to describe fermions and address the problem of fermion doubling by reducing the number of degenerate fermions in the theory. The continuous Dirac-Kähler formulation is regarded as providing the continuum limit for the staggered fermion formulation, so a discrete Dirac-Kähler formulation with continuum properties can offer insight into developing non-degenerate, doubler-free fermionic field theories for the lattice.
4. The authors show how the two lattices of Adams' proposal can be used to describe chiral symmetry in the associated Dirac-Kähler formulation and extend the idea to describe exact flavour projection. This necessitates the introduction of two new structures of lattice and a new operator. The authors also evaluate the path integral for this formulation, considering the effects of chiral and flavour projection.

1. The text discusses the use of cognitive radio networks and information-theoretic security to ensure secure wireless communication. Cognitive radio networks allow secondary users to transmit on the same frequency band as primary users, as long as the interference power at the primary receivers is kept below a certain limit. Information-theoretic security involves using the secrecy capacity to transmit messages while keeping the eavesdropper ignorant of the transmitted information. The text also discusses the use of cooperative relaying and beamforming to improve the secrecy rates in cognitive radio networks.
2. The text also presents the collaborative relay beamforming problem in cognitive radio networks under secrecy constraints. The authors formulate the beamforming optimization problem as a quasiconvex optimization problem, which can be solved through convex semidefinite programming. They also propose two sub-optimal null space beamforming schemes to reduce the computational complexity. The authors consider a cognitive relay channel with a source, a destination, an eavesdropper, and multiple relays, and assume that there is no direct link between the source and the destination, and that the relays work synchronously to perform beamforming. They derive the optimal beamforming solution that maximizes the secrecy rate in the cognitive relay channel using semidefinite programming with a two-dimensional search for both total and individual power constraints.

1. The paper discusses the benefits of maintaining conformal invariance when quantizing the Maxwell field in conformally flat spaces (CFSs). It shows that a classical conformally invariant field cannot distinguish between two CFSs, and maintaining this symmetry during quantization allows for a free field in a CFS to behave like it does in flat space. This results in Wightman two-point functions that can be related to their Minkowskian counterparts.
2. The paper uses Dirac's six-cone formalism and realizes all CFSs as intersections of the null cone and a given surface in a six-dimensional Lorentzian space. Auxiliary fields and the Gupta-Bleuler quantization scheme are used to deal with the gauge freedom of the Maxwell field. A well-suited coordinate system is also used to write down the two-point functions in a Minkowskian form.
3. The paper provides the Wightman two-point functions for Maxwell and auxiliary fields in CFSs. It also shows how to obtain the conformally invariant Maxwell field in a CFS from a six-dimensional one-form using the extended Weyl transformation. The dynamical equations for the Maxwell field are transported from Minkowski space to the CFS using the extended Weyl transformation. The paper also discusses the Gupta-Bleuler quantization scheme and the subspace of physical states.

1. The parallel chip-firing game is a chip-distributing process on graphs where vertices simultaneously pass chips to their neighbors if they have enough chips to do so. The game has been shown to have deep connections to number theory, algebra, and combinatorics, and has the ability to simulate classical computer functions and solve theoretically solvable computational problems.
2. The game has been studied on the complete bipartite graph, with lemmas established to limit the number of chips on each vertex in a game with nontrivial period and to find a necessary and sufficient condition for a period to occur. Every possible period for the complete bipartite graph has been found.
3. The game can be used to simulate a pile of particles that falls whenever there are too many particles stacked at any point, a problem in statistical physics known as the deterministic fixed-energy sandpile. This is a subset of the more general study of spatially extended dynamical systems, which display the phenomenon of self-organized criticality and tend towards a critical state.
4. The study of the parallel chip-firing game has implications in various fields, including biology and social science. It is an example of a cellular automaton, and the study of such systems have been used to model real-life systems and display properties such as noise, fractal patterns, and power law distribution.
5. Further research can be done on bounding the periods of positions on vertex-regular graphs and more general bipartite graphs, as well as studying the transient length of games on certain graphs to make for more efficient computation of the period length of games on complex graphs.

1. The observation and analysis of GRB 090510, a short gamma-ray burst (sGRB), have provided valuable insights into the formation process of black holes (BHs) and the structure of the circumburst medium.
2. The exceptional quality of the data from multiple satellites and telescopes, including Fermi, Swift, Agile, Konus-Wind, and Suzaku-WAM, has allowed for detailed temporal and spectral analyses.
3. The theoretical analysis of the broadband emission of GRB 090510 within the synchrotron/self-synchrotron Compton (SSC) and traditional afterglow models has been applied to other distinct sources, suggesting that gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) can be subdivided into various classes and sub-classes with specific progenitors.
4. The identification of different episodes in GRB 090510, such as a new structure in the thermal emission of the precursor (p-GRB) and the onset of the gev emission linked to BH formation, illustrates the formation process of a BH.
5. The discovery of a vast amount of baryon plasma, energetics of GRBs being of the order of 10^52 erg, and additional ultra-high energy cosmic rays with energy up to 10^20 eV originating from such extreme processes supports the possible relation of GRBs with the vacuum polarization process around a Kerr-Newman BH.
6. The large majority of long bursts are related to supernovae (SNe) and spatially correlated with bright star-forming regions in their host galaxies, while short bursts are often associated with neutron star-neutron star (NS-NS) mergers.
7. The induced gravitational collapse (IGC) paradigm explains the GRB-SN connection in terms of the interactions between an evolved carbon-oxygen core (CO@xmath19) undergoing a SN explosion and its hypercritical accretion on a binary NS companion.

1. The text discusses the use of global fits to precision measurements to limit models with physics beyond the Standard Model (SM) and infer information about the parameters of new models. The authors use the example of predicting the W boson mass in the SM, which is strongly correlated with the experimentally measured value of the top quark mass and increases quadratically as the top quark mass is increased. This correlation is used to limit the allowed region for the Higgs boson mass.
2. The authors also discuss the possibility of a heavy Higgs boson that is consistent with precision electroweak data in the context of oblique corrections. They note that a large contribution to isospin violation from new physics can offset the contribution of a heavy Higgs boson to electroweak observables such as the W boson mass.
3. The text also discusses two examples where the new physics does not decouple from the SM at one loop. The first example is a model with a real scalar triplet, and the second example is a left-right symmetric model. The authors show that a correct renormalization scheme gives very different results from the SM result in these models.
4. The authors also show that the dependence on scalar masses in the W boson mass is quadratic and demonstrate that the triplet is non-decoupling.
5. The authors present their major results in eqs. ([cc1])-([cc3]) and provide numerical results in section [results]. They note that similar results have been found in the context of the littlest Higgs model.

1. A log-Riemann surface is a pair (X, f) where X is a Riemann surface and f is a local holomorphic diffeomorphism that realizes X as a finite-sheeted branched covering of the Riemann sphere. A log-Riemann surface of finite type is a generalized branched covering of a punctured compact Riemann surface given by certain transcendental functions of infinite degree. It is shown in [xcite] that a log-Riemann surface of finite type is given by a pair (X0, f) where X0 is a compact Riemann surface and f is a meromorphic function on the punctured surface X16 with essential singularities at the punctures of a specific type.
2. An exp-algebraic curve is a compact Riemann surface together with equivalence classes of germs of meromorphic functions modulo germs of holomorphic functions, with poles of orders at points. The relevant spaces of functions and 1-forms with exponential singularities at the points can be defined, giving rise to a de Rham cohomology group. The integrals of the 1-forms considered along curves in the Riemann surface joining the infinite ramification points converge, giving rise to a pairing between the cohomology group and the space of 1-forms, which was shown to be nondegenerate in [xcite].
3. Exp-algebraic curves appear in the algebro-geometric integration of integrable systems, where certain functions with exponential singularities, namely the Baker-Akhiezer functions, are used. These functions satisfy certain properties related to their divisors of zeroes and poles and are shown to have dimension equal to the degree of the divisor for non-special divisors of degree at least a certain number. Functions and differentials with exponential singularities on compact Riemann surfaces have also been studied in the solution of the Weierstrass problem and in the context of entire functions with structural finiteness conditions.

1. The text discusses the use of dynamical mean field theory (DMFT) and local density approximation (LDA) to understand the physics of strongly correlated electronic systems and their electronic structure near a localization-delocalization transition. A method called LDA+DMFT has been developed, which merges the computationally tractable many-body technique of DMFT with realistic LDA-based electronic structure calculations of strongly correlated solids. This method has been applied to various systems, including transition metal oxides, and has shown promising results.
2. The text also discusses the need for fast scans of the entire parameter space to determine the interaction for a given doping, degeneracy, and bandwidth via the solution of the general multiorbital Anderson impurity model (AIM). However, present approaches based on non-crossing approximation (NCA) or iterative perturbation theory (IPT) are unable to provide the solution to this problem due to a limited number of regimes where these methods can be applied. The quantum Monte Carlo (QMC) technique in DMFT is accurate but has limitations in terms of its applicability to multiorbital situations and unphysically large temperatures.
3. The paper proposes an interpolative approach for the self-energy in the general multiorbital situation, which is not an attempt to develop an alternative method for solving the impurity problem, but rather a follow-up of the ideology of LDA theory where approximations were designed by analytical fits to QMC simulations for homogeneous electron gas. The authors suggest that even crude evaluations of the self-energy shapes on the imaginary axis may be sufficient for solving many realistic total energy problems. They also stress the need for a numerically stable algorithm that smoothly connects various regions of the parameter space.

1. The study of nonequilibrium phase transitions in complex systems is a growing area of interest, with applications in areas such as contact process, domain growth, catalysis, phase separation, and transport phenomena. While there is no general theory for these systems, progress has been made through approximate analytical methods and simulations.

1. The paper discusses the hydrodynamic limit for interacting particle systems in the crystal lattice, extending the study of the hydrodynamic limit to spaces with geometric structures beyond the Euclidean lattice.
2. The crystal lattice is a generalization of classical lattices, such as square, triangular, hexagonal, kagom, and diamond lattices, and has both global periodic structures and inhomogeneous local structures.
3. Crystal lattices have been studied in the context of discrete geometric analysis, with formulations as abelian covering graphs and discussions of random walks and their relationship with geometric structures.
4. The paper introduces the standard realization, a discrete harmonic map from a crystal lattice into a Euclidean space, to characterize equilibrium configurations of crystals.
5. The relationship between the Albanese metric, introduced in the Euclidean space and associated with the standard realization, and the central limit theorem for random walks on the crystal lattice is discussed.
6. The exclusion process on the crystal lattice is considered, with interactions depending on local structures. The problem of the hydrodynamic limit is to capture the collective behavior of particles via the scaling limit.
7. A crystal lattice is defined as an infinite graph with a free action of a free abelian group with a finite quotient graph. A scaling limit of a crystal lattice is constructed by taking a quotient of the lattice by a finite index subgroup of the free abelian group.
8. The symmetric simple exclusion process and its perturbation, the weakly asymmetric simple exclusion process, are dealt with in the paper. The latter case results in a heat equation with nonlinear drift terms on the torus as the limit of the process of empirical density.
9. The proof of the local ergodic theorem, which is the key step in the proof of the hydrodynamic limit, is based on the one-block estimate and the two-blocks estimate, and is modified for crystal lattices using the notion of periodic local function bundles and two types of local averages.

• The study of harmonic maps has its roots in the work of Fuller, Nash, and Sampson, with the first general result on existence due to Eells and Sampson.
• Harmonic maps are extrema of the energy functional and are characterized by the vanishing of the trace of their second fundamental form.
• The tension field of a harmonic map is a measure of its deviation from being harmonic and is defined as the trace of its Hessian.
• An almost para-hermitian manifold is a smooth manifold endowed with an almost para-complex structure and a pseudo-Riemannian metric compatible with it.
• A para-Kähler manifold is an almost para-hermitian manifold with closed fundamental 2-form.
• An almost paracontact manifold is a smooth manifold with an almost paracontact structure, which is a special kind of almost product structure.
• An almost paracontact metric structure is a paracontact structure with a metric that is metrically dual to the structure vector field.
• A paracontact metric manifold is an almost paracontact metric manifold that satisfies certain additional conditions.

1. Star formation rate (SFR) in galaxies is crucial for understanding the hierarchical build-up of the universe over time.
2. Unregulated star formation can lead to an overabundance of high mass galaxies, suggesting that some process must stop star formation before a galaxy grows too big.
3. Supermassive black holes (SMBHs) in galaxy centers are the likely culprits, growing through accretion of cold material and releasing energy that can heat or remove interstellar medium (ISM) gas.
4. Indirect evidence of AGN feedback includes scaling relationships between SMBH mass and host galaxy properties, suggesting a strong coevolution of the host galaxy and SMBH.
5. Dust in the ISM plays a key role in galaxy physics, contributing little to overall mass but significantly to the radiative output, mainly in the infrared (IR) regime.
6. Dust efficiently absorbs optical and UV emission and re-radiates it in the mid- and far-IR, depending on temperature and grain size.
7. Measuring the total IR light from dust provides insights into the current SFR, although for passive galaxies, IR emission can overestimate the SFR due to dust heating by older stellar populations.
8. Dust also obscures our view of AGN, with dust heated by AGN thought to primarily live in a toroidal structure that absorbs AGN radiative output.
9. The AGN dusty torus is used to explain the dichotomy of AGN into Seyfert 1 and Seyfert 2 within a unified model.
10. Far-IR (FIR) and submillimeter data are important for estimating the SFR of AGN host galaxies, and recent studies have shown the power of long wavelength Herschel data to better constrain the SFR, dust mass, and dust temperature in AGN host galaxies.

- Myles Hollander, a statistician, recounts his experiences and influences throughout his career.
* He was introduced to statistics at Carnegie Mellon University, where he switched from metallurgy to math and was influenced by professors Morrie Degroot and Ed Olds.
* At Stanford, he was part of a talented cohort of students and was particularly influenced by professor Lincoln Ellsworth Moses.
* He met his wife Glee at Stanford and they have two sons and five grandchildren.
* He published a major portion of his thesis in a pair of Annals papers, focusing on rank tests for ordered alternatives in the two-way layout.
* He has written on classical nonparametric testing problems, including bivariate symmetry, regression, uncorrelated nonparametric statistics, and ordered alternatives.
* He and his doctoral student, Ramesh Korwar, were the first to develop inference procedures for the hyperparameter of Ferguson's Dirichlet process.
* He has been at Florida State for 42 years and has had extensive and fruitful collaborations with colleagues there.
* He is known for his work in nonparametric statistics and has received the Noether Senior Scholar Award for his contributions to the field.

1. The fundamental group of the complement of plane curves is a topological invariant that can be used to distinguish between connected components of the moduli space of smooth projective surfaces, compute the fundamental groups of complements of hypersurfaces, and find more examples of Zariski pairs. A pair of plane curves is a Zariski pair if they have the same combinatorics but their complements are not homeomorphic.
2. Fan proved results concerning the projective fundamental group of complex line arrangements, including that if the first Betti number of the graph of multiple points is zero, then the projective fundamental group is a free group. Fan conjectured that the inverse implication is also correct, and this conjecture was recently proved. A conjugation-free geometric presentation of a fundamental group is one with a presentation that has no conjugations in the relations.
3. The paper discusses the problem of determining which line arrangements have a fundamental group with a conjugation-free geometric presentation and presents results for real arrangements with a unique cycle of length 3 and a unique cycle of any length with no line with more than two multiple points. The paper also shows that arrangements with a unique cycle and no line with more than two multiple points have a conjugation-free geometric presentation.

1. The text discusses the use of flavor symmetry to generate mass and mixing patterns of fermions, specifically continuous symmetries like U(1) and discrete symmetries like exchange symmetry.
2. The authors of [e-print] introduced a new symmetry, Z4, to avoid mass degeneracy under U(1) symmetry. This symmetry has been extensively studied and used to fit the tri-bi maximal mixing pattern in the leptonic sector.
3. In the work of Altarelli and Feruglio, the leptonic mixing arises solely from the neutrino sector, leading to hierarchical masses of charged leptons and quasi-degenerate or hierarchical neutrino masses.

• Organic molecular crystals, composed of organic molecules held together by weak van der Waals forces, are promising for fabricating nanoscale devices in electronics and optoelectronics, including solar energy harvesting, surface photochemistry, organic electronics, and spintronics.
• These devices typically consist of both organic and inorganic components, with the organic part being the active component and the inorganic part providing electrical contact to external circuitry.
• The interface electronic structure between the organic and inorganic components plays a crucial role in determining the final device performance, particularly in charge transfer and the energies at which the transfer occurs.
• Upon adsorption on a substrate, a molecule's electron addition and removal energies change due to image charge accumulation on the substrate, affecting the addition or removal energy of charge carriers from the molecule.
• A quasiparticle (qp) description is often used to calculate addition and removal energies, associating electron affinity and ionization potential with the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) and highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) of a molecule, respectively.
• The adequacy of the qp description depends on the level of theory used to calculate energy levels, with density functional theory (DFT) being a common choice. However, DFT has limitations, especially for molecules, and hybrid functionals or self-interaction corrected functionals may be needed for accurate results.
• The energy levels alignment of a molecule in the proximity of a metal presents additional problems, as the formation of the image charge is a non-local phenomenon not easily captured by most functionals.
• Constrained density functional theory (CDFT) can be used to evaluate charge transfer energies of an organic molecule physisorbed on an inorganic substrate more efficiently than qp calculations.
• CDFT avoids qp spectrum calculation by replacing it with total energy calculations for different charge distributions, and it is computationally no more demanding than a standard DFT calculation.
• The paper uses CDFT to study the adsorption of molecules on a 2D metal, specifically graphene, which has technological relevance and has been used as a template layer for the growth of organic crystals.

1. The interaction between many particles is described by determining their pair potential or the forces between a single pair.
2. If the governing physical equations are linear, this approach yields a quantitatively reliable description of the system based on the linear superposition principle.
3. Nonlinearities give rise to many-body effects, which can lead to changes in the force acting on a particle and the appearance of stable or unstable configurations.
4. Many-body effects appear in various systems, including nuclear matter, superconductivity, colloidal suspensions, quantum-electrodynamic Casimir forces, polymers, nematic colloids, and noble gases.
5. Integrating out small scales generates effective interactions among the large particles, which are not pairwise additive.
6. Large particles of the system may exhibit collective behavior, which can be described more easily if it is governed by pair potentials.
7. The paper assesses the influence of many-body effects on critical Casimir forces (CCFs) between a single colloidal particle and a container wall and between two isolated colloidal particles.
8. A theoretical scheme is used to compute the forces between individual pairs and three-body forces on the same footing.
9. Field-theoretic mean-field theory (MFT) is used to capture the universal scaling functions as the leading contribution to their systematic expansion in terms of spatial dimensions.
10. The standard Landau-Ginzburg-Wilson Hamiltonian for critical phenomena of the Ising bulk universality class is used, with suitable boundary conditions.

1. * The text discusses the role of molecular hydrogen (H2) in the interstellar medium (ISM) and its formation on dust grains, which are mainly carbonaceous or silicate particles with various sizes. Small grains or polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) make up a large part of the available surface area for chemistry in the ISM and have characteristics similar to graphite surfaces. Hydrogenation on the PAH edges is an important route to form H2 in the ISM.

The results show that odd hydrogenation states of coronene cations predominantly populate the mass spectrum, indicating that the further hydrogenation of pah cations is associated with a barrier if the number of already attached hydrogen atoms is odd, and no barrier if this number is even. This suggests that pah cations can also enjoy highly hydrogenated states in the ISM and act as catalysts for H2 formation.
