• The invention relates to a heat-dissipating device and a housing thereof, specifically an axial fan with an increased intake airflow rate and a housing that enhances heat-dissipating performance.
• Conventional fans have restrictions in the dimension of the rectangular fan housing, limiting the air passage and blade design, and only achieving limited improvement in increasing intake airflow rate.
• The invention's objective is to provide a heat-dissipating fan and housing that enlarges the intake airflow area without modifying assembling conditions, enhancing heat-dissipating efficiency, and allowing for easy mounting to systems or heat dissipation elements.
• The housing includes an outer frame with a passage for air streams, having a sidewall that extends radially outwards to enlarge the intake or discharge area for air streams.
• The sidewall of the passage may extend in various manners, including symmetrical, frustum-conical, or frustum-elliptically conical, and can be formed with an inclined portion or beveled edge.
• The housing can also include a notch to enlarge the intake area for lateral side air streams.
• The heat-dissipating device includes an impeller and housing, with the housing having a passage for guiding air streams and a sidewall that extends radially outwards to enlarge the intake/discharge area for air streams.
• The dimension of the blade of the impeller increases along with the radially outwardly extending direction of the sidewall of the passage.
• The heat-dissipating system includes a casing, electrical elements, and a heat-dissipating device mounted on the casing for dissipating heat generated from the electrical elements.
• The heat-dissipating device can be an axial fan, and may include a heat sink assembled with the housing for better heat dissipation.

- The invention describes an electroluminescent display panel that can display different colors according to situations without using an intermediate electrode, making it simpler and more cost-effective. The panel can display images in a color with no visible red components or in a color with visible red components with a high luminance.
- The panel is composed of various layers laminated on a glass substrate, including first and second electrode layers, first and second insulation layers, and first and second luminescent layers. The first luminescent layer emits light with no visible red light components, while the second luminescent layer, which overlaps the first luminescent layer, emits light with visible red light components. The second luminescent layer can be eliminated and replaced with a color filter, such as a red color filter, to achieve similar results.

• The source document describes a communications terminal for Internet/network telephony, which uses a network and/or the Internet for transferring information/data representing digitized speech, sounds, music, etc. The terminal increases flexibility with respect to wireless communication/connection with a network and/or the Internet, and does not require specialized equipment and functionality to provide a connection to a network and/or the Internet.
• The terminal comprises audio means, converting means, protocol means, and wireless communications means. The audio means reproduce sound on the basis of a first electrical signal and record sound resulting in a second electrical signal. The converting means convert the second electrical signal into transmission data and convert received data into the first electrical signal. The protocol means handle and control communication of the received and transmission data in accordance with a standardized Internet/network protocol. The wireless communications means communicate the received and/or transmission data in a wireless data format with a connecting unit adapted to establish a connection to a network and/or the Internet.

* High-dielectric oxide materials, such as ferroelectric materials, offer advantages in semiconductor circuitry, but integrating non-SiO2 based oxides directly on Si is difficult due to the strong reactivity of Si with oxygen.
* Deposition of non-SiO2 oxides typically results in the formation of a SiO2 or silicate layer at the Si/oxide interface, which has a low dielectric constant and degrades the usefulness of non-SiO2 based oxides with Si.
* Ferroelectrics with a large dielectric constant can be used to form high density capacitors, but they cannot be deposited directly on Si due to the reaction of Si to form a low dielectric constant layer.
* Putting the high dielectric material on a conductive layer has not solved the problem, as the prior art materials generally either form a silicide or react with silicon or the high dielectric oxide to form low dielectric constant insulators.
* A Ge buffer layer on Si oxidizes much less readily and can be used to prevent or minimize the formation of the low dielectric constant layer. An epitaxial Ge layer on Si provides a good buffer layer which is compatible with Si and also many oxides.
* The epitaxial growth of Ge on top of the ferroelectric or high-dielectric constant oxide is also much easier than Si which makes it possible to form three dimensional epitaxial structures.
* The Ge buffer layer can be epitaxially grown on the Si substrate allowing the high dielectric constant oxide to be epitaxially grown on the Ge and hence epitaxially aligned to the Si substrate.
* The epitaxial Ge layer allows ferroelectrics to be directly gown on Si wafers to form non-volatile non-destructive read out memory cells.
* A Ge buffer layer on the Si or GaAs substrate allows many more oxides to be epitaxially grown on it because of the much smaller chemical reactivity of Ge with oxygen compared to Si or GaAs with oxygen.
* However, not all oxides are stable next to Ge. For example, all ferroelectrics containing Pb such as Pb(Ti,Zr)O3 (PZT) are not thermodynamically

- The invention describes a receiver input circuit that reduces unwanted signal actuation of non-linear components, which can cause distortions. This is achieved by using several amplification control circuits, each with a different response threshold and frequency bandwidth. The first control circuit helps avoid unwanted overloading of the mixer stage and varactor diodes, while the second control circuit avoids overloading of the mixer stage and frequency influences. The third control circuit supports the other control circuits or lowers the amplification of the circuit for better protection from stronger spurious signals.
- The input circuit includes an input network with reactance elements, a PIN diode for controllable signal attenuation, a preamplifier stage, a mixer and oscillator stage, an intermediate frequency filter, rectifier circuits, and a control signal processing circuit. The control circuit is based on a PIN diode, which has the advantage of protecting all distortion-forming circuit components against signal overloading during control and protecting the following amplifier component against high-voltage discharge surges from the antenna. The rectifier circuits are arranged in such a way that the signal distortions do not affect the input circuit. The control signal is leveled by the capacitor in such a manner that the capacitor quickly charges itself up to the amount corresponding to the highest value of the signal level and follows the decreasing signal level relatively slowly. This enables greater elimination of interference through the control circuit if powerful amplitude-modulated spurious signals are present and there is danger of overloading due to peak amplitudes.

• The invention is a system for initiating a collaborative work-share environment between two or more parties to a telephone call, without complex and time-consuming setup processes.
• Each party to a telephone call is provided with a collaboration button and an indicator on their telephone set. When the indicator is illuminated, the system is capable of establishing a work-share environment.
• The system causes network enabled applications to run on the individual users' desktop computers so that the parties are able to share information between themselves, conduct a video conference, etc., while maintaining their initial voice connection.
• The telephone is used in the usual way to make regular, voice-only, telephone calls. Once a call is established, the telephones communicate with each other to determine if they each are associated with equipment which would allow richer collaboration between their respective users.
• If such equipment is available then the indicator on at least one of the telephones is lit, indicating that richer collaboration is possible. If the talking parties decide that they would like to share a document or set up a video conference, this may be initiated by either party pushing the collaboration button.
• The collaboration control program runs on each PC associated with a telephone. This program has the capability of communicating over the LAN with the phone to control the collaborate indicator and sense actuation of the collaborate button.
• The collaboration control program includes a list of all collaboration application programs installed which have been registered with the collaboration control program on the PC, including information about their capabilities and communication protocols.
• The system can be implemented in a peer-to-peer architecture, and can be applied to multiparty collaboration. The system can be implemented by remote computers connected over a network, and the telephone equipment can be integrated within the computer. The invention encompasses a computer program and any form of carrier medium which can carry the computer program.

- The invention describes a method and device for optimizing the visual impact of an advertising clip inserted into a video sequence. It does this by accounting for the regions of interest of the video sequence and the advertising clip, so that there is a continuity between the regions of interest of the pictures of the video sequence and the regions of interest of the advertising clip. This is achieved by generating salience maps for the video sequence and each advertising clip, determining the degree of similarity between them, and selecting the advertising clip with the highest degree of similarity for insertion into the video sequence at a predefined insertion point.
- The insertion point is preferably a point of the video sequence corresponding to a shot change, and the salience map of the video sequence is generated from the salience maps of the last n pictures of the video sequence that precede the insertion point. The salience map of the advertising clip is generated from the salience maps of the first p pictures of the advertising clip. The degree of similarity of an advertising clip is determined by calculating the correlation coefficient between the salience map of the video sequence and the salience map of the advertising clip, or by calculating the Kullback-Leibler divergence between the two salience maps. Alternatively, the degree of similarity can be determined by selecting the N most salient points of the salience map of the video picture and the salience map of the advertising clip, determining the Euclidean distance between each point and its corresponding point of the same order in the other salience map, and calculating the average of the N Euclidean distances. The advertising clip selected is the one providing the best continuity in terms of salience between the video sequence and the advertising clip.

• The invention describes a recessed mask structure to prevent localized high electrical fields at intersections in small dimension semiconductor devices, which can result in lower electrical breakdown.
• The problem of high electrical fields is inherent in dry etching processes, and is caused by pointed regions at the intersection of conductive members. A mask layer is used to protect the dielectric during operations at the surface, but the pointed regions result in smaller line spacing, higher electric fields, and a greater propensity for electrical shorting between adjacent lines.
• The invention arranges the interface between the mask and cap to be placed at a location away from the high electric field points, where the conductive liner diffusion barrier has integrity. This is achieved by removing a portion of the mask layer and positioning the mask member so that the high field points are separated from the interface.
• The recessed mask structure provides benefits such as minimizing damage to the conductive liner, reducing the overall capacitance of the device, and providing faster signal propagation in the interconnect wiring.
• The invention can be integrated into a component with a lower and predictable overall capacitance, which is achieved by positioning the high k mask in an opening between conductors so that the overall capacitance decreases as more of the hard mask is recessed.
• The structure of the invention is made using a standard substrate, and involves depositing a bulk layer of intralevel dielectric material, etching via and trench openings, providing conductive diffusion barrier liners, and chemically-mechanically polishing the surface until the copper conductors are nearly coplanar with the mask surface.

<summary>
- The Downconverting Digitizer of this invention is a novel design implementation for an analog to digital converter that samples and downconverts a modulated (IF) carrier to baseband in-phase (I) and quadrature (Q) components. It consists of a digitally-controlled variable gain amplifier, a gain control logic element, an analog summing element, a sampling element, a predictive digital filter, an offset nuller element, a digital summing element, a digital to analog converter, a digital quadrature mixer, and two rate reduction filters.
- The Downconverting Digitizer operates on the principle of the predictive loop, which generates a prediction of the input signal and minimizes the prediction error signal. The sampler plays a critical role in this process, and the offset nulling loop is designed to eliminate offsets caused by implementation imperfections.
- The predictive filter element is implemented using digital signal processing techniques and is designed to generate a prediction of the modulated IF at the next sampling epoch. The filter coefficient determines the resonant frequency and 3-dB bandwidth of the filter stage.
- The dynamic frequency response adjustment feature of this invention can be used to dynamically adjust the coefficients of the predictive filter to track the instantaneous carrier frequency of the modulated IF or reduce distortion caused by interfering signals in a multi-channel receiver application.
</summary>

<summary>

* The invention relates to a method for fabricating arrays of nano-scale features on a single wafer to form a sensor device or a matrix of devices for multiplex detection of selected analytes.
* The method uses nanoimprint lithography to define groups of semiconducting nanotraces between electrodes, which can be used as a sensor or for multiplex detection of analytes when anchored probe molecules are covalently coupled or synthesized to the surfaces.
* Nanoimprint lithography also provides a method to fabricate arrays of semiconducting electrode "nanotraces" in a controllable and regular pattern in a single processing step.
* A method that provides controlled fabrication of nanophase features provides a means for detection of gases adsorbed on the semiconductor surfaces or multiplex detection of many simultaneous detection zones.
* Binding of complementary targets to the anchored probe molecules in the vicinity of the semiconducting active layer produces a change in electrical conductivity of the semiconducting active layer that can be monitored externally for each sensor device in the array in parallel.
* The method involves patterning the base electrode structures using standard lithography, depositing a semiconducting active layer over the entire wafer, and patterning the semiconducting active layer into a set of parallel nanotraces over the interdigitated finger region of the source and drain electrodes using nanoimprint lithography.
* The nanotraces provide a narrow electrical bridge between source and drain electrodes, and the response is proportional to the degree in which the electrical current traversing the set of semiconductor nanotraces is influenced by changes in the electric field strength near the surface.
* The fabrication of a set of parallel nanotraces serves to homogenize the total response to changes in local environment since the total response is the average of the response of each nanotrace connected in parallel between the interdigitated finger region of the source and drain electrodes.
</summary>

<summary>

* The present invention relates to a method of singulating and plating semiconductor packages to prevent contamination of lead surfaces.
* The method includes providing a plurality of semiconductor dies coupled to a single common leadframe, encasing them in a molding compound, singulating the dies and plating the exposed side surfaces of the leads with a plating material.
* The plating material is a different material than the leads and can be tin, silver, gold, nickel-gold, nickel-palladium, or nickel-palladium-gold.
* The leadframe may have a top and bottom surface, and the singulation can be performed in a single cutting operation or in multiple partial cuts with plating in between.
* The semiconductor dies can be attached to the bottom surface of the leadframe and the top surface can be plated before or after singulation.
* The singulated semiconductor package comprises a leadframe with a die attach pad and a plurality of leads, a semiconductor die coupled to the die attach pad, and a molding compound at least partially encasing the leadframe and the semiconductor die, with side surfaces of the leads exposed and plated with a plating material.
</summary>

<summary>
- The invention describes a method and system for a mobile terminal to switch between a wireless wide area network (WWAN) and a wireless local area network (WLAN) for voice/data communication.
- The WLAN contains a second base station that gathers service information about neighboring WWAN base stations and broadcasts it to the mobile terminal.
- When the mobile terminal connects to the WLAN, it receives the service information and uses it to accelerate the connection process when switching to the WWAN.
- The mobile terminal contains a first network module for connecting to the WWAN and a second network module for connecting to the WLAN. The first network module can skip some initial scanning procedures when connecting to the WWAN by using the service information received from the WLAN.
</summary>

* The invention relates to a method and system for a mobile terminal to selectively connect to a wireless wide area network (WWAN) or a wireless local area network (WLAN) for voice/data communication.
* The WLAN contains a second base station that gathers service information about neighboring WWAN base stations and broadcasts it to the mobile terminal.
* When the mobile terminal connects to the WLAN, it receives the service information and uses it to accelerate the connection process when switching to the WWAN.
* The mobile terminal contains a first network module for connecting to the WWAN and a second network module for connecting to the WLAN. The first network module can skip some initial scanning procedures when connecting to the WWAN by using the service information received from the WLAN.

• The invention describes a process for manufacturing multilayered components, such as capacitors and coils, by stacking laminates with conductive and non-conductive materials.
• The process simplifies the manufacturing process by eliminating certain steps, reducing labor and capital investment, and enabling in-process inspection.
• The new system allows for smaller parts, lower voltage ratings, no shape limitations, and the elimination of cutting stress cracks and internal delamination.
• The end terminations of electrodes enable various tab configurations with no extra process time, and inventory can be carried in decal form for rapid response to customers.
• The invention can also be applied to other electronic ceramic devices, such as multilayer ferrite inductors, semiconductor packages, and precision registers.
• The method of producing an electrical coil includes forming multiple laminates with coil patterns and stacking them to form a coil structure, obviating the need for laborious winding of coils.

1. The invention is related to cellular materials with multiplicity of cell sizes used in structural applications, specifically hierarchical cellular lattices and related methods of using and manufacturing.
2. Sandwich panels are a common application of these materials, used in various fields such as transportation, ballistics, thermal transfer, multifunctional structures, armors, load bearing, construction materials, and containers.
3. The lattice structures typically use trusses of equal size, but the invention proposes a design with a network of hierarchical trusses, synergistically arranged, to provide support and other functionalities.
4. The resulting structure maintains a low weight while providing high specific stiffness and strength.
5. The structure may comprise a first lattice structure with a first primary array and an ancillary array, nested together, and a second lattice structure mated with the first primary array.
6. The ancillary array is nested with the first primary array, where the second order cells of the ancillary array are essentially coaligned with the second order cells of the first primary array, the first order cells of the first primary array, or both.
7. The second primary array of the second lattice structure is mated with the first primary array to form a third lattice structure, where at least one of the first order cells of the first primary array are oppositely oriented to and essentially coaligned with at least one of the first order cells of the second primary array.
8. The method of making the structure involves forming a first lattice structure by nesting an ancillary array with a first primary array, and providing a second lattice structure by mating a second primary array with the first primary array.
9. The structure can be used in various applications, including sea, land, and air transportation, ballistics, blast and impact impulse mitigation, thermal transfer, multifunctional structures, armors, load bearing, construction materials, and containers.
10. The invention was made with United States Government support under Grant No. N00014-07-1-0114, awarded by the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency/Office of Naval Research. The United States Government has certain rights in the invention.

- The invention describes a process for co-producing power and hydrocarbons using an Integrated Gasification Combined Cycle (IGCC) process and a hydrocarbon production process. The IGCC process uses coal as a feedstock and first gasifies it to produce synthesis gas, which then serves as fuel for a combined cycle power production stage. The synthesis gas is then converted to hydrocarbons. The invention aims to provide an IGCC process integrated with a hydrocarbon production process that shows economic and environmental benefits.
- The process includes a wet gasification stage that gasifies coal to produce a combustion gas at elevated pressure, enriching a portion of the combustion gas with hydrogen to produce an H2-enriched gas, generating power from another portion of the combustion gas, a dry gasification stage that gasifies coal to produce a synthesis gas precursor at elevated pressure, mixing the H2-enriched gas with the synthesis gas precursor to provide a synthesis gas for hydrocarbon synthesis, and synthesizing hydrocarbons from the synthesis gas. The combustion gas may be produced at a pressure of at least 45 bar, and the molar ratio of H2/CO in the combustion gas may be at least 0.6. The dry gasification stage should produce synthesis gas at a pressure which is sufficiently high to allow hydrocarbon synthesis at a suitably high pressure. The molar ratio of H2/CO in the synthesis gas precursor may be between about 0.3 and about 0.6. Enriching a first portion of the combustion gas with H2 may include subjecting said first portion to water gas shift conversion thereby to produce the H2-enriched gas. The process may include purifying a portion of the H2-enriched gas to produce essentially pure hydrogen, which may be used for hydroprocessing of hydrocarbons synthesized from the synthesis gas. The H2-enriched gas may be at elevated pressure, and mixing at least a portion of the H2-enriched gas with the synthesis gas precursor may include passing the H2-enriched gas through an expansion turbine to generate power. Generating power from a second portion of the combustion gas may include combusting the combustion gas

• The present invention relates to a method for preparing a solid device for use as an oxide superconducting material, which imparts an important improvement to the properties of the material at the surface or portion close to the surface.
• The method involves forming a blocking film (passivation film) over the spaces or micro-holes in the surface portion of the superconducting material to prevent the removal of oxygen, and controlling the amount of oxygen in the inside surfaces of the superconducting material to match the internal portion.
• The blocking film is formed using a photo CVD method, which is superior in stepped coverage, at a thickness of 10 Å to 2μm. Oxygen is then added onto the surface or portion close to the surface, and the entire body is heat-treated to position the added oxygen in the appropriate atom location.
• The films used for this purpose may be insulating films such as silicon nitride, aluminum nitride, oxidized aluminum, oxidized tantalum, oxidized titanium and the like. A metal or semiconductor which becomes an oxidized insulating film after oxidizing treatment can also be used.
• The method can be used to prepare a superconducting device which is kept superconductive at the surface or portion close to the surface of the oxide superconducting material, and can be used to form a Josephson element structure or as a passivation film.

* The invention describes an apparatus for preparing foam sheet samples for microscopic examination, which includes a base structure for stabilization, a clamping arrangement to grasp the foam sheet specimen, and a screw thread specimen advance mechanism to prepare repetitive samples with uniform thickness and parallel cut edges.
* The method provided by the invention allows for the precise cutting of foam test samples with at least two parallel sides, preserving the structure of individual cells for examination without distortion. This enables the comparison of foam materials' performance criteria, such as brittleness, flexibility, and insulative qualities, which may not be apparent in other physical tests.

• The invention is a method and apparatus for determining the angle of inclination of a seismometer, specifically ocean bottom seismometers (OBS), with respect to the vertical during operation and for leveling the seismic motion detectors.
• Knowing the angle of inclination helps evaluate the data gathered and the causes of any failure to obtain data, and assures good coupling of the seismic motion detector to the framework of the seismometer.
• The invention includes a method and apparatus for automatically leveling seismic motion detectors used in a seismometer, with self-leveling means for their seismic detectors.
• The seismic motion detectors, such as geophones, have a preferred operating axis (vertical or horizontal) and will sense the component of motion occurring along an axis parallel to its operating axis.
• The invention uses a novel device for leveling seismic motion detectors, which can more easily and inexpensively be used than either gimbals or a "boat" with a clamping device such as a spring loaded plunger.
• The invention also comprises a release mechanism for an on-bottom seismometer, as described in U.S. application Ser. No. 144,092, filed Apr. 28, 1980, Prior, "Release Mechanism for On-Bottom Seismometer".
• The seismic detector is mounted on the inside of the door of the instrument compartment, providing a rigid connection between the detector and the frame of the seismometer to provide a good acoustic path between the sea bottom and the detector.
• An acoustic command unit at the surface produces acoustic commands for the on-bottom seismometer, which are sensed by a hydrophone mounted on the seismometer and wired to the instrument compartment.
• The invention employs a geophone having a center of gravity and a vertical operating axis, connected by a collar to the end of a shaft protruding from a spherical ball, which rests in an annular seat provided in a mounting plate. The geophone, shaft, and spherical ball form a simple pendulum, with the center of gravity and the center of the spherical ball aligned when the geophone is allowed to hang freely at the end of the shaft.

<summary>
• The humidity sensing element of the present invention is a small, hollow cylinder made of 99.4% pure aluminum with a fine-machined and roller burnished bore. It consists of a first electrode formed by anodizing the aluminum, an anodized layer impregnated with nickel particles, the anodized layer sealed, and a second electrode formed by vacuum deposition of nickel onto the sealed anodized layer.
• The anodized layer is deposited with nickel particles using vacuum deposition bombardment by atoms of nickel, and the anodized layer is sealed by hydrolizing and sealing the anodized coating. A thin, water vapor pervious electrode is then formed over the nickel-impregnated sealed anodized layer.
• The sensor is mounted in a mounting bracket and electrical connection is made by machining the anodized layer from the underside of the flange for pressure contact with the mounting bracket which is at ground potential. The sensor forms its own protection for the humidity-sensitive portion in its bore, while the surrounding atmosphere may circulate freely through the bore for free exchange of atmospheric molecules with the dielectric layer.
</summary>

<summary>

* The invention relates to a motor assembly with a force transmission structure for a window lift system in a vehicle.
* The force transmission structure includes a drive plate with a Y-shaped mounting hole and a shaft with a Y-shaped toothed portion that fits into the mounting hole.
* The shaft is held captive within the mounting hole by a circlip located within a groove in the distal end of the toothed portion.
* The drive plate is made of a plastics material and has a coupling with buffer holes for reducing distortion during molding.
* The shaft is made of low alloy steel or other metal material and has a pinion for driving a gear of a window lift system.
* The gear train includes a worm driven by the motor, a worm gear meshed with the worm, and a damper attached to and rotatable with the worm gear.
* The drive plate is driven by the worm gear through the damper, and the protrusions on the drive plate engage with second slots of the damper.
* The Y-shaped toothed portion of the shaft extends through the inner ring of the worm gear to be fitted in the Y-shaped mounting hole of the drive plate.
* The equal forces exerted on the teeth of the toothed portion result in stable rotation of the shaft, reducing noise and vibration in the window lift system.

</summary>

1. The document describes a method and system for generating a mobile time reference for a portable transceiver in a wireless communication system. The system includes an antenna, a radio frequency subsystem with a high frequency oscillator and a low frequency oscillator, and a baseband subsystem with a free running counter. The free running counter provides a mobile time reference and can switch between using the high frequency oscillator and the low frequency oscillator to maintain the time reference.
2. The mobile time reference is used for signal detection, identification, and monitoring of multipath signals in 3G wireless communication systems. The system and method described aim to improve the efficiency and accuracy of these processes as transmission speeds increase.
3. The system includes a WCDMA modem with a free running counter that generates the mobile time reference, and a multipath monitor and multipath radio signal recovery circuit for processing received signals. The mobile time reference is provided to both the multipath monitor and the multipath radio signal recovery circuit for acquiring and recovering multipath signals.

<summary>
 
* The invention describes a helmet liner that can be custom-fitted to an individual's head.
* The liner is made up of multiple layers of elastic thermoplastic sheets with an array of pockets.
* The liner is fitted to the wearer's head by heating the sheets to a plastic state, placing the liner on the head, and allowing it to cool and harden.
* The open and unfilled pockets in the layers allow for deformation and conformity to the head's contours.
* The liner can be refitted to accommodate a changed head size.
* The liner is simple and inexpensive to manufacture and does not require trimming or drawstrings.
* The invention improves upon previous methods by simplifying the manufacturing process, increasing conformity to the head's contours, and eliminating the need for drawstrings.
</summary>

• The invention is a multiorifice wafer structure having a plurality of angularly disposed passages and a method for making the multiorifice structure. The structure is made by fusing concentric layers of solid rods interspaced with cylindrically shaped members, with each successive layer of rods disposed at a progressively larger angle with respect to the axis of the fused assembly. The fused assembly is then cut into thin wafers, forming a plurality of angularly disposed passageways in which angles of the passageways increase progressively as a function of their distance from the center of the structure.
• The structure comprises a plurality of layers of rods separated by cylindrical members, with the interstices between the individual rods and the cylindrical members forming a plurality of generally triangularly shaped passageways through the structure. The thickness of the structure is selected such that the fluid passing therethrough will, upon exiting the structure, have a directional component parallel to the axis of the interstices.
• A simple and economical method for fabricating the disclosed multiorifice structure is illustrated, which comprises circumscribing a core rod by a plurality of rods or wires, twisting the rods about the core at a predetermined angle, and sheathing the rods and core in a cylindrical member. A second layer of rods is twisted about the external surface of the cylindrical member and sheathed in a second cylindrical member, with the angle between the rods and core being different from the first layer. The process is repeated until the composite structure has the desired diameter, which is then fused or sintered to form an integral structure.

• The text describes a method of manufacturing a semiconductor device with an LDD (Lightly Doped Drain) structure, which aims to improve the controllability of the width of the oxide portion on the gate sidewall, enable the formation of an LDD structure by a low-temperature process, and prevent degradation of the transconductance and increase of resistances due to hot-carrier injection into the oxide portion on the gate sidewall.

• The method involves forming an insulating film on the gate electrode, substrate, and sidewall therebetween, followed by forming a conformal layer on the insulating film and anisotropically etching away the layer using RIE, except for a portion on the gate sidewall. The oxide film portion on the sidewall of the gate can be made of a high melting point metal or a silicide of such a metal. A conductive layer or polycrystalline semiconductor layer can also be formed after the insulating film on the gate electrode, which is then anisotropically etched away using RIE to form the portion on the gate sidewall. The method also features siliciding a desired portion of the gate electrode or the gate electrode and the source/drain region in fabricating the insulated gate field effect semiconductor device having the LDD structure.

• The present invention relates to an improved end-user interface for Internet-protocol (IP) telephone communication.
• The invention provides an enhanced radio telephone that can be connected to a PC and used as a significantly improved IP telephone, which can operate as either a conventional radio telephone or as an IP telephone.
• The enhanced radio telephone includes an internal speech coder implemented for low power consumption, allowing it to be used with a relatively low-performance PC for effective IP telephony.
• Coded and compressed digital speech signals are passed back and forth between the enhanced radio telephone and the PC, and the PC performs conversions between the coded speech signals and an appropriate computer network protocol.
• The invention also allows for wireless data communication in order to carry IP speech, with coded speech passed from the enhanced radio telephone to the PC where it is formatted according to an appropriate UDP/IP network protocol.
• The present invention provides an improved IP telephone which is more convenient, economical and efficient as compared to conventional IP telephony systems.

<summary>

* The invention is about devices for producing electrical power, pressurized water or other useful work from surface waves on a water body.
* The devices rely on overhead wave-induced subsurface differences in hydrostatic pressure and/or enhanced surge or pitch which expand and contract or otherwise deform or deflect one or more gas-filled submerged containers.
* The expansion and contraction is enhanced or supplemented by wave focusing, reflection or diffraction techniques and/or by overhead surface floating bodies.
* Wave energy commercialization lags behind wind energy despite the higher energy density of waves.
* Hundreds of unique OWECs have been proposed, but only a dozen are currently deployed as commercial prototypes, all suffering from high cost per unit of energy capture due to heavy steel construction and low wave energy capture efficiency.
* Most subsurface OWECs are designed for near-shore sea bed deployment, but waves lose substantial energy as they approach shore due to breaking or reflected wave and bottom and hydrodynamic friction effects.
* Near-shore submerged sea bed OWECs must be deployed at greater depths relative to average wave trough depths due to severe sea-state considerations and cannot be adjusted for tidal depth variations.
* Only a few prior art subsurface devices use gas-filled or evacuated containers, and none capture both hydrostatic (heave) and hydrokinetic wave energy, which represents half of all wave energy.
* None of the prior art subsurface OWECs enhance or supplement energy capture with overhead floating bodies.
* The present invention provides substantial advantages over the prior art, including reduced total and moving mass, increased responsiveness, delayed release of compression and expansion strokes, direct or indirect atmospheric venting, overhead surface floating buoys, no expensive and heavy ectoskeleton/cage, no flexible rolling membrane seal, increased stroke and energy capture, oblong horizontal planar section, adjustable depth mooring systems, and multi-staged or multiple sequenced drive cylinders.
</summary>

<summary>

- The invention relates to a scraped surface heat exchanger blade with locking tracks for mounting on a drive shaft using pins.
- The blade has a first side, a second side, a blade edge, a hinge edge, and mounting holes with L-shaped tracks on both sides.
- The pin has an inner finger, an outer finger, and a base mounted to the drive shaft, with the fingers aligned with the entry tracks of the blade's L-shaped tracks.
- The blade is inserted between the fingers of the pin, with the inner finger holding the blade at an angle and the outer finger sliding into the intermediate track.
- The blade is then moved longitudinally so that the inner fingers align with the mounting holes, and the intermediate slot extends past the hole to accommodate the width of the outer finger.
- The blade is rotated downward into an installation position, with the holes aligned with the inner fingers, and cannot travel downward due to interference on both sides.
- The entry track on the inner side of the blade is a different width than the entry track on the outer side, ensuring the correct side of the blade faces up.
- The locking tracks are provided on both sides of the blade, preserving structural rigidity and reducing wear over time.

</summary>

Note: The summary is a brief and general overview of the main points in the text, and it is not intended to replace or be a substitute for the full text.

- The invention describes a process and apparatus for detecting and eliminating defective or incorrectly positioned cigarettes in a cigarette magazine of a cigarette production and/or packaging machine.
* The detection process uses an optical checking element, such as a camera, to scan and evaluate images of cigarettes in the magazine.
* If a scanned image deviates from a reference image or reference value, an error signal is produced.
* The detection apparatus includes an optical checking element, an image-processing device, and means to produce an error signal.
* The elimination process involves detecting a defective or incorrectly positioned cigarette and actuating an ejecting unit to remove a plurality of cigarettes from the magazine.
* The elimination apparatus includes one or more ejecting units arranged in the region of the magazine, which can eject a plurality of cigarettes located in an ejecting zone assigned to the ejecting unit.

- The invention describes a fixing mechanism for a tool used in machining materials such as wood, plastics, and metal. The fixing mechanism includes a tool, a frame for the tool, and a tool holder in the frame of a machine tool. The tool-fixing mechanism can be used in various applications including cutting, punching, molding, and forming work, particularly in machining of metal sheets.
- The tool-fixing mechanism according to the invention improves upon prior art by using at least one curved surface as a connecting surface between the tool frame and tool holder. This allows for a simple and secure fixing mechanism where the tool and its frame can be placed in the tool holder with a simple movement and the contact surfaces transmit the machining force between the tool, the tool frame, and the tool holder.
- The fixing mechanism comprises a tool, a tool frame with a connecting element, a bushing-like tool holder, and clamps. The connecting element in the tool frame has a first connecting surface and a first contact surface, while the tool holder has a curvilinear connecting surface, such as a spherical surface, forming part of its outer surface. The tool frame is arranged to surround the second connecting surface in the end of the tool holder, with the first and second contact surfaces being against each other.
- The invention provides a formula for determining the radius of curvature of the curvilinear surface, which should be essentially equal to twice the distance between the center of the radius of curvature and the contact surface in the mounting direction. The diameter of the inlay of the connecting element should be substantially equal to twice the radius of curvature plus the fit used. The cross-sectional form of the tool holder and the connecting element in a direction perpendicular to the mounting direction should be a circular form.

• The text describes a continuation of a patent application related to switching circuitry for display drivers that operates at high speeds and produces low electromagnetic interference (EMI).
• Two common techniques for generating supply voltages to display driver circuits are charge pump circuits and switching regulator circuits. Charge pump circuits provide energy at high efficiency but low current, while switching regulator circuits supply high current but generate radiated energy as noise.
• The invention provides methods and apparatus for generating supply voltages for display driver circuits at very high efficiencies and low quantities of radiated energy by modifying switching regulator circuits to create multiple circuit paths that carry electric current in opposite directions to cancel out the radiated noise.
• The invention can produce relatively large amounts of current for driver circuits of relatively large displays, such as the Apple iPhone display, without incurring typical penalties associated with EMI or noise.
• The invention can reduce EMI by using terminal leads at the periphery edges of the circuit to pick up any leaking fields generated by the last fully-connected paths in the circuit.
• FIG. 1 shows a switching regulator circuit that can be implemented in accordance with the principles of the present invention, and FIG. 2 shows a control timing diagram that may be used to show the operation of the switching regulator.
• FIG. 4 illustrates various embodiments of the present invention, including a switching regulator that produces little to no electromagnetic interference by interleaving parallel source and drain paths to cancel out EMI generated in each path.

1. Vehicle battery rebalancing is a process that corrects cell voltage imbalance conditions by measuring the voltage of each cell, identifying the cell with the minimum voltage, and bleeding down the other cells until their voltages are approximately equal. This process is necessary to ensure that all cells in the battery have a similar state of charge and can provide the required power during operation.
2. The time taken to rebalance and charge a battery can be significant, with up to 50% of the time dedicated to rebalancing. Certain embodiments disclosed herein aim to reduce the time spent rebalancing and charging vehicle batteries by optimizing the charging process and balancing the cell voltages more efficiently.
3. The energy content of a battery cell can be approximated using the power applied to the cell over time, and the maximum capacity of a cell can be found by determining the change in capacity and state of charge. The voltage needed to provide a specified energy content can be calculated based on the minimum and maximum voltage of the cell, and the state of charge. This information can be used to optimize the charging process and ensure that all cells in the battery have a similar state of charge and can provide the required power during operation.

• The invention is an AC-to-DC converter used as a lamp power supply that converts an AC input voltage to a constant DC voltage at a predetermined value set by a potentiometer, reducing eye fatigue and protecting eyesight and health by eliminating low and high frequency flicker and electromagnetic radiation.
• The converter includes an input power supply, input protection circuit, EMI filter, rectifier, filter, converter, output filter, lamp, start circuit, control circuit, biasing circuit, sampling circuit, output protection circuit, feedback and dimming circuit, and input monitor circuit.
• The position or connection way of the circuit blocks can be changed, and some blocks can be removed, added, or integrated into one circuit. The input voltage source is usually low frequency AC voltage, and the output voltage is regulated at a constant value by the control circuit. The invention can be used in various applications, such as a bus AC to DC converter, PFC converter, computer power supply, TV power supply, and electronic ballast.

<summary>
• The present invention is a system for controlling the illumination levels in a space using both daylight and artificial lighting, while also reducing sun glare. The system includes a central processor, a dimming panel with various lighting loads, photosensor interfaces, photosensors, wall stations, a window treatment controller, and a computer for programming and monitoring.
• The system uses a closed loop algorithm to control the electric lights and a separate algorithm to control the motorized window treatments. The algorithms are based on the readings of photosensors, which are preferably mounted at approximately two window heights away from the windows and directed towards the window for daylight sensing.
• The system allows for the creation and recall of custom preset scenes for common room activities, and includes an astronomical time clock for scheduling events based on sunrise and sunset times. The motorized window treatments can be programmed to preset window treatment levels, and the system includes a photosensor interface for selection of preset lighting scenes and setting window treatment levels in response to available daylight or electric light.
</summary>

The source document is a description of a system for controlling the illumination levels in a space using both daylight and artificial lighting, while also reducing sun glare. The system includes a central processor, a dimming panel with various lighting loads, photosensor interfaces, photosensors, wall stations, a window treatment controller, and a computer for programming and monitoring. The system uses a closed loop algorithm to control the electric lights and a separate algorithm to control the motorized window treatments. The algorithms are based on the readings of photosensors, which are preferably mounted at approximately two window heights away from the windows and directed towards the window for daylight sensing. The system allows for the creation and recall of custom preset scenes for common room activities, and includes an astronomical time clock for scheduling events based on sunrise and sunset times. The motorized window treatments can be programmed to preset window treatment levels, and the system includes a photosensor interface for selection of preset lighting scenes and setting window treatment levels in response to available daylight or electric light.

<summary>

* The document discusses the vulnerabilities in aviation security before September 11, 2001, including weaknesses in passenger and baggage screening, access control, and air traffic control computer systems.
* The Aviation and Transportation Security Act (ATSA) was enacted in response to the 9/11 attacks, creating the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) and establishing security requirements for the agency.
* TSA has taken steps to improve aviation security, including deploying federal screeners, implementing explosives detection systems, and expanding the Federal Air Marshal Service. However, vulnerabilities remain, particularly in air cargo, general aviation, and airport perimeter security.
* The document also discusses TSA's efforts to develop a risk management approach, improve general aviation security, and address potential vulnerabilities through legislative proposals.
</summary>

1. <summary>The Lobbying Disclosure Act (LDA) of 1995 and the Internal Revenue Code (IRC) have different definitions of lobbying activities and covered officials, with LDA focusing on federal officials and the IRC definitions covering state and local officials as well. The LDA definition does not cover grassroots lobbying, while the IRC definitions do. The choice of definition used by an organization can significantly affect whether they must register with the Secretary of the Senate and the Clerk of the House of Representatives and what information they must disclose on their semiannual lobbying reports.</summary>
2. <summary>The LDA definition of lobbying covers contacts with all Members of Congress and employees of Congress and approximately 4,600 executive branch officials for either legislative or nonlegislative subjects. In contrast, the IRC definitions cover fewer executive branch officials for nonlegislative matters and potentially more for legislative matters. LDA contains 19 exceptions to the definition of lobbying, while the IRC section 162(e) definition has one exception and IRC section 4911 has five exceptions, two of which could allow a significant amount of lobbying expenses to be excluded from coverage.</summary>
3. <summary>The differences in definitions can result in organizations reporting different expenses and related information, which may not be comparable or relevant to LDA's purpose of publicly disclosing the efforts of lobbyists to influence federal officials' decision-making. Harmonizing the definitions would ensure that organizations would not have to keep track of their lobbying expenses and activities under two different definitions, but would require revisiting fundamental decisions made when each definition was enacted.</summary>

<summary>

• GAO has been assessing strategic sourcing in federal acquisitions for over a decade.
• Strategic sourcing involves a shift from numerous individual procurements to an enterprise-wide approach, leading to substantial savings through leveraged buying and other tactics.
• Federal departments and agencies are not fully leveraging their buying power, acting more like unrelated businesses and relying on hundreds of separate contracts for commonly used items.
• OMB implemented strategic sourcing practices in 2005, directing agencies to develop and implement strategic sourcing efforts based on spend analysis results.
• The Federal Strategic Sourcing Initiative (FSSI) was established in 2005 to address government-wide opportunities to strategically source commonly purchased products and services.
• Most agencies leveraged only a fraction of their buying power through strategic sourcing in 2011, with the DOD, DHS, DOE, and VA accounting for 80% of federal procurement spending but managing only 5% of it through strategic sourcing.
• FSSI managed a small amount of spending through its initiatives in 2011, achieving significant savings, but most agencies' efforts did not address their highest spending areas, such as services.
• Realizing cost savings and benefits from strategic sourcing contracts depends on utilization, but only 15% of government-wide spending for covered products and services went through FSSI contracts in 2011.
• Challenges to strategic sourcing in the federal setting include obtaining and analyzing reliable data, securing expertise, leadership support, and developing metrics.
• Agencies face disincentives for strategic sourcing, such as maintaining control over contracting activities, unique requirements, and the perception that strategically sourced contract vehicles may limit customization.

</summary>

• Current federal surface transportation programs are not effective at addressing key challenges, such as increasing congestion and growing freight demand, due to unclear goals and lack of links to needs or performance. Many programs lack rigorous economic analysis for project selection and have insufficient mechanisms to link programs to goals.

• The Highway Trust Fund, which finances most surface transportation programs, is facing fiscal sustainability issues as expenditures exceed revenues. The federal role in transportation funding must be reexamined to ensure sustainability in the context of broader fiscal challenges. A sustainable surface transportation program will require targeted investment from not only the federal government but also state and local governments and the private sector.

4. <summary> The current excise tax system has been successful in funding FAA, but concerns exist regarding revenue adequacy, equity, and efficiency. Trends in fares and average plane size suggest that revenue collected under the current system has fallen and will continue to fall relative to FAA's workload and costs. 6. <summary> FAA has made progress in designing a cost accounting system to determine costs by user group, which would be necessary to assess the extent to which the current approach or any other approach aligns costs with revenues.
7. <summary> Alternative funding options for FAA include relying solely on a fuel tax, increasing the passenger segment tax, weight/distance charges, en-route charges, flight segment charges, and certification charges, each with advantages and disadvantages.

* The Institute of Medicine published a report in 1993 that discussed secret U.S. chemical weapons programs during World War II, which included the use of military personnel as human experimental subjects in tests of exposure to mustard agents and lewisite.
* The Department of Defense (DOD) and the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) have taken actions to identify and notify individuals who were potentially exposed to chemical or biological substances during DOD tests, but have faced challenges in doing so, including inconsistent transmission of information between the two agencies, limited resources, and lost or destroyed records.
* DOD has not taken any actions to notify civilians who have been identified as having been potentially exposed during Project 112 tests and other chemical and biological tests, due in part to a lack of specific guidance defining the requirements to notify civilians.
* The Government Accountability Office (GAO) has recommended that Congress consider requiring the Secretary of Defense to conduct a cost-benefit analysis and provide guidance for notifying civilians who have been potentially exposed to chemical or biological substances as a result of DOD tests.

The report found that an estimated 60,000 military personnel participated in these tests and that unknown numbers of additional servicemembers may have been exposed to these substances through their participation in the production, transportation, and/or storage of these chemical substances.

1. <summary>The National Criminal History Improvement Program (NCHIP) is a federal grant program managed by the Department of Justice's Bureau of Justice Statistics (BJS) to build a national infrastructure to facilitate the interstate exchange of criminal history and other relevant records. NCHIP grants have been used for various criminal history record improvement projects, including NICS-related purposes, automating criminal history records, and making them accessible nationally.</summary>
2. <summary>States have made progress in automating criminal history records and making them accessible nationally using NCHIP grants and other funding sources. However, more work remains, particularly for NICS-related purposes such as automated information on the disposition of felony and other potentially disqualifying arrests and identifying other prohibited purchasers of firearms.</summary>
3. <summary>The demand for background checks is growing, driven by screening requirements for employment and other noncriminal justice purposes. Technology is not static, and long-term funding is needed to replace outdated equipment and automate records.</summary>
4. <summary>The availability and access to arrest disposition information necessary for timely presale background checks of persons purchasing firearms continues to be problematic, particularly for preventing or minimizing the sale of firearms by "default proceed" to prohibited persons.</summary>
5. <summary>Additional opportunities for further progress in automating records and enhancing national systems include improving the availability of records regarding persons who have been adjudicated as mentally defective and persons who are unlawful users of controlled substances.</summary>

<summary>

- The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) established the Superfund program in 1980 to clean up the nation's most hazardous waste sites.
- EPA investigates contaminated areas and places the most highly contaminated sites on the National Priorities List (NPL) for study and cleanup, with 1,210 sites on the NPL as of December 1996.
- EPA selects incineration as a Superfund cleanup remedy in about 6% of decisions, with three incinerators operating at Superfund sites and four more planned as of October 1996.
- Incineration involves four basic steps: preparing and feeding wastes into the incinerator, burning the wastes, collecting and cooling the ash, and filtering and releasing the gases.
- Incinerators at Superfund sites are generally "transportable" and are constructed and operated by contractors, with CERCLA exempting any portion of a cleanup action conducted entirely on-site from the need to obtain a permit.
- EPA requires incinerators at Superfund sites to meet RCRA's substantive requirements, such as the act's standards for emissions, and relies on four principal methods to ensure safe operation.
- EPA establishes specific cleanup standards for each incinerator used at a Superfund site, based on studies of the site's characteristics and typically adopting RCRA's standards for fixed facility hazardous waste incinerators.
- EPA requires engineering controls to prevent standards from being exceeded and has built-in safety features unique to each model to prevent excessive emissions of contaminants in the event of an emergency shutdown.
- RCRA's regulations require that incinerators have devices that will stop contaminated waste from being fed into an incinerator when the operating conditions deviate from the required operating parameters.

</summary>

• The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) did not maintain effective internal control over financial reporting as of September 30, 2007, due to material weaknesses and significant deficiencies in internal control. These weaknesses include issues with period-end financial reporting process, disgorgements and penalties accounts receivable, accounting for transaction fee revenue, and preparing financial statement disclosures. Additionally, there are deficiencies in controls over property and equipment, and accounting for budgetary resources.

• The SEC's financial statements for fiscal years 2007 and 2006 were fairly stated in all material respects, but the weaknesses in internal control may adversely affect decisions by SEC management based on inaccurate information. Unaudited financial information reported by SEC may also contain misstatements due to these weaknesses. The weaknesses in internal control include errors in the calculation of accounts receivable for disgorgements and penalties, and issues with the integration and compatibility of automated systems with the general ledger system.

1. The U.S. Postal Service, the nation's largest civilian employer, had about 765,000 career employees at the end of fiscal year 1997, with 10% of those being in EAS (Executive and Administrative Schedule) positions. The Service's diversity development program was studied by Aguirre International, which found that the Service was a leader in meeting affirmative action goals and striving for parity between its workforce and the CLF. However, the report also noted that women and minorities appeared to be experiencing problems advancing to management jobs at EAS 17 and above positions.
2. The Service's cluster-level workforce was found to have black and Asian men and women fully represented, while Hispanic men and women, Native American men and women, and white women were underrepresented when compared with the 1990 CLF. The same trend was observed in the Service's headquarters-level and area office-level workforces.
3. The representation of women and minorities in EAS 17 and above positions generally increased from fiscal year 1993 to 1997, with the exception of black men at the cluster level and black, white, and Native American men at the area office level.
4. The representation of women and minorities among those promoted to EAS 17 and above positions in fiscal year 1997 was higher than their representation in EAS 17 and above positions, with the exception of Asian women at the cluster and headquarters levels and certain groups at the area office level.
5. The overall representation of women and minorities in EAS 17 and above positions was lower than it was in EAS 11 through 16 positions in fiscal year 1997, indicating an opportunity for the Service to increase diversity in its higher EAS positions.

• MWDs (Military Working Dogs) are canines used by the DOD for various operations such as explosive and illegal narcotic detection, patrol, and tracking. They can be deployed outside their assigned military installation and are removed from service due to medical or behavior problems or when they are no longer needed.

• Robby's Law, enacted in 2000, promotes the adoption of MWDs after their military service. The NDAA for FY 2016 established priorities for the authorized recipients of MWDs removed from service, giving first priority to former handlers, second priority to others capable of humanely caring for the MWD, and the lowest priority to law enforcement agencies.

• The DOD uses the term "disposition" to describe the process of removing MWDs from service. Decisions regarding removal are made by a review board, including the Commander of the Air Force’s 341st Training Squadron, a Veterinary Corps Officer, and a Veterinary Corps Officer behavioral representative.

• Handlers interested in adopting an MWD must communicate their interest to the Kennel Master where the MWD is located. The most recent handler would typically adopt the MWD in case of multiple handlers expressing interest.

• The Army Veterinary Service has the lead responsibility for the medical care of all DOD-owned animals, including MWDs. During the MWD disposition process, Army Veterinary Corps Officers provide a recommendation letter and a consultation/referral form describing each MWD’s medical condition and suitability for adoption.

• The number of MWDs adopted or transferred during 2011 through 2015 varied, with the highest numbers in 2012 and 2013. Some of the adopted MWDs were likely never deployed outside of their assigned military installations. Available data for 55 percent of the MWDs adopted in 2014 and 2015 indicate that prevalent medical conditions included skin, dental, and musculoskeletal issues.
