* The U.S.-Oman Free Trade Agreement (FTA) was concluded in 2005 and is the fifth U.S. bilateral FTA with a country in the proposed Middle East Free Trade Area (MEFTA). The FTA is expected to have a small but positive impact on the U.S. economy and will provide immediate duty-free access for almost all consumer and industrial goods traded between the two countries.
* U.S. interest in Oman includes its strategic location at the entrance to the Persian Gulf, its moderate Islamic government, its history of political and economic cooperation with the U.S., and its support for the U.S. war on terrorism. Oman is seeking to diversify its economy beyond oil and gas exports and sees the U.S. as an important ally in this effort.
</summary>

• Hate crimes are criminal offenses motivated by bias against certain personal characteristics.
<summary>

• Congress has enacted several laws to address hate crimes, including the Civil Rights Act of 1968, the Hate Crimes Statistics Act of 1990, and the Hate Crimes Sentencing Enhancement Act of 1994.

• The Matthew Shepard and James Byrd, Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act of 2009 expanded the scope of hate crime victims to include gender, sexual orientation, gender identity, and disability.

• The commerce clause, section 5 of the 14th Amendment, and section 2 of the 13th and 15th Amendments are the grants of power most often mentioned when discussing Congress's authority to proscribe hate crimes and to enact other forms of civil rights legislation.

• The commerce clause authorizes Congress to regulate activities that have a substantial relation to interstate commerce, but the Supreme Court has narrowed the "affects interstate commerce" category.

• Hate crimes that involve interstate travel continue to be within the commerce clause's reach, but attempts to broaden the scope of hate crime legislation tied to findings and the general nature and consequences of hate crimes under the commerce clause may be constitutionally suspect.

• Hate-driven denials by state officers or those acting under the color of law of equal protection or due process, or the right to vote fall within the scope of the legislative sections of the 14th and 15th Amendments.

• Hate crimes committed by private individuals not acting under the color of law are beyond the scope of the 14th and 15th Amendments, but Section 2 of the 13th Amendment may be a more viable option for broadening hate crime legislation.

• There are other constitutional limits upon the manner in which Congress and/or states may enact hate crime legislation, including challenges under the 1st and 6th Amendments.

• East Asian nations, including China, Japan, and South Korea, have had exchange rate policies that have caused tension with the United States. Some argue that these policies constitute currency manipulation and violate international agreements.
<summary>

• The Department of the Treasury is required to analyze the exchange rate policies of major trading partners and has identified six countries, including four from East Asia, to monitor for potential currency manipulation.

• Different types of exchange rate policies include free float, pegged, and managed float, each with its own advantages and disadvantages. Many East Asian governments have chosen a managed float policy.

• A free float policy allows a nation more autonomy with its domestic monetary policy but can result in greater exchange-rate risk, potentially destabilizing balance sheet effects, and possible rapid shifts in capital flows.

• A pegged exchange rate policy can virtually eliminate exchange-rate risk but can result in the loss of autonomy in domestic monetary policy, potentially rapid changes in domestic prices, and exposure to speculative attacks on the pegged exchange rate.

• The Currency Reform for Fair Trade Act has been introduced in the 115th Congress, which would permit the imposition of countervailing duties on imports from countries with fundamentally undervalued currencies.
</summary>

<summary>

* The title "Chief of Mission" (COM) refers to the principal officer in charge of each U.S. diplomatic mission to a foreign country, foreign territory, or international organization.
* U.S. ambassadors, who are appointed by the President with the advice and consent of the Senate, typically hold the COM position at U.S. embassies abroad.
* COMs are responsible for coordinating interagency activities and have authority over U.S. forces operating in their countries of assignment, with some exceptions.
* The role of COMs has expanded significantly since World War II, and they are now considered "chief executive officers" of multi-agency missions.
* The Foreign Service Act of 1980 (FSA 1980) outlines the authorities and responsibilities of COMs, including their responsibilities, authority over personnel, and obligations of U.S. government personnel to the COM.
* COM authority is derived from the President's general constitutional powers in foreign affairs and is detailed in the President's letter of instruction to each COM.
* COMs have full responsibility for the direction, coordination, and supervision of all executive branch employees in their country of assignment, except for certain exclusions.
* COMs are responsible for promoting U.S. goods and services for export and for keeping fully and currently informed of all activities and operations of the U.S. government within their country of assignment.
* COM authority does not extend to representatives of the judicial and legislative branches, including Members of Congress and their staffs.
</summary>

<summary>

- China's economy is heavily dependent on global trade and investment flows, with net exports contributing to one-third of its GDP growth in 2007.
- Foreign direct investment (FDI) flows to China have been a major factor behind its productivity gains and rapid economic growth, with FDI flows totaling $92 billion in 2008.
- The current global economic slowdown, particularly among its major export markets, is having a significant negative impact on China's export sector and industries that depend on FDI flows.
- China's exposure to the current global financial crisis, particularly from the fallout of the U.S. sub-prime mortgage problem, is unclear, but Chinese government entities may have been more exposed to troubled U.S. mortgage securities.
- China has taken a number of steps to respond to the global financial crisis, including implementing a two-year, 4 trillion yuan ($586 billion) stimulus package dedicated to infrastructure projects and industry subsidies.
- China has also announced plans to spend $124 billion over the next three years to create a universal health care system and boost rural incomes and spending levels.
- Despite recent positive developments, many analysts have raised concerns over long-term growth prospects, including the reliance on bank lending and infrastructure spending projects, potential sharp rise in non-performing loans, and slowing reform efforts.
- Analysts debate China's role in responding to the global financial crisis, including boosting purchases of U.S. securities and stocks, but concerns over long-term economic benefits and domestic development needs may hinder significant increases in investments.
</summary>

1. <summary>The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) is responsible for managing most federal mineral development, including oil and gas leasing on public domain lands. The Forest Service, part of the U.S. Department of Agriculture, plays a role in authorizing mineral development on National Forest System lands.</summary>
2. <summary>The Mineral Lands Leasing Act of 1920 (MLLA) authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to lease oil and gas deposits and onshore public domain lands containing oil and gas deposits, with the federal government retaining title to the lands. This leasing authority applies to National Forest System lands that are reserved from the public domain and to most reserved subsurface mineral estates.</summary>
3. <summary>The Secretary of the Interior cannot issue any lease for National Forest System lands reserved from the public domain if the Secretary of Agriculture objects. The U.S. Forest Service has issued separate regulations governing certain aspects of leasing and permitting for oil and gas development on lands within its jurisdiction.</summary>
4. <summary>The Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (FLPMA) requires the Secretary of the Interior to develop and revise land use plans for public lands that consider present and potential future uses and prevent permanent impairment of environmental, historical, and natural resource values. These Resource Management Plans (RMPs) serve as the initial determinant of which lands may be subject to leasing.</summary>
5. <summary>The MLLA authorizes both competitive and noncompetitive leasing procedures. Competitive bidding must be held on a quarterly basis in each state where public lands are available for leasing. The Secretary may also authorize additional opportunities for bidding if he considers them to be necessary.</summary>
6. <summary>The Energy Policy Act of 2005 (EPACT) requires the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture to enter into a memorandum of understanding regarding issues such as the establishment of procedures to ensure timely processing of oil and gas lease applications, surface use plans of operation, and APDs. The EPACT also establishes that certain actions taken by either the Secretary of the Interior or by the Secretary of Agriculture (when NFS lands are involved) shall be subject to a rebuttable presumption that the use of a categorical exclusion under NEPA would apply

<summary>

- In 2014, 30% of tax filers chose to itemize their deductions, with higher-income filers more likely to itemize and claim larger average deduction amounts. Of those who itemized, 56.2% had incomes less than $100,000, and 86.8% had an AGI less than $200,000.
- Specific deductions tend to benefit different types of itemizers based on their income. For example, tax filers in higher-income ranges claimed deductions for charitable gifts, state and local income taxes, and real estate property taxes at higher rates than tax filers in lower-income ranges.
- The mortgage interest deduction was, on average, the largest single deduction claimed by tax filers with an AGI less than $500,000, while the deduction for state and local income taxes was the largest average deduction amount claimed for any deduction by tax filers with an AGI greater than $500,000.
- The four itemized deductions that are projected to contribute most to tax expenditures in FY2018 are estimated to account for 17.8% ($241.2 billion) of the approximately $1.36 trillion in net individual tax expenditures. These deductions include the deduction for state and local income or sales taxes, the deduction for home mortgage interest, charitable gifts, and real estate taxes.

</summary>

1. The Pacific Islands region, also known as the South Pacific or Southwest Pacific, is strategically important to the United States and encompasses U.S. territories. The region is home to 14 sovereign states and three countries in "free association" with the United States. The United States has economic interests in the region, particularly fishing, and provides foreign assistance to Pacific Island countries for climate change adaptation and mitigation.
2. The Pacific Islands Forum (PIF) is a regional organization that seeks to foster cooperation between member states on issues such as climate change, regional security, and fisheries. The Melanesian Spearhead Group (MSG) is a subgroup of the PIF that includes Melanesian countries and organizations. The MSG has granted observer status to the United Liberation Movement for West Papua and associate member status to Indonesia.
3. The United States enjoys friendly relations with Pacific Island countries and has benefitted from their support in the United Nations. The United States has worked with Australia and New Zealand to advance shared strategic interests, maintain regional stability, and promote economic development in the region. China has become a diplomatic force, major source of foreign aid, and leading trade partner in the Southwest Pacific. Other nations, including Russia, India, and Indonesia, have also made efforts to expand their engagement in the region.
4. The Pacific Islands region faces challenges such as weak political institutions, lack of resources, and threats from climate change. The United States has emphasized the importance of the region for U.S. strategic and security interests and has sought to promote sustainable economic development, good governance, and regional cooperation. U.S. assistance aims to help strengthen Pacific Islands regional fora and address areas of concern such as illegal fishing, peacekeeping operations, and natural disasters.

<summary>

* The Endangered Species Act (ESA) is a federal law that provides for the listing and protection of species that are endangered or threatened with extinction. Listing a species results in limitations on activities that could affect that species and penalties for taking individuals of a listed species.
* Federal agencies are required to consult with the Fish and Wildlife Service or the National Marine Fisheries Service to determine whether an agency project might jeopardize the continued existence of listed species or destroy or adversely modify a species' critical habitat. This process is known as consultation and concludes with the issuance of a biological opinion (BiOp) as to the harm the project poses.
* If a project could jeopardize a species, a jeopardy opinion is released along with any reasonable and prudent alternatives (RPAs) to the agency action that would avoid jeopardy. To excuse any incidental taking of listed species, the Services issue an incidental take statement that includes reasonable and prudent measures (RPMs) to minimize the effects of the project.
* The exemption process is available for federal agencies, the governor of the state where the project would occur, or the licensees or permittees involved in the project to seek an exemption from the ESA if there are extraordinary economic circumstances and there is no RPA that would avoid jeopardy. This process offers the opportunity to consider economic factors in evaluating federal actions, and provides an opportunity for economic factors to override jeopardy to the species.
* In the controversy over California water projects, there were proposals in the mid- and late-2000s to seek an exemption from the ESA. The exemption process is used so rarely that the historical prologue as seen through these past applications may prove useful.
</summary>

• The enactment of the individual income tax in 1913 has led to continuous debate in Congress regarding the appropriate taxation of capital gains income, with numerous bills introduced in every session to change the way capital gains income is taxed. There has also been interest in the tax treatment of capital losses, with some proposing an increase in the limit on capital losses that can be deducted against ordinary income (the loss limit) from its current $3,000 to $10,000 or $15,000. The loss limit was originally enacted to prevent taxpayers from minimizing their income taxes by altering the timing of the realization of gains and losses. However, increasing the loss limitation would tend to increase the dichotomy between the tax treatment of gains and losses.

• The tax treatment of capital gains and losses has changed repeatedly over the years, with some legislative changes attempting to reestablish symmetry between the tax treatment of capital gains and capital losses. Under current law, asymmetries remain, with net long-term losses deductible against net short-term gains without limit, and net long-term losses deductible against up to $3,000 of ordinary income even though the maximum rate on ordinary income is 35% while the maximum rate on long-term gains is 15%. The recent downturn in the stock market has prompted suggestions to increase the net capital loss limitation as a means of softening the downturn for some investors, but this would tend to increase the dichotomy between the tax treatment of gains and losses.

<summary>

* The National Labor Relations Act (NLRA) recognizes the right of employees to engage in collective bargaining through representatives of their own choosing.
* The NLRA applies only to "employees," and not to all individuals employed by an employer; an employee's job title does not determine whether an individual is a supervisor for purposes of the NLRA.
* The NLRB and U.S. Supreme Court have sought to provide meaning to the term "independent judgment" in the NLRA's definition of a supervisor.
* In Kentucky River Community Care, Inc., the U.S. Supreme Court maintained that the NLRB's reference to "ordinary or technical judgment" established a "startling categorical exclusion" that was not suggested by the NLRA's statutory text.
* The NLRA prohibits certain misconduct by both employers and unions that interferes with the right of employees to engage in collective bargaining.
* An employer's communication to its employees may constitute an unlawful threat for purposes of section 8(a)(1) of the NLRA if it contains a 'threat of reprisal or force or promise of benefit.'
* The NLRB has indicated that section 8(b)(1)(A) "broadly interdicts any union conduct threatening job security of employees because of the employees' refusal or failure to abide by union membership conditions."
* The NLRB has maintained that an employer may make antiunion, but noncoercive, speeches to their employees on company time and on company property without allowing a union an equal opportunity to reply.
</summary>

<summary>

* Banks play a crucial role in the economy by connecting borrowers and savers, but banking is also an inherently risky activity that can generate significant losses.
* Regulatory measures have been implemented to manage risks in banking, including prudential regulation and consumer protection laws. The Dodd-Frank Act and Basel III Accords have made banking regulations more stringent in recent years.
* The Volcker Rule, a provision in the Dodd-Frank Act, generally prohibits depository banks from engaging in proprietary trading or sponsoring a hedge fund or private equity fund.
* Community banks, which are generally smaller and simpler than large banks, are subject to regulatory relief measures to minimize their regulatory burden. However, the number of community banks has been declining in recent decades.
* Financial regulatory agencies are generally independent from the President and Congress, but this independence can result in a lack of accountability. Some observers argue that financial regulators should be more accountable to Congress through measures such as ending self-funding and bringing regulators into the appropriations and authorization processes.
</summary>

* The President signed S. 2499, the Medicare, Medicaid, and SCHIP Extension Act of 2007, which makes changes to Medicare, Medicaid, and SCHIP programs.
* The Act suspends the Medicare physician payment cut scheduled to take effect and provides SCHIP funding through March 2009.
* The Act mandates a 0.5% increase in the Medicare physician fee schedule for the six-month period from January 1, 2008, through June 30, 2008, and provides FY2008 and FY2009 SCHIP allotments through March 31, 2009.
* The Act also extends a number of expiring provisions and programs, including Medicare Advantage plans, Medicare payments for certain providers and services, and Medicaid payments and programs.
* The Act includes funding for miscellaneous activities, such as additional funds under the State Health Insurance Assistance Programs and grants for Area Agencies on Aging and Aging and Disability Resource Centers.
* The Act extends the Title V Abstinence Education block grant through June 30, 2008, and amends the Public Health Service Act to provide for research into the prevention of Type I diabetes.
* The Act also includes offsets to pay for the provisions, such as a reduction in federal payments for the Medicare Advantage stabilization fund in 2012 and strengthened procedures for determining Medicare's responsibility as a secondary payer.
</summary>

* Committees are required to adopt their own written rules of procedure, which must be consistent with House rules. These rules cover various aspects of committee operations, including hearings, markups, reporting, oversight and investigations, funding, staff, and travel.

<summary>

* The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) is a 10-member grouping of Southeast Asian nations with a combined population of 580 million and an annual gross domestic product (GDP) of around $1.5 trillion.
* The Obama Administration has expressed an intent to pay greater attention to Southeast Asia, listen more carefully to regional concerns, and work with multilateral organizations, particularly ASEAN, to cooperate on issues of mutual interest.
* The United States has deep-seated interests in Southeast Asia, such as maritime security, the promotion of democracy and human rights, the encouragement of liberal trade and investment regimes, counterterrorism, the combating of illegal trafficking of narcotics and human trafficking, and many others.
* Engagement with ASEAN has presented the United States with an important foreign policy dilemma. Despite considerable U.S. security, economic, and foreign assistance initiatives in the region, particularly at the bilateral level, in recent years a perception has developed among Southeast Asian elites that the United States has placed relatively little priority on ASEAN itself and has, thereby, demonstrated a lack of commitment to Southeast Asia as a whole.
* The United States has long had close bilateral relations with many of Southeast Asia's nations. However, symbolic commitment is particularly important in a region that places a heavy emphasis on process and informal networking. Many observers argue that the United States needs to "show up" more frequently and at higher official levels, lest it lose influence in the region and risk being cut out of emerging Asian diplomatic and economic architectures.
* The Obama Administration has taken steps to engage with ASEAN and Southeast Asian countries at a higher level, including the accession to ASEAN's Treaty of Amity and Cooperation (TAC) and the participation in the U.S.-ASEAN leaders meeting in 2009.
</summary>

<summary>

- The "state sponsors of terrorism list" is a designation under the Export Administration Act of 1979, and currently includes Cuba, Iran, North Korea, Sudan, and Syria.
- Countries on the list are subject to certain trade benefits, foreign aid, and international financial institution restrictions.
- Cuba has been on the list since 1982 due to its repeated provision of support for acts of international terrorism.
- Removal from the list can occur if the President certifies that the government has not supported acts of international terrorism and will not in the future.
- Cuba was added to the list in 1982 due to its ties to international terrorism, including support for armed insurgencies and terrorist activities in Latin America and the Caribbean.
- Cuba has provided support for terrorist organizations such as the FALN, FMLN, and FSLN, and has helped transship Soviet arms to Nicaragua and El Salvador for use by terrorist organizations.
- Cuba has been accused of hosting members of foreign terrorist organizations and U.S. fugitives from justice, and has been criticized for not extraditing wanted fugitives to the United States.
- Critics argue that Cuba's presence on the list is a holdover of the Cold War and that it diverts U.S. attention from serious terrorist threats.

</summary>

1. The Alternative Minimum Tax (AMT) is a separate tax calculation with a broader base than the regular tax, including certain itemized deductions, the standard deduction, and personal exemptions. However, it does not include the benefits of lower capital gains tax rates and the exclusion for tax-exempt bonds. The AMT exemptions are not indexed to inflation, causing an increase in the number of taxpayers subject to the AMT over time.
2. In 1987, about 140,000 returns paid the AMT, but this number increased to 823,000 by 1999 and is projected to reach over 9 million by 2009. This growth is due to the failure to index exemptions to inflation and the interaction of the AMT with tax credits.
3. The AMT will gradually reach further down into the income distribution, with a larger portion of returns with tax liability subject to the AMT. The shift in the distribution of the AMT is dramatic, with a decrease in the share of taxpayers in the highest income classes and an increase in the middle and upper middle income classes.
4. The cost of correcting the AMT is significant, with indexing AMT exemptions costing $13.9 billion by 2008 and eliminating the credit limit provision costing many billions of dollars by 2008 or 2009.
5. Tax cuts that reduce regular tax liabilities and do not alter the AMT will increase the number of taxpayers on the AMT and cause some or all of the tax cut not to be received by certain families. Tax provisions that are aimed at reducing taxes for joint returns may particularly interact with the AMT due to the progressive tax rates and higher incomes of married couples.

1. The Transportation, Housing and Urban Development, and Related Agencies (THUD) Appropriations Subcommittees in the House and Senate are responsible for drafting bills to provide annual appropriations for the Department of Transportation (DOT), the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD), and six related agencies. DOT's budget is primarily for grants to state and local government agencies for transportation infrastructure, while HUD's programs address housing problems faced by low-income households or those with special needs.
2. The THUD bill typically includes regular annual appropriations, advance appropriations, and sometimes emergency appropriations. Most of DOT's budget is in the form of contract authority, while most of HUD's funding is discretionary. The House-passed FY2018 bill would provide $115.3 billion for THUD, while the Senate-reported bill recommends $119.1 billion.
3. The President's FY2018 budget requested $40.7 billion in gross discretionary appropriations for HUD, while the House-passed bill would provide $48.0 billion and the Senate-reported bill would provide $49.9 billion. The President's budget proposed eliminating funding for several HUD grant programs and reducing funding for most other accounts, while the House and Senate bills would provide increased funding for some accounts and decreased funding for others.

<summary>

* The U.S. and India have established a "global partnership" in 2005, focusing on various issues including non-proliferation and security.
* India has a historical and friendly relationship with Iran, and has been reluctant to abandon it despite U.S. pressure, due to energy commerce and geostrategic motives.
* India has voted with the U.S. in IAEA resolutions finding Iran in noncompliance with its international obligations, causing criticism from opposition parties and independent analysts.
* The Hyde Act, which became P.L. 109-401 in December 2006, preserved the House's "statement of policy" language and added a prerequisite for the President to provide to Congress a description of India's efforts to prevent Iran from obtaining weapons of mass destruction.
* There have been occasional revelations of Indian transfers to Iran of technology that could be useful for Iran's purported weapons of mass destruction programs.
* India and Iran have established steady but relatively low level defense and military relations since the formation of an Indo-Iran Joint Commission in 1983, but have not evolved into a noteworthy strategic alliance.

</summary>

• The text discusses the proposed Milk Import Tariff Equity Act, which aims to limit imports of milk protein concentrates (MPCs), casein, and caseinates through the introduction of two separate tariff-rate quotas (TRQs). The first TRQ would apply to MPCs with a protein concentration of 40% to 90%, and the second TRQ would cover the combined imports of three products: milk protein concentrate (90% protein), casein, and caseinates. Annual imports in excess of the proposed TRQ quantities would be assessed higher duties. Enactment of the proposed legislation would likely result in the United States entering compensation negotiations with WTO member countries that are major suppliers of MPCs to the U.S. market.

• The text also highlights the positions of various stakeholders regarding the proposed legislation. Dairy farmers, represented by organizations like the National Milk Producers Federation and Dairy Farmers of Canada, generally support the legislation as they believe it will help protect their interests. However, dairy product processors and manufacturers, represented by the International Dairy Foods Association, are against further restrictions on dairy imports, arguing that it would increase production costs, raise consumer prices, and potentially harm U.S. dairy exports. The potential impact of imposing TRQs on farm milk prices depends on the level of farm prices relative to the implied level of support under the Dairy Product Price Support Program.

<summary>

* Serbia has experienced substantial economic growth, but the global economic crisis has had a negative impact and recovery has been slow.
* Serbia has held largely free and fair elections, but organized crime and high-level corruption remain serious problems.
* Serbia has set integration in the European Union as its key foreign policy goal, but its prospects have been clouded by concerns over its relations with Kosovo.
* The Serbian Progressive Party (SNS) and the Socialist Party of Serbia (SPS) made significant gains in the 2012 parliamentary, presidential, and local elections.
* The new government, led by the SPS, has boosted its popularity by launching an anti-corruption drive, but observers caution that the rule of law must be preserved.
* The powers of the autonomous region of Vojvodina and the status of the Presevo Valley region in southern Serbia have been controversial issues.
* Serbia's relations with its former Kosovo province have been a major challenge, with Belgrade opposing Kosovo's declaration of independence and pushing for de facto control over northern Kosovo.
</summary>

1. <summary>The Supreme Court decided four search and seizure cases during its October 2012 term, including Florida v. Jardines, which dealt with the use of a trained narcotics-detection dog at the front door of a suspected marijuana grow house. The Court held that such a search requires probable cause.</summary>
2. <summary>The Court's decision in Jardines was based on the Jones principle that a Fourth Amendment search occurs whenever the government physically intrudes upon constitutionally protected property, rather than the expectation of privacy rationale used in previous dog sniffing cases.</summary>
3. <summary>The Florida Supreme Court had previously refused to accept a trained drug-detection dog's positive reaction as per se probable cause in Harris, instead listing a host of criteria under which a trained dog's alert might be considered probable cause.</summary>
4. <summary>In Bailey v. United States, the Court held that the natural metabolization of alcohol in the bloodstream does not present a per se exigency that justifies an exception to the Fourth Amendment's warrant requirement for nonconsensual blood testing in all drunk-driving cases.</summary>
5. <summary>The Court's decision in Bailey was based on the specific facts of the case and the need to balance the Fourth Amendment's limit on intrusions on personal liberty with the need for officer safety and the preservation of evidence.</summary>

• The federal government has supported energy storage and electric power system technology since the 1970s, before the establishment of the Department of Energy (DOE). The program was initially focused on energy storage and supporting large coal and nuclear power plants.
<summary>

• Advancements in computer capacity, miniaturization, and industrial controls have expanded the ability of grid operators to monitor and control electric power flows. The increase in networking of computerized devices for grid data collection and control has further improved operators' ability to anticipate, avoid, and mitigate potential power crises.

• However, in recent years, Internet-connected networks have become vulnerable to unwanted computer-driven intrusions and disruptions, revealing a new cybersecurity challenge for electric power systems.

• The nation's energy infrastructure is diverse and includes various transmission and distribution system network structures, operating models, hardware, and software. Interdependency within the sector and across the nation's critical energy infrastructure sectors is significant. Coordinating the security and resilience of energy assets is complicated by the virtually borderless nature of energy use and the reliance on predominantly privately-owned infrastructure.

• Key challenges and opportunities facing the electric power industry include a changing power generation mix, replacing aging infrastructure, modernizing and securing communication networks, accommodating new end-use technologies, planning for increased interdependencies of natural gas, water, and electricity systems, and devising business models to manage these challenges while providing reliable and affordable electricity.

• The DOE Office of Electricity Delivery and Energy Reliability (OE) is responsible for supporting more economically competitive, environmentally responsible, secure, and resilient U.S. energy infrastructure. OE supports electric grid modernization and resiliency through research and development (R&D), demonstration projects, partnerships, facilitation, modeling and analytics, and emergency preparedness and response.

• OE is the federal government's lead entity for energy sector-specific responses to national energy security emergencies due to hardware or software problems. OE leads DOE's efforts to strengthen, transform, and improve the energy infrastructure so that consumers have access to reliable, secure, and clean sources of energy.

• The largest share of OE funding goes to R&D on technology development, while the remainder supports various planning and operational areas. OE divides its responsibilities into five general areas: R

<summary>

* The District of Columbia is unique as it is the center of the U.S. government and location of numerous memorials.
* The Commemorative Works Act (CWA) was enacted in 1986 to guide the creation of memorials in the District of Columbia.
* The CWA aims to preserve the integrity of the L'Enfant and McMillan plans, ensure continued public use and enjoyment of open space, preserve open space, and ensure appropriate design and location of future commemorative works.
* The CWA applies to statues, monuments, sculptures, memorials, plaques, inscriptions, or other structures designed to perpetuate the memory of an individual, group, event, or other significant element of American history.
* The CWA does not apply to military properties or land under the jurisdiction of the Smithsonian or the Architect of the Capitol.
* The CWA established a 24-step process for creating a memorial in the District of Columbia, including initiation, legislation, site election and approval, design approval, fundraising, construction, and dedication.
* The National Capital Memorial Advisory Commission offers consultative services to potential sponsors of commemorative works.
* The CWA provides that no commemorative work may be established in the District of Columbia unless specifically authorized by Congress.
* The CWA specifies requirements for military works and works commemorating events, individuals, or groups, including a 10-year waiting period for military works and a 25-year waiting period for events, individuals, or groups.
</summary>

<summary>

* The Senate Finance Committee approved the America's Healthy Future Act of 2009 (S. 1796) on October 13, 2009, which would reform the private health insurance market, set minimum standards for health benefits, and provide financial assistance to certain individuals and small employers.
* The bill would require individuals to maintain health insurance and certain employers with more than 50 employees to provide insurance or pay a tax, with some exceptions.
* Market reforms such as modified community rating and guaranteed issue and renewal would be implemented, and existing plans offered by employers and in the individual market would be grandfathered.
* Exchanges would be established to offer eligible individuals and small businesses access to private plans, and certain individuals with incomes below 400% of the federal poverty level could qualify for credits and subsidies towards their premium costs and cost-sharing.
* States would have the flexibility to establish basic plans for low-income individuals not eligible for Medicaid.
* Title VI of the bill includes provisions to raise revenues to pay for expanded health insurance coverage, such as excise taxes and annual fees on health insurers, limitations on executive compensation of insurance companies, and limitations on contributions to tax-advantaged accounts used for health care expenses.
* The bill would alter how current private health insurance markets function, particularly for individuals who purchase coverage directly from an insurer or through a small employer.
* Reforms affecting premium rating would likely increase premiums for some and lower premiums for others, depending on their age, health, behaviors, and other factors.
* States are the primary regulators of the private health insurance market, though some federal regulation applies, mostly affecting employer-sponsored health insurance.
</summary>

• High risk health insurance pools (HRPs) are established by 35 states to provide health insurance coverage to individuals who cannot obtain or afford health insurance in the private market due to preexisting health conditions.
<summary>

• HRPs cover individuals who have been denied coverage, received high quotes, or received offers with preexisting condition exclusions in the individual market. They also help states comply with HIPAA's portability and guaranteed availability provisions.

• State HRPs have limited enrollment, with approximately 200,000 individuals enrolled in 2008, while nearly 4 million additional persons were potentially eligible. This is due to the narrow focus on individuals with preexisting conditions seeking coverage in the private, non-group market.

• Federal and state laws restrict insurers' ability to reject applications or design coverage based on health factors in the nongroup market, but some applicants are still rejected or charged higher premiums. HRPs assist such individuals by providing an alternative source of coverage.

• HRPs are designed to stabilize the market, promote competition, and retain insurance carriers by removing high risk persons from the individual market and placing them in publicly subsidized insurance pools. However, some researchers are skeptical about their ability to substantially reduce the number of uninsured, particularly among those with serious medical conditions.
</summary>

<summary>

* The Civil Reserve Air Fleet (CRAF) is a program that provides additional airlift capacity to the Department of Defense (DOD) during times of crisis, using commercial aircraft from U.S. carriers. The program is managed jointly by DOD and the Department of Transportation.
* CRAF has three main segments: international, national, and aeromedical evacuation. The international segment is further divided into long-range and short-range sections, while the national segment is divided into domestic and Alaskan sections. Assignment of aircraft to a segment depends on the nature of the requirement and the aircraft performance characteristics needed.
* The FY2008 National Defense Authorization Act contained provisions for a comprehensive assessment of CRAF, extension of the Aviation Insurance Program, and a DOD study on the size and mix of the airlift force, including the potential impact of CRAF on DOD's airlift fleet requirements.
</summary>

<summary>

* The National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA) is a U.S. Department of Commerce agency that advises on domestic and international telecommunications and information technology policies, represents the executive branch in telecommunications and information policy activities, and manages spectrum used by federal agencies.
* NTIA's responsibilities include overseeing the transfer of radio frequencies from the federal domain to the commercial domain, administering grants programs, and establishing a $135 million grant program for states to plan for participation in a new nationwide public safety broadband network.
* NTIA collaborates with other agencies, such as the Federal Communications Commission, Department of State, Rural Utilities Service, and Department of Homeland Security, on various telecommunications and information technology matters.
* NTIA is currently working on increasing spectrum capacity for mobile broadband, studying spectrum sharing, and implementing provisions from the Middle Class Tax Relief and Job Creation Act of 2012, including working with the FCC to identify specific bands for auction and supporting the creation and operation of FirstNet, a new nationwide, broadband network for public safety communications.

</summary>

1. The Energy Policy Act of 2005, also known as the "Electric Reliability Act of 2005," was signed into law by President Bush on August 8, 2005. It includes provisions related to tax incentives for domestic energy production and efficiency, a mandate to double the use of biofuels, faster procedures for energy production on federal lands, and authorization of numerous federal energy research and development programs.
2. The act includes electricity provisions that establish federal jurisdiction over activities that support the reliability of the U.S. bulk power system. It clarifies the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission's (FERC) authority to establish and regulate an electric reliability organization (ERO), which is responsible for developing and enforcing reliability standards for the bulk power system, including cybersecurity protection.
3. The act requires FERC to conduct a study of electric transmission congestion every three years and authorizes FERC to issue construction permits in certain cases. It also gives the Department of Energy (DOE) new authority to prepare environmental documents and make decisions related to rights-of-way and siting on federal lands.
4. The act includes provisions related to third-party finance and advanced transmission technologies. It also establishes an Advanced Power System Technology Incentive Program and provides incentive payments to owners or operators of advanced power generation systems.
5. The act includes provisions related to open nondiscriminatory access, federal utility participation in regional transmission organizations, and the Native Load Service Obligation. It also requires FERC to issue a rule on long-term transmission rights and organized markets within one year of enactment.

• The Robinson-Patman Act (R-P) was enacted in 1936 to allow small businesses to compete with larger ones in purchasing commodities.
 • The R-P prohibits sellers in interstate commerce from charging different purchasers different prices for goods of "like grade and quality" and applies only to the sale of goods purchased for resale within the United States.
 • The R-P has been inconsistently enforced by the Federal Trade Commission and has been met with criticism from the Department of Justice, which views the act as not beneficial to consumers.
 • Defenses to an allegation of unlawful price differentials under the R-P include "meeting competition" and "cost justified" price differentials, as well as the Nonprofit Institutions Act, which permits price breaks on purchases of supplies for nonprofit institutions not operated for profit.
 • The Nonprofit Institutions Act has been interpreted strictly by the Supreme Court, limiting its exemption to purchases made in order to enable the institution to meet the needs of its users and excluding purchases for resale or for use in a portion of a hospital-based physician's private practice unconnected with the hospital.
 • The Antitrust Modernization Commission recommended in 2007 that Congress should repeal the R-P in its entirety, as it has had the unintended effect of limiting the extent of discounting and causing consumers to pay higher prices than they otherwise would.

1. <summary>The Take Care Clause of the U.S. Constitution requires the President to ensure that laws are faithfully executed, but it has been interpreted as both imposing a duty on the President and providing the President with discretion not to enforce certain laws.</summary>
2. <summary>The President has significant involvement in the legislative process, but once a bill becomes law, the President's role shifts to executing the law.</summary>
3. <summary>The Take Care Clause has been interpreted as preventing the President from simply disregarding or suspending laws enacted by Congress, and it helps to maintain the separation of powers between the executive and legislative branches.</summary>
4. <summary>The Supreme Court has established that when an executive officer fails to perform a specific duty assigned by law, the courts may enforce the obligation through a writ of mandamus.</summary>
5. <summary>The President's obligation to execute the law is contingent upon the creation of a well-defined statutory mandate or prohibition, and courts are unlikely to enforce the duty when Congress has legislated broadly, ambiguously, or in a nonobligatory manner.</summary>
6. <summary>The Take Care Clause also establishes a personal responsibility in the President to oversee the execution and enforcement of the law, and the courts have invalidated laws that would undermine this responsibility.</summary>
7. <summary>Prosecutorial discretion, or the decision to initiate a criminal prosecution, is a core aspect of the President's obligation to execute the law, and judicial hesitance to review prosecutorial decisions is perhaps at its peak when the government chooses not to prosecute.</summary>
8. <summary>Agency civil enforcement decisions in the administrative context share some characteristics with prosecutorial discretion, but it is not entirely clear if they enjoy the same constitutional footing.</summary>
9. <summary>Courts generally will not review discretionary agency enforcement decisions, and they have established a presumption of nonreviewability for agency nonenforcement decisions, which may only be overcome in certain situations.</summary>

• In 2013, the official U.S. poverty rate was 14.5%, a statistically significant drop from 15.0% in 2012.
• The poverty rate tends to follow the economic cycle, with higher poverty rates during recessions and lower poverty rates during economic growth.
• The poverty rate among non-aged adults (persons age 18 to 64) reached a high of 13.8% in 2010 and remained statistically unchanged at 13.6% in 2013.
• The poverty rate among children (under age 18) fell from 21.3% in 2012 to 19.5% in 2013, but is still well above the pre-recession low of 16.9%.
• The Supplemental Poverty Measure (SPM) is a new measure that addresses some of the weaknesses of the official poverty measure, including the effects of taxes, in-kind benefits, and necessary expenses on poverty.
• The SPM yields a different impression of poverty by age than the official measure, with a higher poverty rate for adults ages 18 to 64 and a much higher poverty rate for persons age 65 and over.
• The SPM expands the definition of the economic unit for poverty measurement to include cohabiting partners and their relatives, as well as unrelated children living with a parent. This results in a lower poverty rate for children and a higher poverty rate for the aged compared to the official measure.

<summary>

- The US agricultural sector heavily relies on exports, accounting for about 20% of total U.S. agricultural production.
- U.S. farm legislation, known as the farm bill, is subject to WTO rules and scrutiny due to its significant role in agricultural markets.
- The Agricultural Act of 2014 made substantial changes to the previous farm safety net, with most provisions lasting until September 2018 or the 2018 crop year.
- WTO commitments, particularly under the Agreement on Agriculture (AoA) and Agreement on Subsidies and Countervailing Measures (SCM), impact U.S. agricultural policy choices.
- The AoA categorizes and restricts agricultural domestic support programs based on their potential to distort commercial markets.
- Green Box programs are minimally trade-distorting and exempt from spending limits, while Amber Box programs are the most market-distorting and subject to strict annual spending limits.
- The SCM details rules for determining when a subsidy is prohibited or actionable, focusing on the degree of market distortion caused by the subsidy.
- The WTO Understanding on Rules and Procedures Governing the Settlement of Disputes provides a means for resolving disputes arising under WTO agreements.
</summary>

1. <summary>The campus-based programs, which include the Federal Supplemental Educational Opportunity Grant (FSEOG), Federal Work-Study (FWS), and Federal Perkins Loan programs, are authorized under Title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (HEA) and are unique in that the mix and amount of aid awarded to students are determined according to institution-specific award criteria.</summary>
2. <summary>The authorizations of appropriations for the campus-based programs, along with many other provisions under the HEA, expired at the end of FY2015, but have continued to be funded through annual appropriation bills.</summary>
3. <summary>Of the approximately $125 billion of federal aid that was made available to students through programs authorized under the HEA in FY2016, 76% was through the Direct Loan program, 21% through the Pell Grant program, and 2% through the campus-based aid programs.</summary>
4. <summary>The Federal Perkins Loan program, the oldest of the campus-based aid programs, was originally enacted under Title II of the National Defense Education Act of 1958 and was established in part as a response to the space-race between the United States and the Soviet Union.</summary>
5. <summary>The campus-based programs have come to play a relatively smaller role in the federal student aid effort as federal aid has largely transitioned to a system that allows for "portability" in receipt of student aid.</summary>
6. <summary>As lawmakers consider reauthorization of the HEA, several issues related to the campus-based programs may be considered, including the extent to which the campus-based programs provide types of aid to students that are not provided via other postsecondary aid programs, whether the current formula for allocating funds to institutions is optimal, and the potential role of the campus-based aid programs in a redesigned federal aid system.</summary>
7. <summary>The current formula for allocating funds to institutions participating in the campus-based programs is based on a two-stage, state distribution formula, with funds first allocated to each state based on the population of students in the state and then sub-allocated to IHEs within the state based on the financial need of the IHE's students

1. <summary> The document discusses the issue of adults going missing and the proposed measures to assist in recovering vulnerable adults who go missing. The document also provides an overview of alert systems in 11 states and the methods used to gather data on these systems. The report highlights the need for a federal role in developing state alert systems for missing adults, particularly for vulnerable populations such as seniors with dementia. </summary>
2. <summary> The report identifies various reasons why adults may go missing, including personal choice, disabling conditions, natural catastrophes, and crimes. Unlike children, adults have the legal right to go missing under most circumstances, which can limit the assistance provided by law enforcement agencies to recover them. The document also discusses the federal Missing Alzheimer's Disease Patient Alert grant program, which assists in identifying missing individuals with Alzheimer's disease and other forms of dementia. </summary>
3. <summary> The report provides an overview of alert systems in 11 states, including the legal authority to establish the systems, target population, administrative responsibility, training, process for activating alerts, coordination with other states, system costs, use of the systems, and outcomes. The report concludes with a discussion of issues for Congress to consider with respect to the federal role in developing state alert systems for missing adults. </summary>

<summary>

* The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2017 (P.L. 115-31) includes the Department of Homeland Security Appropriations Act, 2017 (Division F), which provides $41.3 billion in adjusted net discretionary budget authority for the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for FY2017. This is $578 million above the level requested by the Obama Administration and $246 million above the enacted level for FY2016.
* The act also includes $6.7 billion in funding for the costs of major disasters under the Stafford Act and $163 million in funding for overseas contingency operations.
</summary>

<summary>

• The water supply and water quality infrastructure in the US are potentially vulnerable to terrorist attacks, including physical disruption, bioterrorism/chemical contamination, and cyber attacks.

• Damage or destruction of water infrastructure systems could disrupt vital human services, threaten public health and the environment, or cause loss of life.

• Water infrastructure systems are highly linked with other infrastructure systems, such as electric power and transportation, and a disruption in one system can have a domino effect on other systems.

• Water infrastructure systems include surface and ground water sources, dams, reservoirs, aqueducts, pipes, treatment facilities, distribution systems, and wastewater collection and treatment facilities.

• Across the country, these systems comprise approximately 77,000 dams and reservoirs, thousands of miles of pipes, aqueducts, water distribution, and sewer lines, 168,000 public drinking water facilities, and about 16,000 publicly owned wastewater treatment facilities.

• The federal government has ownership responsibility for hundreds of dams and diversion structures, but the vast majority of the nation's water infrastructure is either privately owned or owned by non-federal units of government.

• The federal government has built hundreds of water projects, primarily dams and reservoirs for irrigation development and flood control, with municipal and industrial water use as an incidental, self-financed, project purpose.

• The largest federal facilities were built and are managed by the Bureau of Reclamation (Reclamation) of the Department of the Interior and the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers (Corps) of the Department of Defense.

• Despite its critical involvement in such projects, especially in the West, the federal government is responsible for only about 5% of the dams whose failure could result in loss of life or significant property damage.

</summary>

1. <summary>The Carl D. Perkins Vocational and Technical Education Act of 1998 (Perkins III) was amended and reauthorized by the Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Improvement Act of 2006 (Perkins IV). Perkins IV authorizes funding for career and technical education (CTE) programs for FY2007-FY2012. The act maintains the overall structure and purpose of Perkins III, but makes technical changes and revises certain provisions.</summary>
2. <summary>Perkins IV makes changes to the funding formulas, including reducing the percentage reserved for assistance for outlying areas and increasing the amount of direct grants to outlying areas. The act also modifies the state allotment formula when there are "additional funds" above the amount allotted to states for FY2006.</summary>
3. <summary>Perkins IV strengthens accountability requirements and associated sanctions, including specifying separate core indicators of performance for the secondary and postsecondary levels, linking established indicators to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act (ESEA), and requiring eligible recipients to meet at least 90% of an adjusted level of performance for each core indicator or face sanctions.</summary>
4. <summary>Perkins IV expands the list of interested parties with whom the eligible agency must consult in developing the state plan and adds new requirements to the state plan, such as describing how CTE programs will prepare secondary students, including special populations, to graduate with a diploma and detailing how funds will be used to develop or improve CTE courses at the secondary level.</summary>
5. <summary>Perkins IV adds provisions for the meaningful participation of secondary school students enrolled in nonprofit private schools in career and technical education programs and activities, upon written request of the private school personnel and representatives.</summary>

<summary>

- The federal estate tax is a tax on the estate of a deceased person, levied against and paid by the estate, while an inheritance tax is imposed on and paid by the heirs of the decedent. The gross estate includes the value of all property, real or personal, tangible or intangible, in which the decedent owned an interest on the date of death, as well as certain interests in property transferred to another person prior to death.
* The value of the gross estate is determined by adding the value of all lifetime taxable gifts made by the decedent to the taxable estate. Deductions from the gross estate include estate administration expenses, certain debts and losses, qualified transfers to a surviving spouse, charitable bequests, and state death taxes.
* The federal estate tax is computed by applying the tax rate schedule to the sum of the decedent's taxable estate and lifetime taxable gifts, and then reducing the result by any available credits. The unified transfer tax credit, the credit for foreign death taxes, and the credit for previously taxed property are the three major estate tax credits presently in effect.
* The gift tax is a tax imposed on an annual basis on all gratuitous transfers of property made during life. The taxable gift is determined by reducing the gross value of the gift by the available deductions and exclusions, such as the annual per donee exclusion, the gift tax marital deduction, and the gift tax charitable deduction.
* The generation-skipping transfer (GST) tax is a flat-rate tax applied to three different transfer events: a direct skip, a taxable termination, or a taxable distribution. The taxable amount for direct skips is the value of the property received by the transferee, while the taxable amount for taxable terminations and distributions is determined by including the tax value with the value of the property before applying the tax rate.
</summary>

<summary>

* Border and Transportation Security (BTS) is a critical function in protecting the American people from terrorists and their weapons.
* The federal government has implemented various programs and policies to achieve BTS, which can be seen as a series of concentric circles or screens, starting from preventive efforts launched outside the country and moving through progressively smaller circles to emergency preparedness and response.
* Congress has shown consistent concern for terrorism and border security, with legislative efforts evolving from understanding the terrorist threat to structural changes, specific actions to protect against immediate threats, and broader, more comprehensive approaches.
* The Homeland Security Act of 2002 created the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the Directorate of BTS, which houses the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection (CBP), the Transportation Security Agency (TSA), and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE).
* CBP is responsible for securing U.S. borders and facilitating the flow of people and goods, while the Coast Guard aids in securing U.S. ports and waterways through defense readiness, drug interdiction, migrant interdiction, and law enforcement-related functions.
* TSA is primarily responsible for securing the nation's air system, with current policies focusing on people-related border security and goods-related border security.
* The U.S. maritime system, with over 300 sea and river ports and more than 3,700 cargo and passenger terminals, has received significant attention due to the potential for terrorists to infiltrate containerships.
* The U.S. government has employed various strategies and programs to secure the nation's borders, including pushing the border outwards, hardening the border, making the border more accessible, strengthening the border through intelligence, and engaging other actors in the enforcement effort.
* Current border security activities involve targeting people and goods for inspection, with over 427 million travelers inspected at a U.S. port of entry in 2004.
</summary>

<summary>

- Cabo Verde is a small island nation with historical ties to the US, located off the coast of West Africa.
- It is considered a success story in Africa with high per capita income levels, high literacy rate, and positive social indicators.
- Its geographic location has made it a transshipment point for Latin American cocaine bound for Europe and a key refueling stopover for trans-Atlantic air traffic.
- US-Cabo Verdean cooperation focuses on counternarcotics efforts, military professionalization, and development projects.
- Cabo Verde is eligible for tariff preferences under the African Growth and Opportunity Act (AGOA), but its use of these benefits is minimal.
- The country is a volcanic island archipelago with few natural resources, but a large maritime zone and beaches that are a tourism destination.
- Cabo Verde was a Portuguese colony until 1975 and most Cabo Verdeans are of mixed Portuguese and African descent.
- It has a successful transition to democracy and a generally consensus-based polity, with two major political parties, the PAICV and the MPD, dominating politics.
- Cabo Verde faces some rule of law and human rights challenges, but its record is better than most other African countries.

</summary>

* Cabo Verde is a small island nation with historical ties to the US, located off the coast of West Africa.
* It is considered a success story in Africa with high per capita income levels, high literacy rate, and positive social indicators.
* Its geographic location has made it a transshipment point for Latin American cocaine bound for Europe and a key refueling stopover for trans-Atlantic air traffic.
* US-Cabo Verdean cooperation focuses on counternarcotics efforts, military professionalization, and development projects.
* Cabo Verde is eligible for tariff preferences under the African Growth and Opportunity Act (AGOA), but its use of these benefits is minimal.
* The country is a volcanic island archipelago with few natural resources, but a large maritime zone and beaches that are a tourism destination.

• The United States and New Zealand have re-established a close security partnership, with recent developments bolstering practical aspects of defense and security cooperation and reaffirming the overall close relationship between the two nations. This partnership is demonstrated by New Zealand's invitation to the Nuclear Summit in 2010 and the lifting of restrictions on New Zealand naval ship visits to U.S. ports in 2012.

• The Wellington Declaration of 2010 and the Washington Declaration of 2012 have played a key role in reorienting the bilateral relationship and establishing a framework for strategic partnership. The two nations have also been working together in addressing regional and global challenges, including enhancing dialogue on regional security in the Pacific and supporting Pacific island countries in patrolling their Exclusive Economic Zones.

1. The U.S. Constitution's Recess Appointments Clause allows the President to appoint certain officials when the Senate is in recess, with the appointee's commission expiring at the end of the next session of Congress.
2. The Recess Appointments Clause has been interpreted to apply to both inter- and intrasession recesses, with the shortest duration for an intrasession recess appointment being 10 days.
3. Recess appointees have the same legal authority as confirmed appointees, but Congress has attempted to discourage recess appointments through legislation such as restricting certain appointees' salaries.
4. The President's recent recess appointments, including Richard Cordray as Director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) and three members of the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB), have raised legal questions about the scope of the President's authority under the Recess Appointments Clause and the statutory authorities these individuals may exercise.
5. A challenge to the President's recess appointments may come from private individuals, Members of Congress, or the Senate as a whole, and would need to satisfy the constitutional standing requirements and prudential principles.
6. The Supreme Court has established a number of "justiciability" doctrines, including the political question doctrine, to ensure that a claim is properly before a court.
7. The political question doctrine may prevent a court from considering certain disputes between the executive and legislative branches, such as those involving the Recess Appointments Clause, if they are considered "inappropriate" for judicial review.
8. The Baker v. Carr standards for determining what constitutes a political question are often considered insufficient, and the Supreme Court has identified certain constitutional provisions, such as the Republican Form of Government Clause, that tend to trigger the political question doctrine.
9. Lower federal courts have considered challenges to presidential appointments made pursuant to the Recess Appointments Clause and have used constitutional text, history, practice, and precedent to resolve interpretive controversies.
10. However, there are important aspects of any potential challenge to a presidential recess appointment that a court may view as "political questions" inappropriate for consideration, such as claims that the President's recess appointment "circumvented and showed an impro

<summary>

* The expedited removal process is a streamlined procedure for removing certain inadmissible aliens from the United States without a hearing or further review.
* It applies to arriving aliens who lack valid entry documents or have attempted to gain admission through fraud or misrepresentation, and in limited circumstances, to aliens present in the United States who have not been admitted or paroled and have been in the country for less than two years.
* Aliens subject to expedited removal who establish a credible fear of persecution or torture are generally detained pending consideration of their applications for asylum and related protections.
* The Supreme Court has upheld DHS's statutory authority to detain aliens potentially indefinitely pending their removal proceedings, but has left unresolved the issue of whether such detention is constitutionally permissible.
</summary>

<summary>

* The principle of a republic is that the people should choose whom they please to govern them, as embodied in congressional redistricting.
* Prior to the 1960s, court challenges to redistricting plans were considered non-justiciable political questions, but the Supreme Court's ruling in Baker v. Carr changed this.
* Recent and pending Supreme Court cases continue to shape the process of congressional redistricting, such as clarifying how to evaluate whether race was a predominant factor in a redistricting plan.
* Key constitutional and federal statutory requirements applicable to congressional redistricting include the standard for equality of population among districts and the Voting Rights Act (VRA).
* The "one person, one vote" standard requires districts to be drawn to achieve exact population equality, with at least once every 10 years, most states required to draw new boundaries for its congressional districts.
* The Supreme Court has interpreted the Constitution to require that each congressional district within a state contain approximately the same population.
* Congressional district boundaries in every state are required to comply with Section 2 of the VRA, which prohibits any voting qualification or practice that results in the denial or abridgement of the right to vote based on race, color, or membership in a language minority.
* The Supreme Court's 2015 ruling in Arizona State Legislature v. Arizona Independent Redistricting Commission upheld an Arizona constitutional provision establishing an independent commission for drawing congressional districts.
* Selected legislation in the 114th Congress includes bills that would establish additional statutory requirements and standards for congressional redistricting.
</summary>

<summary>

* The U.S. Department of Agriculture's Forest Service (FS) and the U.S. Department of the Interior (DOI) manage federal lands and have traditionally funded wildfire programs through the Bureau of Land Management (BLM), but now have a department-wide funding item.
* Federal land wildfire funding has increased since 2000 and now constitutes a significant portion of land management agency budgets. Severe fire seasons have become more common since 2000, with total wildfire funding for FY2008 reaching a record high of $4.46 billion.
* Federal wildfire protection programs are divided into three categories: protection of federal lands, protection of non-federal lands, and fire research, facilities, and forest health.
* The FS was created in 1905 to halt wildfires in national forests following several large fires in 1910. Aggressive fire control policies were developed, with the goal of protecting human life, then private property, and then natural resources.
* In the 1970s, these aggressive fire control policies began to be questioned due to the ecological benefits of wildfires in some situations. In 1994, concerns were raised about unnaturally high fuel loads leading to catastrophic fires and spiraling suppression costs.
* Federal funding for wildfire protection has increased since 2000, with the Clinton Administration developing the National Fire Plan and a supplemental budget request in response to the severe 2000 fire season. The Bush Administration developed the Healthy Forests Initiative in 2002 and the Healthy Forests Restoration Act was enacted in 2003.
* The Federal Land Assistance, Management, and Enhancement (FLAME) Act was enacted in 2009 to insulate other agency programs from high wildfire suppression costs.
</summary>

<summary>

* Social Security coverage is extended to state and local government employees through "Section 218 Agreements" between a state and the Social Security Administration (SSA).
* Under current law, public employees who have a pension plan but are not covered by Social Security can hold a referendum to elect Social Security coverage.
* Proposals to mandate Social Security coverage for all state and local government employees hired in the future have been part of the policy debate for many years.
* State Social Security Administrators are responsible for administering, preparing modifications for, and monitoring coverage of subdivisions under the state's Section 218 Agreement.
* Coverage under Section 218 Agreements differs greatly from state to state and even within a state.
* The Bipartisan Policy Center and the National Commission on Fiscal Responsibility and Reform have recommended mandatory Social Security coverage for newly hired state and local government employees.
* The Social Security Trust Funds are projected to be exhausted by 2036, and mandatory Social Security coverage for newly hired state and local government employees could help close the system's projected long-range funding shortfall.
* Opponents of mandatory coverage argue that it would not necessarily result in better benefit protections for workers and could result in higher payroll taxes and lower benefits for current workers.

</summary>

<summary>

* TAA is a federal program that provides assistance to workers who lose their jobs due to foreign competition.
* Eligible workers receive funding for training and reemployment services, income support while in training, and potentially a tax credit for health insurance premiums.
* Workers aged 50 and over may be eligible for Reemployment Trade Adjustment Assistance, a wage supplement program.
* TAA was reauthorized by the Trade Adjustment Assistance Reauthorization Act of 2015 (TAARA) and is authorized through June 30, 2021.
* TAA is jointly administered by the federal government and the states, and is funded by mandatory appropriations.
* Funding for training and reemployment services is capped at $450 million per year, while funding for income support and wage insurance is not capped.
</summary>

• The Federal Employees Dental and Vision Benefits Enhancement Act of 2004 established the Federal Employees Dental and Vision Insurance Program (FEDVIP), which offers dental and vision plans to federal employees, Members of Congress, annuitants, and dependents.

• Enrollees are responsible for 100% of the premiums, and there are no preexisting condition exclusions, but there are waiting periods for orthodontia. Eligible individuals can enroll during the standard open season for FEHB plans or following a qualifying life event.

• There are four nationwide dental plans and three vision plans, with varying premiums based on plan, family members, and residency (for dental plans only). Active employees pay FEDVIP premiums on a pre-tax basis, but annuitants, survivor annuitants, and compensationers do not have this option.

• The benefits provided by these plans include oral examinations, restorative procedures, endodontic services, periodontal services, major restorative services, prosthodontic services, and orthodontic services for dental plans, and eye exams, lenses, frames, and low vision coverage for vision plans.

• Enrollees will pay less out-of-pocket costs if they use in-network services. Premiums, benefits, and network limitations vary by plan. It is important to compare FEHB coverage to determine if also enrolling in FEDVIP is beneficial.
