* The America COMPETES Reauthorization Act of 2010, also known as COMPETES 2010, was signed into law on January 4, 2011, by President Obama. The law aims to improve U.S. competitiveness by increasing funding for research in the physical sciences and engineering, authorizing certain federal science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education programs and policies, and addressing other related issues.
* COMPETES 2010 reauthorized selected provisions of the 2007 America COMPETES Act (P.L. 110-69) and increased funding authorizations for the National Science Foundation (NSF), the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) core laboratories and construction accounts, and the Department of Energy (DOE) Office of Science. It also authorized new technology transfer and commercialization activities at these agencies.
* The President's FY2013 budget requested increased funding for the doubling path accounts but included support for few COMPETES 2010 authorized STEM education programs. Of the new programs with defined funding authorizations in COMPETES 2010, only the Regional Innovation Program (RIP) at the Department of Commerce (DOC) was specifically included in the Administration's FY2013 budget request.
* The FY2013 NSF budget request included funding for a green chemistry program at NSF, in response to the Green Chemistry Basic Research program authorized by COMPETES 2010.
* The President's FY2013 budget request for NIST was $857.0 million, which was $106.2 million (14.1%) more than the FY2012 enacted level of $750.8 million and $182.7 million (17.6%) less than the authorized level of $1.040 billion.
* The President's FY2013 budget request for the DOE Office of Science was $4.992 billion, which was $57.0 million (1.2%) more than the FY2012 current plan funding level of $4.935 billion and $1.009 billion (16.8

<summary>

* The Lacey Act, enacted in 1900, regulates the trade of wildlife and plants and creates penalties for violations related to domestic and international illegal trade of plants and wildlife.
* The Lacey Act was amended in 2008 to include nonindigenous plants and violations of foreign laws pertaining to certain conservation actions and other activities involving plants and plant products.
* The 2008 amendments expanded the definition of a plant to include any plants, whereas before it referred only to plants indigenous to any state or associated commonwealths, territories, or possessions of the United States.
* The 2008 amendments require importers of all covered plants and plant products to submit an import declaration to U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) at the time of importation, which includes information such as identification of the species and genus of plants or plants used in a product, and country of origin of plants.
* The primary aims of the 2008 amendments were to reduce illegal logging and to increase the value of U.S. wood exports.
* Illegal logging is a pervasive problem affecting several countries that produce, export, and import wood and wood products, with estimates of the extent of illegal logging varying between 15% and 90% of the volume of all forestry.
* The economic value of global illegal logging is estimated to be between $50 billion and $100 billion of the global wood trade, and it is a concern due to its economic implications as well as its environmental, social, and political impacts.
* The Lacey Act is administered by the Departments of the Interior, Commerce, and Agriculture through their respective agencies, including the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS), National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS), and Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS).
* The 2008 amendments to the Lacey Act have been met with criticism, including concerns about the difficulty of monitoring the harvesting and processing of plants and plant products in foreign countries, and the cumbersome and in some cases, not possible to meet, declaration requirements for importing plants and plant products.
</summary>

<summary>

* The farm bill of 2002, known as the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act (FSRIA), provides new long-term counter-cyclical support for grains and cotton, replacing annual PFC payments with fixed, direct payments to farmers. The law also maintains marketing assistance loans and loan deficiency payments, with changes in most loan rates. Soybeans and minor oilseeds are now fully covered under the support program rules that apply to grains and cotton.
* The new counter-cyclical program is not contingent upon acreage reduction rules and payments are based upon historical, not current, production. A key difference is that the new target price payments are not tied to annual planting rules. An individual may receive no more than $130,000 per year in counter-cyclical assistance. Milk support would continue under FSRIA through government purchases of nonfat dry milk, butter, and cheese, with an added feature of counter-cyclical payments.

</summary>

• The United States and Vietnam have expanded relations and cooperation across various sectors since establishing diplomatic relations in 1995, including interest in strengthening nuclear energy cooperation.
• A civilian nuclear cooperation agreement was signed in 2014 under Section 123 of the Atomic Energy Act of 1954, subject to congressional review, which can facilitate the transfer of nuclear energy technology.
• Vietnam has nuclear cooperation agreements with several countries, and the U.S. nuclear industry contends that billions of dollars of exports could result from the Vietnam 123 agreement.
• U.S.-Vietnam cooperation in the nuclear nonproliferation sphere has included converting Vietnam's research reactor from HEU to LEU fuel and returning the HEU fresh and spent fuel to Russia.
• Vietnam plans to build its first nuclear power plants to provide 20%-30% of the country's electricity by 2050, with the first two 1,000 MWe reactors planned at Phuoc Dinh and Vinh Hai.
• The U.S.-Vietnam 123 agreement does not include a legally binding commitment by Vietnam not to build uranium enrichment and reprocessing facilities, and the extent to which Vietnam's human rights record should affect the decision to enter into a nuclear energy agreement was a prominent issue during the congressional review period.
• The nuclear cooperation agreement complies with the Atomic Energy Act as amended and may enter into force after the 90 th day of continuous session following its submittal to Congress unless a joint resolution disapproving the agreement is enacted.

1. * In 2005, there was little progress in resolving the North Korea nuclear issue, with no major reversals or breakthroughs in relationships and regional trends. North Korea escalated the security situation on the Korean peninsula through words and actions, including announcing it had nuclear weapons and suspending participation in the Six-Party Talks. However, a joint statement of principles was agreed to in September by all parties during the fourth round of talks, committing North Korea to abandoning all nuclear weapons and existing nuclear programs.
2. * The year saw increased focus on North Korea's human rights record and criminal activities. Jay Lefkowitz was appointed as the Special Envoy for Human Rights in North Korea, and his public statements, along with a high-profile meeting in the White House between President Bush and a prominent North Korean defector and author, amplified the Administration's concern about North Korea's human rights record. In late 2005, American officials imposed penalties on Banco Delta Asia, a Macau bank that allegedly allowed the laundering of U.S. dollars counterfeited by North Korea.
3. * Pyongyang-Seoul relations definitively advanced toward stronger cooperation, with major progress achieved in developing the Kaesong Industrial Zone and tourism numbers and inter-Korean trade increasing. However, ties between Washington and Seoul were often strained by the capitals' different approaches to North Korea. Despite these tensions, Presidents Bush and Roh held summits in June and November, reiterating their shared strategic goal but declining to work out tactical differences. China burnished its leadership credentials as host of the Six-Party Talks process, avoiding major diplomatic crises and strengthening its economic relations with South Korea.

- Proteomics, or the study of proteins, has become more sensitive and accurate in identifying and quantifying proteins in complex samples due to advancements in protein separation techniques and peptide analysis by mass spectrometry. However, obtaining comprehensive protein profiles from very complex samples remains challenging due to the large number of proteins present in the sample over wide concentration ranges. To improve proteome coverage, samples are typically fractionated at either the protein or peptide level, or both. Regardless of the initial fractionation methods used, the final step in most strategies involves analysis of tryptic peptides by LC-MS/MS. However, undersampling can occur, where only a subset of the peptides will be identified if the complexity of these tryptic digests exceeds the analytical capacity of the mass spectrometer. This has raised concerns about the general value of proteomics for most applications, as the identifications of abundant proteins are reproducible, while most of the variability is observed in lower-abundance proteins.
- To achieve more comprehensive proteome coverage, strategies such as repetitive LC-MS/MS analyses, longer HPLC gradients, or additional fractionation via either more fractions or more modes of separation of complex proteomes can be used. However, the key factor is to determine the most time- and resource-effective strategies for achieving a high depth of analysis, as these factors directly affect sample throughput and proteome analysis cost. In a study comparing the effects of two commonly used strategies, gelc-ms/ms with repetitive lc-ms/ms analysis and additional protein prefractionation, it was found that both strategies conferred some benefit in terms of depth of analysis and reproducibility using cancer cell lysates. However, the 3-d method, which included the prefractionation of the cell lysate using microscale solution isoelectrofocusing prior to the SDS-PAGE separation, substantially improved proteome coverage compared with the repetitive analysis of fractions from the 2-d method.

• The study found that the incidence of secondary, delayed hemorrhage was significantly higher in patients who underwent tonsillectomy (5.05%) compared to those who underwent submucosal uvulopalatopharyngoplasty with tonsillectomy (smuppp) (1.45%).
• The study suggests that suturing both the muscular and mucosal layers of the tonsillar fossa in smuppp decreases the incidence of postoperative bleeding, and double-layer closure and approximating muscular and mucosal layers after tonsillectomy might help postoperative oropharyngeal healing, resulting in decreased bleeding incidence.

<summary>

- The -lactam and -lactam scaffolds are important in various biologically relevant compounds and pharmaceuticals.
- The group has explored the synthesis of -lactams using aryl-, thioaryl-, and cyano-substituted anhydrides, demonstrating the possibility of one-pot four-component reactions (4CRs) with thioaryl substitution.
- Computational studies suggest that cyanosuccinic anhydride reactions proceed by a Mannich-like mechanism via the enol tautomer of the anhydride.
- Related reactions reported by Castagnoli, Cushman, and Haimova likely proceed by this mechanism as well.
- The anhydrides used in these reactions are poorly enolizable and require forcing conditions.
- Cushman and Haimova later reported analogous reactions with homophthalic anhydride, which is highly enolizable and reacts at lower temperatures.
- The group then explored Mannich-type reactions and related 4CRs of variously substituted anhydrides.
- Aryl-substituted succinic anhydrides showed some variation in reactivity based on the substituents attached to the aromatic ring.
- Direct attachment of an electron-withdrawing group resulted in higher reactivity.
- The diastereoselectivity was reversed relative to the aryl and thioaryl cases and could be controlled by resident stereogenic centers in cyanosuccinic anhydride reactions.

</summary>

1. <summary>The morbidity of breast cancer is increasing, and early detection and analysis of molecular biology characteristics are important for treatment. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) have been found to play a role in the invasion and development of breast cancer.</summary>
2. <summary>Some miRNAs, such as mir-125a, mir-206, and mir-145, have functions similar to anti-oncogenes and are related to the occurrence of tumors. Mir-206 plays a key role in adjusting breast cancer proliferation, and mir-125a can inhibit the metastatic and invasive abilities of breast cancer cells.</summary>
3. <summary>The expression levels of mir-125a, mir-206, and mir-145 in breast cancer tissues are lower than those in para-carcinoma tissues. Mir-145 is negatively correlated with tumor size and lymph node metastasis, and is correlated with negative estrogen receptor (ER), human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2), and topoisomerase 2A (TOP2A) expression.</summary>
4. <summary>Mir-21 and mir-10b have functions similar to oncogenes and are related to the invasion and metastasis of tumors. The expression of mir-21 and mir-10b in breast cancer tissues is higher than that in para-carcinoma tissues. Mir-21 exhibits high expression in older, postmenopausal patients with various symptoms, such as lymph node metastasis and positive HER2.</summary>
5. <summary>The relative transcript levels of mir-21 and mir-10b in patients' tumor tissues are higher than those in para-carcinoma normal tissues, while the relative transcript levels of mir-145, mir-125a, and mir-206 in patients' tumor tissues are apparently lower than those in para-carcinoma normal tissues. These miRNAs can be used as markers of breast cancer for early diagnosis.</summary>

• Transplantation is limited by organ shortage and unfavorable long-term success due to chronic allograft injury (CAI), which is caused by chronic allograft vasculopathy (CAV), glomerulosclerosis, and interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy (IFTA).
<summary>

• The pathogenesis of CAI is poorly understood, but acute rejection episodes are a significant risk factor. A model using Fischer-344 (F344) to Lewis rat strain combination has been established to study CAI, and a severe but reversible acute rejection episode occurs 9 days after allogenic transplantation.

• During acute rejection, there is a strong mononuclear infiltration of the allograft interstitium and numerous leukocytes accumulate in the blood vessels. After resolution of acute rejection, the number of intravascular leukocytes decreases but remains chronically elevated compared to healthy kidneys.

• A majority of blood leukocytes in day 9 allografts are monocytes displaying a unique state of partial activation regarding cell surface antigen and cytokine expression. These cells interact with graft endothelial cells and might trigger CAV, which is characterized by intimal hyperplasia.

• Tissue transglutaminase (TG2) was found to be upregulated by mononuclear leukocytes accumulating in the lumina of allograft blood vessels. TG2 is a protein that catalyzes posttranscriptional modifications of proteins, resulting in cross-linking of proteins and modifications via amine incorporation into proteins and via deamidation.

• TG2 has a bewildering functional diversity and is involved in numerous cellular processes such as apoptosis and cell survival, phagocytosis, cell adhesion and migration, and cell signaling. TG2 is ubiquitously expressed and localizes to virtually all compartments of the cell, including the cytoplasm, the nucleus, and mitochondria.

• The study investigates TG2 mRNA and protein expression by mononuclear blood leukocytes isolated from Lewis to Lewis isografts and F344

<summary>

- Endothelial cells were grown and stimulated with plasminogen activation inhibitor-1 (PAI-1) to produce extracellular microvesicles (EMVs).
- EMVs were characterized and quantified using flow cytometry based on CD31- and annexin V-positivity in a size gate of less than 1 μm.
- EMVs were introduced to a model patient circuit and circulated through a CVVH filter for 70 minutes.
- EMV levels were recorded and expressed as a fraction of starting concentration after mixing occurred.
- The decline in EMV levels due to dialysis was rapid, with 50% clearance seen in the first 30 minutes and a relatively constant level of 29% of starting concentration thereafter.
- At the end of 4 hours of uninterrupted dialysis, the dialysate contained 5.7% of the original EMV concentration.
- The findings support the idea of CVVH as a meaningful therapeutic intervention in acute lung injury (ALI) due to clearance of EMVs from the patient circulation.
- The experimental conditions achieved the same plasma level of EMVs as seen in human clinical disease (110 per ml).
- Limitations of the model include the potential for saturable emp-binding, the relative volume of human circulation to CVVH circuit, and the absence of convection and pressure gradient forces.

</summary>

<summary>

- Frequent angina is associated with greater physical limitations and decreased quality of life.
- The goals of chronic stable angina management include symptom control and reducing the risk of adverse clinical outcomes.
- Optimal medical therapy, along with aggressive risk factor modification, is as effective as revascularization in reducing the risk of adverse coronary events.
- Nitrates, such as sublingual nitroglycerin, reduce angina symptoms and prolong exercise duration.
- A combination of anti-anginal agents is often necessary for optimal symptom control.
- Increased physical exercise is important for patients with stable angina to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events.
- A study found that sublingual nitroglycerin spray increased time to onset of moderate angina during exercise, which may have clinical relevance for patients with stable angina.
- Further studies are needed to evaluate the long-term beneficial effects of using routine prophylactic nitroglycerin spray in patients with stable angina.

</summary>

<summary>

- The presence of residual and resistant microorganisms, including fungi like Candida albicans, is a major cause of root canal treatment failures.
* Candida albicans is found in 20% of endodontic treatment failures and has a tendency to invade dentin.
* The presence of Candida albicans in endodontic treatment failures may be due to coronal leakage after or contamination during the treatment.
* Factors such as resistance to intracanalicular treatment materials and ability to survive without nutrients may contribute to the persistence of Candida albicans in the root canal system.
* Mineral trioxide aggregate (MTA) is a commonly used root-end filling material with excellent sealing ability, biocompatibility, high alkalinity, radiopacity, and antimicrobial effects.
* MTA Angelus has been reported to have good marginal adaptation, good sealing, sealing ability in mineralized tissues with complete closure, and is inflammation-free in most cases.
* MTA Angelus has an excellent antibacterial effect and a strong fungicidal effect against Candida albicans.
* A study was conducted to evaluate and compare the antifungal properties of fresh and set ProRoot MTA and MTA Angelus against Candida albicans at 1-, 24-, and 48-hour time points.
</summary>

<summary>

* Deficits in motor and sensory functions on the side of the body contralateral to the damaged hemisphere of the brain are common after a stroke.
* There is increasing evidence of subtle motor deficits on the ipsilateral side, or the side of the body that is contralateral to the damaged hemisphere.
* Ipsilateral motor deficits emerge during the acute phase of stroke and persist chronically, but the reasons for their presence are unclear.
* Clinical assessment tools may not be sufficient for detecting ipsilateral motor deficits, but laboratory testing has identified deficits in dexterous motor and coordination function on the ipsilateral side.
* Recent studies have also found kinematic deficits in the ipsilateral upper limb during the performance of specific motor tasks requiring dexterity and coordination.
* Several possible mechanisms for ipsilateral motor deficits have been suggested, including disrupted counterbalance of each hemisphere, dysfunction of the uncrossed corticospinal tract, and the different roles of both sides in hemispheric functions.
* Most studies of ipsilateral deficits in stroke patients have focused on motor deficits, rather than sensory deficits.
* A study was conducted to investigate the presence of motor and sensory deficits in the ipsilateral upper limb of stroke patients and to examine the correlation between the two variables.
* The study found that stroke patients had a lower accuracy index in a tracking task and a higher score of reposition errors in a joint reposition test, indicating the presence of motor and sensory deficits.
</summary>

* The study found a significant correlation between ipsilateral sensory deficits and motor deficits in stroke patients.
* The findings suggest that stroke patients have difficulty performing complicated motor tasks requiring delicate sensoriomotor functions due to the negative correlation between motor and sensory deficits.
* The study also supports previous research suggesting the presence of motor deficits in upper limbs ipsilateral to the damaged hemisphere in the visuomotor tracking task.
* A possible mechanism for the motor dysfunction in the ipsilateral hemisphere of stroke patients is bilateral hemisphere activation during the performance of motor tasks.

1. * The use of nanoparticles for targeted delivery of biopharmaceutical agents to specific cells has been a long-term goal, but specific binding mediated cell entry can be overwhelmed by non-specific enhanced cell uptake mechanisms.* A post-coupling methodology has been developed to attach biological targeting ligands to nanoparticles with controlled mol% attachment and ligand orientation, enabling integrin receptor-mediated cellular uptake of agents to cells. This methodology has been used to create integrin-targeted imaging nanoparticles that can mediate integrin-specific delivery of an API such as siRNA to v3/5 integrin-receptor presenting cells.
2. * The biophysical properties of the nanoparticle platform, including nanoparticle dimensions, potential values, and ligand surface coverage, are crucial for successful receptor-mediated cell entry. Further research is needed to determine if these three nanoparticle "rules" for receptor-mediated cell entry are general rules or simply guidelines for receptor-mediated cellular uptake of nanoparticle systems by corresponding receptor-expressing cells in vitro, ex vivo, and/or in vivo.

<summary>

* The Millennium Cohort Study is the largest prospective study using primary data collection ever undertaken by the Department of Defense (DoD), focusing on health, behavioral risk factors, and occupational characteristics related to military service that may be associated with adverse health outcomes.
* The study began in 2001, with the first enrollment cycle including 77,047 participants (36% of those able to be contacted). Approximately 71% of those participants enrolled at baseline responded to follow-up surveys conducted in 2004 and 2007.
* The study assessed self-reported provider-diagnosed medical conditions, mental health symptoms, physical and functional status, alcohol and tobacco use, occupational status, military exposures, sleep patterns, and demographic information.
* The primary data sources were the self-administered Millennium Cohort Surveys and DoD electronic personnel files, managed by the Defense Manpower Data Center.
* The study found that participants who newly self-reported diabetes during follow-up were significantly more likely at baseline to have reported trouble sleeping, sleep duration of 5 hours, and sleep apnea.
* Military service characteristics, such as no deployment, enlisted pay grade, administration/supply occupation, and having separated from the military since baseline, were significantly related to the outcome of new-onset diabetes.
* Sleep characteristics, including reported trouble sleeping and sleep apnea, remained significantly and independently associated with higher diabetes odds, even after adjusting for other covariates.
* A positive screen for PTSD was significantly associated with higher diabetes odds, independent of sleep characteristics and other covariates in the model.
* The study findings suggest that sleep characteristics are associated with subsequent new-onset self-reported diabetes, independent of mental health conditions and sleep apnea.

</summary>

1. <summary>The study retrospectively reviewed the radiological and clinical findings of 13 patients with a pathologically confirmed mesenchymal hamartoma of the liver. The patients were aged from 6 months to 7 years 6 months, and the tumors occurred in the right lobe of the liver in nine patients and in the left lobe in four patients. The tumors were classified into three types based on the extent of the cystic component on CT scans: multiseptated cystic, mixed solid and cystic, and solid. The study found that the amount of hepatocytes was significantly different among the three types of tumors.</summary>
2. <summary>Histologically, a mesenchymal hamartoma appears as a disordered arrangement of mesenchyme, bile ducts, and hepatocytes. Cystic degeneration of the mesenchyme may lead to enlargement of the tumor. A multiseptated cystic appearance is a typical finding of mesenchymal hamartoma, while intratumoral calcification is rare. The study reported two cases of mesenchymal hamartoma with calcification in a 57-year-old woman and a 10-year-old boy.</summary>
3. <summary>In children with a solid mesenchymal hamartoma, radiological differential diagnosis should include various hepatic tumors such as a hepatoblastoma, a hepatocellular carcinoma, an infantile hemangioendothelioma, a hepatic adenoma, or a focal nodular hyperplasia. Heterogeneous enhancement and absence of a tumor capsule in a mesenchymal hamartoma can be helpful in the differential diagnosis from other tumors.</summary>

<summary>

- Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic autoimmune disease that affects people of all ages, but its prevalence increases with age and is more common in women. The prevalence of RA in Northern Europe and North America is estimated to be 0.5-1%, while in Southern Europe, it is estimated to be lower at 0.45-0.66%. The annual incidence of RA is also lower in Southern European countries. The economic burden of RA is significant, with costs varying across countries due to differences in methods of calculation, reimbursement policies, availability of drugs and social services, and treatment guidelines.
- In Italy, the healthcare costs associated with age-related diseases like RA are expected to increase due to the aging population. The introduction of newer costly therapies may further contribute to the economic burden of RA in Italy. A review of the economic impact of RA in Italy in the past two decades found that the costs of RA before and after the introduction of biological agents were not significantly different. However, the review predicted that the future costs of RA in Italy would increase and be higher than those in other European countries.
- Studies have shown that the prevalence of RA in Italy is around 0.5%. The largest study on the prevalence and incidence of RA in Italy involved more than 4.5 million people and indicated that both the prevalence and incidence of RA progressively increase in both men and women up to the age of 80 years. As Italy is undergoing a demographic transition, the number of elderly people is expected to increase, leading to a heavy socioeconomic burden on the National Health Service (NHS) in the coming years.
- The severity and progression of RA have a significant impact on the costs of the disease. The introduction of biological drugs for the treatment of RA highlights the role of economics in patient access to innovative but expensive treatments. Health-economic analyses should consider the long-term evolution of the disease in terms of its impact on social costs and loss of productivity, as rapid/severe progression can lead to huge increases in indirect social costs and loss of productivity.

</summary>

1. A patient with missing teeth and restricted mouth opening due to oral submucous fibrosis and bilateral angular cheilitis was treated with sectional maxillary and mandibular final impression procedures, followed by fabricating maxillary hinged and mandibular sectional and hinged complete dentures.
2. The sectional impression trays were fabricated and border molding and final impression were made individually with each half of the tray. The denture bases were fabricated and then were sectioned from the midline. Wax rims were prepared over the denture bases and teeth arrangement was done.
3. The maxillary and mandibular hinged and sectional dentures with anterior removable partial denture were placed in the patient's mouth. The patient was educated about the insertion and removal of dentures and was recalled for follow-up visits to check for maintenance and patient's adaptability with the dentures.

• Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is the sixth most common malignancy worldwide and the third leading cause of cancer-related mortality.
• Risk factors for HCC development include chronic liver inflammation from hepatitis B and C infection, autoimmune hepatitis, excessive alcohol use, nonalcoholic steatohepatitis, primary biliary cirrhosis, environmental carcinogens such as aflatoxin B, and genetic metabolic diseases.
• HGF-cMET signaling is critical for normal processes such as embryogenesis, organogenesis, and postnatal tissue repair after acute injury, but its activation is also implicated in cellular invasion and metastases in HCC.
• HGF-cMET pathway plays an essential role in mammalian development and is likely to be critical in many aspects of adult homeostasis, including cardiac and hepatic tissue injury repair.
• Dysregulation of the HGF-cMET axis occurs in various solid tumors and hematopoietic-derived malignancies, promoting tumor cell migration, epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition, invasion, proliferation, and angiogenesis.
• Overexpression of HGF and cMET is observed in a significant portion of human HCC samples, and cMET overexpression has been correlated with poorly differentiated HCC, increased intrahepatic metastases, and shorter five-year survival.
• Pharmacologic cMET inhibition is a promising therapeutic strategy for HCC, with several inhibitors in active clinical trials, targeting ligand-receptor interaction, cMET kinase activity, and cMET and adaptor protein interaction.

• Recent epidemiologic studies have confirmed an increased risk of certain types of malignancies, including breast, colon, and pancreatic tumors, in patients with type 2 diabetes. The long-acting insulin analogue, glargine, is one of the most commonly used agents in the management of type 2 diabetes, and several studies have demonstrated its potential mitogenic and anti-apoptotic effects on cultured cancer cells. However, the clinical implications of these findings remain controversial.

• A series of studies published in Diabetologia have suggested a specific cancer risk associated with glargine, particularly in women with breast cancer. However, other studies have not found an increased risk of total or site-specific cancer associated with overall glargine use. The use of insulin therapy, including glargine, has been associated with an increased risk of malignancy, particularly colorectal and pancreatic tumors. Concomitant metformin therapy has been shown to attenuate this effect. Further research is needed to address the relationship between diabetes, insulin, insulin analogues and secretagogues, and cancer, and to explore potentially protective effects of metformin.

<summary>

* Adamantinoma of the tibia is a slow-growing primary bone tumor, with approximately 300 cases reported in English language literature.
* The most common site of metastasis is the lungs, but regional lymph node metastases are rare and not well-studied.
* The relationship between osteofibrous/fibrous dysplasia and adamantinoma is controversial, with some authors suggesting a spectrum of disease.
* The document reports two cases of tibial adamantinoma with problematic diagnoses, including one case with inguinal lymph node metastases initially misdiagnosed as a cutaneous adnexal carcinoma.
* A review of inguinal nodal metastatic adamantinoma is provided, along with chronological review of 10 cases with inguinal lymph node metastases from adamantinoma of the tibia as reported in English literature since 1930.
* Risk factors for metastases include male sex, persistent pain, symptoms of less than five years duration, and inadequate initial treatment.
* Increased clinical awareness of rare neoplasms and uncommon patterns of metastases is essential for accurate diagnosis and optimal patient management.
</summary>

1. * Antireflection (AR) technology is important for high-efficiency solar cells, and combining surface texturization with thin-film deposition can result in low light reflectivity in crystalline silicon solar cells.
2. * To further reduce reflectivity and improve solar cell efficiency, nanostructures made of wide bandgap materials have been proposed, including ZnO nanostructures, which have been popularly used in photocatalysis and optoelectronic nanodevices.
3. * ZnO nanostructures can be fabricated using various approaches, including a seeding and growth two-step process in zinc salt and amide mixed solutions, which is low cost and has good potential for scale-up.
4. * Experiments have shown that ZnO nanorod arrays can exhibit better antireflective properties than other oxide compounds, and a weighted global reflectance of 6.6% has been achieved in the broadband range from 400 to 1,200 nm.
5. * The document describes the growth of ZnO nanowhiskers (NWS) on the surface of Czochralski (CZ) silicon solar cells using the seeding and growth two-step process, resulting in a 3% relative improvement in solar cell efficiency.

<summary>

* Hyperhidrosis is a condition that is not well understood, affecting 0.6-1.0% of the population, and typically manifests in childhood or early adolescence.
* The principal characteristics of hyperhidrosis include intense discomfort that affects social, affective, and professional lives, and it generally occurs in the axillae, palms, plantar surface of the feet, and the face.
* Although various treatment options are available, they have limitations, and video-assisted thoracic sympathicotomy (VATS) has been accepted globally as a form of treatment for primary palmar hyperhidrosis.
* This study aimed to compare two simplified methods for the treatment of palmar and axillary hyperhidrosis, in which the sympathetic chain was transected in merely one segment at the level of either the third or fourth rib.
* Between January 1999 and April 2009, 133 patients with primary hyperhidrosis underwent VATS, and the severity of palmar sweating, sweating in other parts of the body, other concomitant symptoms, and past medical history were recorded.
* The incidence of "moderate" to "severe" compensatory sweating was higher in the r3 (71.8%) group than r4 (33%, p=0.02).
* No patient requested reoperation in either group, and no patient expressed regret after surgery.
* The study suggests that r4 sympathicotomy decreases the extent of side effects but does not compromise efficacy compared to r3 sympathicotomy, and it should be the method of choice for the treatment of palmar and axillary hyperhidrosis.
* Both r3 and r4 sympathicotomy have similar success rates in the treatment of palmar and axillary hyperhidrosis.

</summary>

<summary>

- Parkinson's disease (PD) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the degeneration of dopaminergic and non-dopaminergic neurons with Lewy bodies.
- The clinical diagnosis of PD is often straightforward, but it can be challenging in mild or uncertain cases and in differentiating it from other neurodegenerative parkinsonian syndromes such as multiple system atrophy (MSA), progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP), and corticobasal degeneration.
- Molecular imaging techniques such as dopamine transporter (DAT) ligands and meta-[i]-iodobenzylguanidine (MIBG) myocardial scintigraphy can improve the diagnostic accuracy of PD and non-PD.
- DAT SPECT abnormalities can support a diagnosis of degenerative parkinsonian syndromes by excluding patients with essential tremor, psychogenic, and vascular parkinsonism. However, it cannot differentiate between the various types of degenerative parkinsonian syndromes with sufficient accuracy.
- MIBG myocardial scintigraphy can assess the sympathetic cardiac nerve terminals in PD patients, with a decreased cardiac MIBG uptake in comparison with other parkinsonian syndrome patients.
- The use of either DAT SPECT or MIBG scintigraphy alone is insufficient for distinguishing PD from non-PD due to their limited test accuracy.
- A retrospective study compared the results of SPECT studies of striatal DAT receptors and myocardial MIBG scintigraphy with the clinical diagnoses in 34 patients with suspected parkinsonian syndromes to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy and usefulness of combined SPECT imaging in the same patient population.
- The study found that the combined use of DAT SPECT and MIBG myocardial scintigraphy allowed for more accurate differentiation between PD and non-PD, with a sensitivity of 86.7%, a specificity of 73.7%, an accuracy of 79.4%, a positive predictive value of 72.2%, and a negative predictive value of 87.5%.

</summary>

Note: PD stands

1. A 73-year-old Korean man presented with a round nodule in the left perianal area, which was caused by a perianal infestation with the tick species Amblyomma testudinarium. The patient had recently visited a rural county in South Korea and felt a pain of sting around his anus while defecating.
2. The tick was surgically removed and identified as a female adult of A. testudinarium based on its morphological characteristics. This species is more common in tropical areas, including Southeast Asia and the Indian peninsula. In Korea, it is distributed in Jeju Island and the southern coastal area of the mainland.
3. The tick's saliva has anti-inflammatory effects, which cause a paucicellular zone with relatively few inflammatory cells around the lesion abutting the cement. The salivary glands of hard ticks, including A. testudinarium, secrete eosinophilic cement material that helps attachment of the tick to the host for the feeding period.
4. A. testudinarium is known to be distributed in Korea, but human infestation is rare. This case extends the geographic range of distribution of A. testudinarium in the Korean peninsula, as the patient was infested in a western coastal area of Jeollanam-do, which is below 36 north latitude.

1. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is a genetic disorder characterized by left and/or right ventricular hypertrophy, with predominant involvement of the interventricular septum. It can be caused by mutations in genes that encode sarcomere proteins, including cardiac troponin T (TNNT2).
2. Mutations in TNNT2 have been associated with a severe form of HCM, characterized by a poor overall prognosis with a high incidence of sudden death despite only mild left ventricular hypertrophy. However, the genotype-phenotype correlation of this gene still remains insufficient in Japanese familial HCM.
3. The phenotypic expression of TNNT2 mutations varies considerably, ranging from asymptomatic individuals with a normal life expectancy to those with sudden cardiac death or the need for an early heart transplant. Clinical parameters such as the degree of left ventricular hypertrophy, the presence or absence of a left ventricular outflow tract gradient, and electrophysiology testing have not been predictive markers of poor prognosis.
4. Late gadolinium enhancement with cardiac magnetic resonance can be a predictive marker of the ventricular arrhythmia and poor prognosis in HCM. Genetic test-based risk stratification has been considered to be clinically informative, but the specific gene mutation cannot be the sole factor that dictates clinical phenotype. The development of a case-based method would be useful to treat and help each individual, and more attention needs to be paid toward searching for the modifier and environmental factors including diet, lifestyle, exercise, and the modification gene and polymorphism.

1. Schistosomatidae is a family of digenetic endoparasites with complex life cycles that alternate between intermediate (freshwater gastropods) and definitive hosts (birds, reptiles, fishes, and mammals). The Schistosoma species can live in the human host for over 5 years. Schistosoma, the avian and mammalian blood flukes, is the best-studied genus of Schistosomatidae, with six species known to infect humans and cause schistosomiasis.
2. The genomes of S. haematobium, S. japonicum, and S. mansoni have been sequenced, revealing that they carry a nuclear genome of approximately 385, 397, and 363 megabases, respectively, and are composed of approximately 13,073, 13,469, and 10,852 protein-coding genes. Comparative genomics of three Schistosoma species has revealed several conserved features, including overall GC content, sequence identity, presence of repetitive elements, and synteny.
3. Mitochondrial genes have been used as molecular markers for species and strain identification, and the analysis of the whole mitochondrial genome of diverse taxa has changed the perspective of such studies. The mitochondrial genome of six Schistosoma species has been sequenced, ranging in size from 13,503 to 16,901 bp and encoding 36 genes. Comparative mitogenomics has revealed a highly conserved gene order among distinct platyhelminthes, except for some Schistosoma species. The unique gene order rearrangements identified in these species constitute valuable information for the reconstruction of the phylogenetic relationships of Schistosoma and other platyhelminthes.

1. * The study found that for patients with synchronous colorectal liver metastases (sCLM), simultaneous resection of the primary colorectal and liver tumors is a favorable strategy, but it is associated with a high morbidity rate due to greater surgical stress and longer operation time.
2. * The study aimed to determine which patients could benefit from staged resections instead of simultaneous resection by identifying predictive factors for postoperative morbidity and anastomotic leakage after simultaneous resection of sCLM. The medical records of 86 patients who underwent liver resections for colorectal liver metastases from January 1992 to January 2004 were analyzed. The results showed that an operation time greater than 8 hours was the only independent predictive factor for anastomotic leakage after simultaneous resection of sCLM.

1. Asthma is a chronic inflammatory disease that affects the performance of daily activities and requires pharmacological treatment to achieve and maintain clinical control.
2. Inhalation is the most widely used approach for asthma treatment, allowing drugs to reach the lungs in a selective manner and reducing systemic adverse effects.
3. However, only half of all asthma patients use the prescribed medication correctly, and incorrect inhaler use can lead to treatment failure and difficulty in achieving clinical control.
4. The frequency of incorrect use of metered dose inhalers (MDIs) ranges from 14% to 90%, reducing lung drug deposition to less than 20%.
5. Scoring systems that assess the difficulties patients face in using inhaled drugs can be useful in reducing those difficulties and improving treatment adherence.
6. Two scoring systems have been developed to assess the ability of patients to use MDIs or dry powder inhalers (DPIs), but they have not yet been validated.
7. The present study aimed to validate these scores, identify the most common errors made during inhaler use, and identify patients in need of an educational program for inhaler use.
8. The study included patients diagnosed with asthma, in outpatient treatment for at least two years, between 15 and 65 years old, with at least four years of schooling, no hearing impairment, and who agreed to participate in the study. Patients who had previously participated in educational programs regarding the use of asthma medications were excluded.

1. <summary>Enterocin S37 is a bacteriocin produced by a strain of Enterococcus faecalis recently isolated from chicken feces. It has potential as a food preservative and shows activity against the foodborne pathogen Listeria monocytogenes and, to a lesser extent, Campylobacter jejuni. The bacteriocin is heat-stable and resistant to pH changes, but sensitive to proteases. Its activity increased during the purification process, and it may be a class IIa bacteriocin.</summary>
2. <summary>The study of the effects of K channel modulators on enterocin S37 revealed that cromakalim and pinacidil, which act on ATP-sensitive potassium channels, caused membrane hyperpolarization and inhibited the growth of sensitive L. monocytogenes strains. Glipizide, which affects cell membrane potential and calcium ion influx, had a weaker inhibitory effect. The combination of enterocin S37 and K channel modulators suggested an implication in a depletion of intracellular potassium levels, affecting the growth of sensitive cells.</summary>
3. <summary>The lipid composition of the cell membrane plays a role in the efficiency of bacteriocin activity. Enterocin S37 alone did not affect the growth of a bacteriocin-resistant variant of L. monocytogenes, but the combination of enterocin S37 and K channel modulators impacted strongly the growth of the resistant variant. The mode of action of enterocin S37 may be triggered by potential interaction with the cell membrane, leading to the formation of pores and the loss of intracellular components, resulting in cell death.</summary>

<summary>

* The study was conducted in compliance with various guidelines and regulations, and approval was obtained from the institutional review board.
* The phase 1 study was a first-in-human, open-label, escalating-dose study to assess the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of a single intrathecal dose of nusinersen in children with spinal muscular atrophy.
* A total of 28 children were enrolled and received dosing in the phase 1 study, with 15 children having spinal muscular atrophy type 2 and 13 having spinal muscular atrophy type 3.
* Lumbar punctures were performed at four sites, and the majority of them were carried out using either a 22- (48%) or 25-gauge (37%) needle inserted in the l3-l4 (44%) or l4-l5 (29%) space.
* Nearly half (44%) of the lumbar punctures were guided using fluoroscopy.
* Of the 73 lumbar punctures performed, the majority (68%) had no complications, while lumbar puncture-related adverse events were reported in 32%.
* The most common adverse events were headache, back pain, and post lumbar puncture syndrome, and all events resolved without long-term complications.
* A subgroup analysis demonstrated that headache, back pain, and post lumbar puncture syndrome were observed more frequently when a 21- or 22-gauge needle was used, in older children (8 - 14 years of age), and in children with spinal muscular atrophy type 3.
* The study suggests that using a 24-gauge or smaller needle would likely reduce the chance of adverse events in children with spinal muscular atrophy.

</summary>

1. <summary> The UK Department of Health introduced Clinical Governance (CG) in 1997 as a strategy to improve the quality of healthcare services. The Iranian Ministry of Health and Medical Education (MOHME) has applied CG in all hospitals since 2009.
2. <summary> The CG model developed in Iran consists of seven interlocking components, including clinical effectiveness, clinical audit, risk management, patient and public involvement, education and training, staff and staff management, and use of information.
3. <summary> A study on the implementation of CG in different health systems and healthcare settings identified several barriers, such as insufficient knowledge and attitude toward CG, lack of resources, inadequate information technology systems, resistance to change, necessity of cultural change, and professional boundaries.
4. <summary> A qualitative research study was conducted to capture both facilitators and barriers in CG implementation from the viewpoint of curative deputies in Iranian medical universities.
5. <summary> The study found that most senior managers accepted that improving the quality of healthcare should be integral to their role and essential to safeguard patient care. They believed that quality improvement is a strategic goal to achieve central government targets.
6. <summary> The findings demonstrated the willingness to support and positive attitude towards CG. Senior managers also declared that having adequate knowledge about CG and a positive attitude toward the necessity of the program are the main factors affecting CG implementation.
7. <summary> The level of enthusiasm expressed by senior managers seemed to be related in particular to their knowledge and attitude about CG concept and components. Those managers who had gained such knowledge were more optimistic toward success of the program.
8. <summary> The main themes of senior managers' viewpoint toward CG barriers and facilitators included knowledge and attitude, culture, organizational factors, managerial factors, and barriers.
9. <summary> The study found that sufficient knowledge and clear understanding about the principles and practice of CG have major roles in achieving desired improvement in service quality and patient safety in healthcare settings.
10. <summary> The study identified several obstacles, such as lack of adequate managerial support, resource, structural and cultural issues, and professional boundaries, and recommended developing educational courses and workshops to raise staff awareness toward CG concept and practice.

1. Hydatid cyst disease is a common zoonotic disease caused by the larval stage of the Echinococcus granulosus parasite. It is prevalent in many countries, including Iran, and is spread through contaminated soil, water, and vegetables. The disease is more common in regions with traditional animal husbandry and close contact with animals.
2. In Khorasan Razavi province of Iran, a cross-sectional study was conducted to determine the epidemiological and clinical status of human hydatidosis during 2011-2014. The study found that the majority of cases were women (54.9%), rural residents (40.3%), and housewives (45.8%). The most common symptom was abdominal pain (42.3%), and liver involvement was reported in 59.4% of patients.
3. The study also found that the majority of patients (70.5%) had a single cyst, and 42.3% of them were diagnosed by radiology method. The most common clinical symptom was abdominal pain (42.3%), and liver involvement was reported in 59.4% of patients.
4. Previous studies in Iran have reported varying incidence rates of hydatidosis, ranging from 0.54 to 13.8 per 100,000 population. The findings of this study suggest that the highest proportion of hydatidosis is in the age group of 21-40 years old and in women. The study also found that contact with dogs and improper washing of vegetables are significant risk factors for infection with hydatidosis.

<summary>

- Ciliated hepatic foregut cysts (CHFCs) are rare, congenital liver cysts first described by Friedrich in 1857.
- CHFCs are thought to result from evagination of the foregut during embryogenesis and have specific characteristics, including four layers: pseudostratified columnar epithelium with mucus cells, sub-epithelial connective tissue, smooth muscle, and outer fibrous capsule.
- CHFCs are usually found in the left lobe of the liver, are mostly asymptomatic, and are typically located superficially in the median segments.
- CHFCs can be confused with other hepatic cysts, such as simple cysts, hydatid cysts, biliary cystadenoma, cystadenocarcinoma, and bronchogenic cysts.
- CHFCs can present with abdominal pain, and the recommended treatment varies from observation to surgical excision.
- CHFCs can harbor squamous cell carcinoma in rare cases, making serial imaging necessary for those undergoing cyst sclerosis.
- Laparoscopic excision is the best approach for CHFCs, especially for lesions in segments II to VI, where visualization and access are easiest.
- Reporting individual cases of CHFCs is essential due to their rarity, as illustrated by the case presented, which highlights the importance of considering CHFC as a diagnosis for a superficially located unilocular hepatic cystic mass and the benefits of laparoscopic excision as a first-line treatment.

</summary>

1. <summary>The oral route is a preferred method of drug administration due to its safety, ease of use, and patient acceptance. However, low bioavailability, longer onset of action, and difficulty swallowing pills can be drawbacks.</summary>
2. <summary>Fast dissolving tablets (FDTs) are an alternative to traditional oral solid dosage forms, dissolving or disintegrating within 60 seconds without water. They are also known as mouth-dissolving tablets, orodispersible tablets, rapidmelts, and porous tablets.</summary>
3. <summary>FDTs have some disadvantages, such as their physical solid form, psychological fear of swallowing, chewing, or choking, friability, and expensive packaging costs. To address these issues, orally dissolving strips (ODS) have been developed.</summary>
4. <summary>ODS are a more advanced form of oral solid dosage form, providing flexibility and comfort. They dissolve within a minute in the oral cavity without chewing or water, improving drug efficacy and bioavailability.</summary>
5. <summary>ODS are useful for specific patient populations, such as pediatrics, geriatrics, bedridden patients, and those with allergic reactions or sudden coughing episodes. They are also an alternative to FDTs due to their faster dissolution rate, higher flexibility, and better patient compliance.</summary>
6. <summary>Clobazam, a well-tolerated antiepileptic drug, has been formulated as an ODS to improve bioavailability and palatability. This drug candidate is ideal for ODS due to its indication in children and low-dose requirement.</summary>
7. <summary>A 3-factorial design was used to evaluate the influence of film forming polymer PVA and disintegrating agent SSG on the film's mechanical properties, disintegration time, and dissolution rate. The in vivo performance and IVIVC of the optimum formulation were also assessed in healthy rabbits.</summary>
8. <summary>The prepared ODS of clobazam using PVA and PEG 400 as plasticizers showed satisfactory drug dissolution and acceptable physicomechanical characteristics. The formulation f6, with 100 mg

<summary>

* Stroke is a major cause of death and disability worldwide.
* Self-management interventions (SMIs) are designed to help individuals manage their health more effectively, but their evaluation is complex due to variation in delivery and goals.
* The theoretical basis of SMIs is unclear, and it is uncertain which outcomes should be monitored to assess their cost-effectiveness and clinical impact.
* Patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) are important for evaluating SMIs, but their accuracy depends on their ability to reflect the variable in question.
* A recent international Delphi study resulted in the Consensus-based Standards for the Selection of Health Status Measurement Instruments (COSMIN) checklist, which can be used to assess the methodological quality of studies on measurement properties.
* The COSMIN checklist has good inter-rater agreement and reliability and addresses modern psychometric theory methodology.
* The current review aims to systematically examine the outcome measures adopted in stroke SMIs in terms of their methodological quality and psychometric properties for use with stroke populations.
* The review focuses on the value of the outcome measures used in stroke SMIs, rather than the quality of the studies or the effectiveness of the interventions.
* The COSMIN checklist defines nine properties that will be examined, including internal consistency, reliability, measurement error, content validity, structural validity, hypothesis testing, cross-cultural validity, criterion validity, and responsiveness.
* The review identified 43 different outcome measures used in stroke SMIs, but only 21 of these demonstrated some properties in stroke populations according to the COSMIN checklist.

</summary>

1. * Osteoarthritis (OA) in the knee joint is a common cause of functional disability and reduced quality of life in older adults in India.
* Physiotherapists use a combination of self-reported questionnaires and performance-based tests to monitor OA knee rehabilitation progress, with each having its own advantages and limitations.
* The study found that the Koos self-reported questionnaire had a weak correlation with the 6-minute walk test (6-MWT) for ADL but strong correlations for symptoms, pain, sports, and quality of life.
* BMI had strong correlations with all Koos subscales, while weight had weak to strong correlations and there was no correlation between age and any Koos subscales except for a weak correlation with quality of life.
* The study results support the use of Koos in Indian OA knee patients, with a similar trend in subscale scores compared to previous studies.
* The correlation between self-reported and performance-based measures is important for a more accurate assessment of OA knee rehabilitation progress.

- Obesity is a low-level, chronic inflammatory disease caused by a combination of factors including a sedentary lifestyle, caloric food consumption, and genetic predisposition. Adipose tissue secretes pro- and anti-inflammatory factors, and a high-fat diet can promote the production of proinflammatory interleukins and a chronic inflammatory process.
* Menopause is defined as the permanent cessation of menstruation due to loss of ovarian function and is associated with adverse changes in lipoproteins, glucose and insulin metabolism, distribution of body fat, clotting, and vascular endothelium. These changes, in combination with weight gain, place women at a high risk of developing cardiovascular diseases.
* A study was conducted to evaluate the effects of a high-fat diet and ovariectomy on the inflammatory process in rats. The results showed that administration of a hyperlipidic diet for 8 weeks combined with short-term ovariectomy promoted an increase in body weight gain and a decrease in metabolic efficiency, accompanied by hyperleptinemia. The cytokines content of the liver and gastrocnemius muscle was unchanged, but levels of all cytokines analyzed were decreased in mesenteric adipose tissues.
* The study also found that ovariectomy in rats fed a hyperlipidic diet caused hyperleptinemia and increased body weight gain, food efficiency, and carcass lipid content. These changes, in combination with long-term ovariectomy, may contribute to the induction of proinflammatory processes, particularly those associated with a high-fat diet. Therefore, after menopause, women must decrease their consumption of fat.

1. Hemoptysis is a common symptom in patients with respiratory diseases and can have a high mortality rate if massive.
<summary>
2. Bronchial artery embolization (BAE) is a safe and effective treatment for both massive and chronic or recurrent hemoptysis.
3. The first step in BAE is a complete angiography of the pulmonary vascular tree, followed by embolization if bleeding bronchial arteries are seen.
4. A retrospective study of 344 patients who underwent BAE found that the main causes of hemoptysis were tuberculosis (55.2%) and bronchiectasis (28.8%).
5. The study also found that BAE was successful in controlling hemoptysis immediately in 96% of patients, but 17.7% had recurrent hemoptysis within 1 month.
6. Complications related to BAE include fever, chest pain, back pain, shoulder pain, and transient dysphagia or lower limb numbness.
7. The long-term outcome of BAE is not good for some patients, but it may be the only life-saving treatment option for those who are poor surgical candidates.
8. The source of massive hemoptysis is usually due to the bronchial circulation (90%), with the remaining 10% divided equally between the pulmonary circulation and other systemic arterial supply to the lungs.
9. The anatomy of bronchial arteries is variable, and the main responsible vessels for bleeding are right bronchial arteries, left bronchial arteries, combined right and left bronchial trunk, and right intercostal arteries.

• Helicobacter pylori (HP) infection and celiac disease (CD) can both cause lymphocytic gastritis (LG), which is defined by the presence of >25 intraepithelial lymphocytes (IELs) per 100 epithelial cells in the gastric mucosa.
• In this study, patients with CD had a higher proportion of LG (50%) compared to patients with HP infection alone (8.3%). HP infection was associated with an increased number of lymphoid aggregates in the antrum, regardless of CD status.
• The study found that CD patients with associated HP infection showed a lower rate of LG, which may be due to the limited role of bacterial infection in cytotoxicity and HP's ability to converge the immune response towards a TH2 response and suppress the TH1 immune response.
• The study suggests that in undefined cases of CD with overlapping clinical and histological features, the number of CD8+ IELs in the antrum may hint toward the diagnosis of CD rather than HP infection, and the number of lymphoid follicles directs toward the diagnosis of HP infection. Therefore, it is important to include immunohistochemical analysis of CD8 lymphocytes in the antrum in undefined cases of CD.

1. Angiogenesis, the process of forming new blood vessels, is required for solid tumor growth and is stimulated by vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF).
2. Inhibition of angiogenesis with drugs could be an important tool in cancer treatment as it can limit tumor growth by preventing the formation of new blood vessels.
3. Anti-angiogenic treatments should have low toxicity and should not interfere with normal cell division, as angiogenesis also occurs during fetal development, menstrual cycle, and wound healing.
4. The targets of anti-angiogenic treatments are normal processes controlled by normal cells, not by tumor cells, making them less susceptible to drug resistance caused by tumor cell mutations.
5. In breast cancer, bevacizumab, a humanized monoclonal antibody that binds human VEGF and prevents it from binding to its receptors, is approved for the treatment of metastatic HER2/neu-negative breast cancer.
6. Inhibition of VEGF binding to its receptors reduces tumor growth, microvessel density, and tumor-associated macrophage infiltration in breast cancer xenografts.
7. VEGF is a major chemoattractant for inflammatory cells, including macrophages, neutrophils, dendritic cells, myeloid-derived suppressor cells, and T cells.
8. Inhibition of VEGF reduces angiogenesis and modulates immune cell infiltration of orthotopic breast cancer xenografts.
9. Angioinhibitors have been approved for the treatment of tumors and age-related macular degeneration, and are being tested in combination with conventional chemotherapy in clinical trials. Preventive angioinhibitory therapy may also be possible in the future.

• Vulvar and vaginal atrophy (VVA) is a common medical condition in postmenopausal women caused by the loss of estrogen stimulation on vaginal and vulvar tissue.
<summary>

• An estimated 32 million postmenopausal women in the US suffer from VVA symptoms including dyspareunia, vaginal dryness, and vaginal irritation.
• VVA is chronic, progressive, and will not resolve without treatment, which can negatively impact women's quality of life, sexual relationships, and emotional well-being.
• The REVIVE survey, conducted among a large cohort of postmenopausal women in the US, highlights women's poor understanding of VVA and concerns about the efficacy, convenience, and safety of VVA treatments.
• The survey findings emphasize the need for better communication between women and healthcare providers (HCPs) about VVA and its treatment options.
• The survey results demonstrate that many postmenopausal women have low awareness and poor understanding of VVA and its associated symptoms, often mistaking it for natural aging.
• Among women who discussed VVA symptoms with an HCP, only 13% reported that the HCP initiated the conversation, indicating a need for HCPs to proactively address VVA with their patients.
• The most commonly reported VVA symptoms among postmenopausal women are vaginal dryness, dyspareunia, and local irritation, with more than half of participants reporting that VVA had the greatest impact on enjoyment of sex.
• Effective patient education should emphasize that VVA is a common medical condition associated with reduced estrogen levels after menopause and that it will worsen over time if left untreated.
• HCPs should guide patients to appropriate treatment options, including prescription therapies that directly improve the physical changes underlying VVA, and counsel women on the many treatment options available for VVA-related symptoms.
</summary>
